column2: PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 15--There is accumlating evidence of change in Czechoslovak internal policy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)-- Three operators of vocational training schools for war veterans refused today to tell Sen ate investigators whether they had belonged to the Communist party in the past.
ALBANY, Jan. 18--Governor Harriman urged the Legislature today to broaden and expand the special services and assfstance that the state and its localities provide for the aged.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18--A new message of world-wide common purpose aimed at the elimination of war and promotion of international welfare was proclaimed today at Independence Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Congressional investigators were told today that the Department of the Interior used unusual procedure in giving to Al Sarena Mines the right to valuable public timber land in Oregon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18-- Sharp denunciation of certain Arab diplomats in this country for "using the public platform to vilify Americans for their friendship for Israel" was made tonight at a meeting of American Jewish leaders.
Commuter reaction to the resignation of Patrick B. McGinnis varied yesterday from jubilant hurrahs to expressions of mild regret.
ALBANY, Jan. 19--One of the Deputy State Directors of Veterans Affairs, a vestige of the Lehman days in Albany, has been ousted to make room for a Harriman Administration appointment.

A "professional workshop," where performers will have the opportunity of refreshing and expanding their acting talents in the classics, has been established at 210 West Sixty-fifth Street. It will be known as the American Shakespeare Festival Academy.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 19 --Indonesia's pro-Western Cabinet, on the verge of collapse tonight, decided to keep its delegation in Geneva to negotiate with the Dutch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP) --George Romney, president of American Motors Corporation, predicted today that automobile makers would "pay the price" in 1956 for their "horse-trading" practices in post-war years.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 19 (UP)-- Patty Berg shot a four-under par 71 today to take the firstround lead in the $5,000 Tampa women's open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- President Eisenhower urged Congress today to clear up a constitutional ambiguity on how a President should be declared unable further to function in office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The United States and Britain have made some progress toward ironing out their differences in the Middle East.

Ray Hickok at 37 is a vigorous, square-shouldered, square-jawed 6-footer. When he greets you in the spacious corner office of the president at the sprawlingHickok Manufacturing Company plant on St. Paul Street in Rochester, N.Y., his warm smile is matched by his handshake. And to yourself you say you'd like to have this man on your side.

Joseph L. Rauh Jr., Washington lawyer, testified yesterday that he advanced $8,500 to get evidence of "illegal activities" by the Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. In return, he declared, he got fabricated documents based on half-truths, rumors and newspaper accounts.

The advertising account of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee, which in 1954 accounted for more than $9,000,000 in billings, has been resigned by Biow-Beirn-Toigo, Inc. The agency was to have taken over the account as of March 1 from Lennen Newell. Inc.

The Louisiana State Building Authority received bids yesterday on $7,600,000 of serial bonds secured by special taxes. The best bid was submitted by a syndicate headed by C.J. Devine Co. The bid represented an interest cost of 3.062 per cent. Subject to award, the bonds were reoffered at yields of 2.5 per cent to 3.05 per cent. The bonds will come due serially on Feb. 1 from 1961 tO 1985.

Brooklyn warehouse workers of the International Longshoremen's Association, independent, rejected yesterday a two-year contract proposed by employers. The action revived the threat of a strike that would tie up foodstuffs and other cargoes.

Just One Break, Inc., an organization that has found employment for several thousand physically disabled persons, will be the beneficiary of the third annual May Festival. The event, a dinner dance, will be held on May 14 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
A new type of transistor, said to be "ideally suited for guided missiles" and for more efficient electronic brains, was announced yesterday by the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
THE expressive hush in Theodoros Stamos' paint ings--the serene, ceremonial atmosphere that pervades the Betty Parsons Galley, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street, where Stamos is showing for the...
PARIS, Jan. 19--According to Abderrahim Bouabid, Moroccan Minister of State, his Government will seek in its talks with France the right to carry on its own diplomacy.

Mrs. Mary Daly Gerard, widow of James W. Gerard, who was Ambassador to Germany in World War I, died Wednesday at her home, 1014 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness. She was 80 years old last Friday. Mr. Gerard died in 1951.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- President Eisenhower defended John Foster Dulles today as "the best Secretary of State" he had ever known.
The controversy as to who should occupy the pulpit of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights moved yesterday into Supreme Court.

PARIS, Jan. 19--France's newly-elected Deputies, after a perfunctory opening session of the National Assembly, returned today to the difficult search for a government to deal with crises at home and abroad.
Two Police Department chaplains spoke before 350 trainees at the Police Academy yesterday on the subject of developing character for their future work.
Mayor Wagner ordered the Department of Health to stand by early this morning to declare a state of emergency if the fourday fuel strike is not settled by 11 A.M.
Snow, scheduled to have hit this city late yesterday afternoon and leave a white blanket of from three to five inches, arrived about six hours later and without much en

PARIS, Jan. 19--The project, for a supranational European community for atomic energy, approved yesterday by the Action Committee for the United States of Europe, received moderate attention in the Paris press today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 19--It appears as if timidity on the propaganda front is tending to obscure whatever the free world's alliance in Southeast Asia may have accomplished to check Communist aggression and subversion.

ABOARD U.S.S. WYANDOT, off Ross Island Antarctica, Jan. 19--An enormous crevasse in the Ross Shelf Ice has temporarily stopped a Navy trail party attempting to make the longest journey by mechanized surface vehicles in the history of Antarctic exploration.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (Reuters) --Mechislovas A. Gedvilas, Premier of Soviet Lithuania since 1943, has been relieved of his post and replaced by a local Communist party leader.

The condemnation of Israel for her military raid of reprisal on the Syrians on Dec. 11 was deserved. The Security Council of the United Nations passed a resolution to this effect yesterday sponsored by the Big Three Western powers but also...

There were some early Christmas shoppers among the 250 persons who attended yesterday's auction of abandoned, forfeited, or unclaimed merchandise by the Bureau of Customs. The sales are held periodically to clear out the backwash of international trade.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 19--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1955:
The P. Lorillard Company is going out of the cigar business. The Consolidated Cigar Corporation yesterday concluded an agreement to buy Lorillard's cigar assets, it was announced...
Flying saucers were found yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel--each with a General Motors "dream car" aboard.
CHRISTOPHER MARLOWE'S "Tamburlaine the Great" made its professional American debut at the Winter Garden last evening, 369 years late.

The hearing of Tex Sullivan and Willie Gilzenberg was postponed until Tuesday morning at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday. Commissioner Julius Helfand granted the request of Francis W.H. Adams, chief counsel for the defendants, for a delay. Adams said he had accepted the case on Monday and had previous commitments.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 19--The Bombay police, fighting to put down the worst political riots in independent India's history, charged tonight that the violence was plotted and led by the Communist party of India.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--President Eisenhower sharply rejected today the criticism of national defense policy made by Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Net income of the International Harvester Company in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 was $55,501,000, or $3.60 a common share. This compared with $36,304,000, or $2.24 a share, a year earlier, John L. McCaffrey, president, announced today in the annual report to shareholders.

Indictments were returned yesterday against eleven additional persons accused of being members of a fake automobile accident ring that was broken up last May. Forty-three persons were arrested at that time, and since then twelve more have been arrested, bringing the total of those under indictment to date to sixty-six.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- President Eisenhower cautioned Republicans today that they had better consider more than one possibility and more than one personality in selecting their 1956 standard bearer.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 19 (UP)--Mike Souchak, a former football player, cracked the course record of the Tijuana Country Club today with a seven-under-par 65. He took the lead at the end of the first round of the $12,500 Caliente open golf tournament.
MONTREAL, Jan. 19--The development of Canada's northern frontier was the subject of the principal briefs submitted today to a royal commission seeking light on this country's economic prospects.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 19-- A legislative challenge to the United States Supreme Court for its ruling against segregated public schools was offered in Virginia's Senate today.

Moves in commodity futures prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, copper and both sugar contracts were active, but most other markets were dull. Cocoa, coffee, potatoes, cottonseed oil and soybean oil rose; copper, hides, rubber and zinc eased, and price movements in sugar, onions and wool were mixed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The presentation of a Congressional gold medal to Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of polio vaccine, will coincide next Thursday with the transmission to Capitol Hill of President Eisenhower's message on health needs.

Production and consumption of newsprint during December were at record levels, while the inventory average of American publishers made a relative improvement despite a tightened supply, monthly reports of trade groups showed yesterday.

"Ambrose Bierce and the Black Hills," a reconstruction of a little known incident in the writer's life, will be published by the University of Oklahoma Press on Feb. 27. In 1879 the author, journalist, critic and soldier, "apparently disappeared"...

DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (AP)--Oleg Goncharenko of Russia raced to a record victory in the 5,000-meter event today to continue the Russian domination of the Swiss international speedskating championships. America's skaters were out of the running.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--An expert mining witness testified today that ore assays on which the Department of the Interior awarded the Al Sarena mining claims were some of the poorest he had ever seen.
For three hours yesterday Long Island Rail Road officials defended their policies against the attacks of Public Service Commission lawyers and two commuters.
A big let-up in turnover of the new Ford stock shares occurred in over-the-counter trading yesterday. The market price declined too.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UP)-- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's first full-dress news conference since Aug. 4. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout.
The Board of Education adopted without change yesterday the proposed operating budget for 1956-57. It calls for an expenditure of $349,824,701.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19--The Security Council unanimously voted condemnation today of Israel's raid on Syrian military posts near the Sea of Galilee.

The traveler going into Colombia from the Pacific side has to do some climbing, by rail or highway, before he comes to Cali, in the watershed of the Cauca River. If he goes fifty miles further inland, up the Pacific slope of the Cordillera Occidental,...

EVANSTON, Ill., Jan. 19-- Danger to the human race from radioactive fallout resulting from nuclear weapons tests "at present rates" is insignificant on the basis of world-wide evidence, Dr. Willard F. Libby declared here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Federal Trade Commission filed today one of its biggest antimerger complaints to date. It charged that thirty-nine acquisitions by Foremost Dairies, Inc., since 1950 might injure competition.

The Transit Authority reaped an $18,000 harvest from Wednesday's taxicab stoppage called by a local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. However, another local of the same union had the authority worried yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 19--Louis Oppenheimer, co-builder of a South African diamond mining empire, died today at his home, Lantern Cottage, in Gerrard's Cross, Buckinghamshire. He was 85 years old.

Loans to business outstanding on the books of New York City banks increased by a modest $3,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The Poetry Society of America, awarded laurels and $3.150 in cash to poets and critics at its forty-sixth annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
ALMOST any capable wildfowler can, by the judicious placing of decoys, lure waterfowl within range of his gun, but to lure a goose right into the blind calls for a special technique.
Mayor Wagner's new traffic advisory council was described yesterday by experts as a step in the wrong direction.
TRENTON, Jan. 19--Four persons charged with collecting $24,000 in the last two years by selling fraudulent driver licenses have been arrested, it was announced today.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 19--A question by Premier Einar Gerhardsen during his recent visit to Moscow about acceptable conditions for German reunification brought open laughter from Soviet officials.

The General Motors Corporation agreed yesterday to sponsor a nation-wide color telecast of Shakespeare's "Richard III," the new three-hour British motion picture produced by Sir Laurence Olivier, who also stars in the film.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--New allotments of steel, copper and aluminum for defense and atomic energy requirements were announced today by the Office of Defense Mobilization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The bill to remove production of natural gas from direct Federal regulation was subjected to heavy attack in the Senate today.

There is continuing rioting in Bombay over the decision of the Central Government to make a firm declaration on the status of the disputed city and state. Yet the Central Government seems to have acted wisely and to have taken the only course that meets the peculiar local circumstances.

Orlando William Wells, an early leader in the oil industry and a prominent map-maker, died yesterday in French Hospital after a brief Illness. Mr. Wells, who lived at Larchmont, N.Y., and had a summer home at Southold, L.I., was 77 years old.
Patrick B. McGinnis, who will resign today as president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, may soon have a new job.

Many of the National Motor Boat Show regulars got serious and technical yesterday and left the Kingsbridge Armory exposition for periods of varying lengths to study safety and other engineering matters.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that 5,000 policemen must be added to the force over the next two budget years. The increase is needed, he Said, to "maintain" standards of human decency."

This newspaper had the pleasure of publishing on its front page yesterday a photograph of a painting of the Eisenhowers' Gettysburg farm painted by Grandma Moses of Eagle Bridge, N.Y., and presented...
WESTPORT, Conn., Jan. 19-- A new electronic system enabling the police at remote locations to observe both the speed and density of automobile traffic will be tried on the Merritt Parkway here.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 --Columbia has parted with $200,000 to acquire motion-picture rights to "The Last Hurrah," a February Book-of-theMonth Club selection published by Little, Brown Co.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 19--The United States and Yugoslavia signed agreements. today envisioning new deliveries here of $73,000,000 worth of agricultural products.

THE Tonga Islands, all 150 of them, reise from the South Pacific about 400 miles east of Fiji and 300 miles south of Samoa. Many people heard of them for the first time when their large and majestic queen, Salote Tupou, attended the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II, Little known compared with Tahiti and less conspicuously blessed...

A two-story taxpayer at the at the southeast corner of Jamaica Avenue and Springfield Boulevard in Queens Village, Queens, has been sold by the Jamezel Realty Corporation, of which Harry Suskind is president, to a client of Matthew W. Tosti, attorney. Samuel Goldberg was attorney for the seller. L.J. Phillips Co. and Samuel Ertractor were the brokers in the deal.

Most ski areas were still on the comeback trail yesterday as a result of last week's thaw. In many cases, particularly in the Berkshires and southern Vermont, at least four or five inches of powder were still needed to insure satisfactory conditions.

Advances in automotive safety's devices shared interest with "dream cars" at the opening session of General Motors' $2,000,000 Motorama yesterday, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The attendance totaled 40,000, an opening-day record.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy and Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh served notice yesterday that they would continue to be "tough" about enforcement of traffic regulations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19--Grains displayed a firm undertone in most of today's session, but there was still little disposition to follow rallies. Uncertainty over the final shape of farm legislation now pending tended to prevent either buying or selling in an aggressive way.
Hank Bauer, one of the Yan kees' most reliable outfielders, yesterday became their third contract signer. The previous play. ers to sign were Shortstop Phil Rizzuto and Pitcher Tommy Byrne.

A novel Girl Scout honor, the first in this city, was won last night by Troop 4 of Manhattan. A purple ribbon was awarded the troop for being the first under the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York to reach its fortieth birthday.
LONDON, Jan. 19--John Cavanagh, Norman Hartnell, Worth of London and Michael Sherard opened today the spring showings of the "Bid Twelve" fashion designers here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--For the first time in our history, so far as the available reference books disclose, the President of the United States has proposed that official steps be taken (Congress participating) to clarify the "inability"...

EARLIER this season the New york PhilharmonicSymphony engaged Pierre Monteux for two weeks as a way of paying tribute to his eightieth birthday. Last night the conductor, who is now nearing 81, repaid the compliment by helping the orchestra out of a somewhat difficult spot.
GENEVA, Jan. 19--The United States received today a lot of advice and some compliments on its international trade policy in a public session of the world tariff conference here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The consensus of diplomatic opinions here today was that Peiping's latest denunciation of the United States position at Geneva did not necessarily mean the Communists wanted to break off the Ambassadorial talks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Federal Court of Appeals affirmed today the conviction of Ernest K. Bramblett, former Representative in Congress from California, in a case involving an alleged payroll "kickback" scheme.

CADIZ, Ohio, Jan. 19 (AP)-- A near-mishap interrupted the unveiling today of the world's largest power shovel. Scores of spectators were standing about watching the monstrous power shovel begin its journey to stripping operations at...

MIAMI, Jan. 19 (AP)--Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's home-bred, Sometime Thing, under top weight of 121 pounds, launched her winter campaign with a triumph in the $7,500 Blue Skies Purse at Hialeah Park today. The race was a prep for the $30,000 added Black Helen Handicap on March 2.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--It was a different President Eisenhower who came back to the Washington news at arena today, and the difference was a surprise.

Mrs. Eugene Meyer called yesterday for an end to hypocrisy about birth control. She said it had been conservatively estimated that at least 750,000 criminal abortions were performed annually in this country Most of them, she said, are obtained by married women with three or more children.

LONDON, Jan. 19--Field Marshal Sir John Harding, Governor of Cyprus, cautioned on his arrival here today that "differences of substance and not just of words" were blocking a settlement of the crisis in the colony.
ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 19--In the Nevada atomic explosion test last May 5, heat-sterilized foods kept in tins and glass containers were intact at distances of 3,750 feet or more from the blast.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19--The Soviet Union and Liberia have agreed to establish diplomatic relations and exchange Ambassadors.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Jan. 20 (UP)--Thirty-five civilians were, killed on the Nationalist Chinese island of Quemoy yesterday in a fierce seven-hour artillery duel with Communist guns, it was reported today.
ALBANY, Jan. 19--The Harriman Administration introduced a bill today to apply the state's anti-discrimination laws to housing built with Federal loans or mortgage guarantees.
Directors of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank yesterday elected Harold H. Helm, its pres ident, as chairman and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--A temporary reversal of the policy of curbing imports of residual (fuel) oil was indicated today by officials of the Office of Defense Mobilization.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Jan. 19--An airliner left for the United States tonight loaded with Dutch emigrants.

Ending the agreement against public airing of differences at the SinoAmerican talks in Geneva, the Chinese Communists have issued a lengthy statement in which they reassert their right to Taiwan (Formosa) and refuse to renounce force in the pursuit of that goal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- Congressional demands for an investigation of meat packers and the Administration's pork purchase program rose today after Government figures showed packers' charges for processing pork had doubled in recent months.
The Producers Theatre, inter national in scope, is formulating plans to import an outstanding Italian repertory company, headed by Eduardo de Filippo.
American industrialists who suggest "business as usual" with Russia are "living in a fool's paradise," George Meany declared yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19-- Governor Harriman accused the Eisenhower Administration today of glossing over the truth about national security and encouraging complacency.

A property that once was part of the old Stuyvesant estate holdings on the East Side has passed to new control with the sale by the Fourteenth Street Estate Realty Corporation of five buildings containing stores and. apartments at 88 to 96 Third Avenue, north-west corner of...

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 (AP)--Stockholders of F.H. McGraw Co., a heavy construction concern were notified today of a proposal to sell 40 per cent of the company's common stock to the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.

Isn't something radically wrong with basketball when forty-eight personal fouls are called and eighty-nine free throws are awarded in a forty-minute game? That's what happened in the Columbia-Yale contest at New Haven on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--A Senate-House Atomic Energy Subcommittee called on the Navy today to justify plans to rush construction of a nuclearpowered cruiser.
Taxicabs were plentiful yesterday after the one-day work stoppage on Wednesday. But the drivers' union spoke threateningly of a full-scale strike.
Short-term securities are in strong demand for temporary investment, money market reports indicated yesterday. And that circumstance is having the effect of temporarily forcing money rates downward.
Two waves of selling, one in the noon hour and a lighter one in the final thirty minutes, sent stock prices yesterday to the lowest levels since Nov. 3. Metals and chemicals were notably weak.
FOR a synopsis of today's trends in interior decoration and furniture design, a visit to Macy's newly opened model rooms is recommended.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--Government, management and labor are not measuring up to their re spotssibilities in the maritime industry, a committee of Congress said today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 19--The Foreign Ministry announced tonight that a meeting of the Political Consultative Committee of the eight Warsaw pact countries would be held here Jan. 27.

The New York City Young Men's Christian Association is nearly 92 per cent self-supporting, with a total annual budget of $7,204,000. The association currently his engaged in its annual appeal for the rest of the money it needs to continue its vital program for boys and...
LONDON, Jan. 19--The British Government acknowledged today that in the past year fifty to 100 "old" Sherman tanks had slipped through its export controls to Israel by way of France.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 19 (AP)--Tenley Albright, America's world figure skating champion, gashed her right leg in a skating accident today, but inisisted she would bid for an Olympic gold medal.

MOSCOW, Jan. 19--Mass recruitment of settlers for the new lands of the Soviet East has ended. Individual pioneers are still heeding the Government's call to go east, but the pressure for major population shifts is off, at least temporarily.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 19--The New York State School Boards Association urged Governor Harriman and the Legislature today to go beyond the recommendations of the Heald Commission in providing state aid to education.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 19--Following is the text of a resolution unanimously adopted today by the United Nations Security Council:

Albert M. Handy, a lawyer and an authority on income and inheritance taxes, died on Wednesday night at the New York Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Handy lived at 1235 Park Avenue and maintained offices at 277 Broadway.

The British press, even the proGovernment newspapers, was not entirely satisfied with Prime Minister Eden's speech at Bradford Wednesday in which he mainly discussed internal difficulties. It appears that Sir Anthony was not tough enough, not prepared, to tackle the inflation, imbalance of trade and overemployment with stern enough measures.

Mrs. D. Russell John of Palm Beach, Fla., and Howard S. Kniffin Jr. of Hewlett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Brent Kniffin, to Robert Dinsmore Huntington Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Huntington of Palm Beach and Upper St. Regis, N.Y.

LONDON, Jan. 19--Volume continued to fall on the stock market today in the absence of any announcement in the Prime Minister's speech on whether the Government planned new measures to loosen the grip of inflation. The only exception to smaller trading was the South African gold-mining group, which revived sharply.
Cold Maine lobster and a chance to salute President Eisenlower were selling well, if not like hot cakes, Republicans reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 19--A series of three Republican program bills to "humanize" the state personal income tax was submitted to the Legislature today.
A legislative plan to consolidate state forest preserves and double camping and picnic sites received approval from local conservationists yesterday.

The Cities Service Company is planning the largest capital outlay in its history for expanding its search for new oil and gas reserves in the United States and in foreign areas. The company has appointed four new vice presidents and two other executives.
TWENTY-FOUR families, each with fifteen children, have been turned up in this city by a local candymaker to help him celebrate his establishment's fifteenth anniversary next Tuesday.

The Police Department and the State Liquor Authority yesterday ordered investigations into charges that a man with a criminal record had received a liquor store license on the recommendation of four high police officials.
Five Christian denominations were represented in a single religious service at Union Theological Seminary last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)-- Senator Theodore Francis Green recommended today that goals for technical aid to underdeveloped nations be set "for ten or even twenty years ahead."
The replacing of Mr. Gedvilas seems to fit in with recent indications of Moscow's dissatisfaction with the economic and political situation in Lithuania.

Julius Helfand, the New York State Athletic Commission chairman, followed up his recent knockout of the Boxing Guild of New York with a few powerful punches at the National Boxing Association last night.
WINTER PARK, Fla., Jan. 19 --Clifford Sawyer Bragdon, former Superintendent of Schools in New Rochelle, N.Y., died yesterday in an Orlando hospital at the age of 85.

Northern States Power Company (Minnesota) and subsidiaries achieved gains of 7.3 per cent in operating revenues in 1955, according to a preliminary report yesterday. Allen S. King, president, also reported a 5.7 per cent gain in electric revenues, which accounted for 86 per cent of total revenues. Gas revenues increased by 20.5 per cent over their 1954 level.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19--At a diplomatic reception in Yugoslavia in November, 1954, a Soviet official walked up to an American correspondent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--The top Republican on the House Education and Labor Committee today predicted that the aid to school construction bill would be on the House floor and disposed of within ten days to two weeks.
LONDON, Jan. 19--Reaction to the speech Prime Minister Eden made in Bradford last night has been mixed but on the whole mildly favorable.
BOSTON, Jan. 20--Patrick B. McGinnis was elected tonight as president of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

Henry Miller, author of "Tropic of Cancer" and "Tropic of Capricorn," is the subject of a book by his friend Alfred Perles. Titled "My Friend, Henry Miller," it will be published in April by John Day. The book will deal mainly...
GORTINA d'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 20 (AP)--American performances improved but still fell short of championship standards today as training for the seventh Olympic Winter Games continued.

After three years in the spotlight as the mid-winter yachting center of the East, the Bronx learned yesterday it would lose its National Motor Boat Show after tomorrow. This fantastic June-in-January display of vacation delights will move back to...
The Columbia Broadcasting System's "Radio Workshop" will send some unheard-of sounds into receivers with its adaptation of Aldous Huxley's novel "Brave New World."

ANDERNACH, Germany, Jan. 20--The first six volunteer training companies of West Germany's new armed forces were inspected here today in subzero weather by the 80-yearold Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20--After a decade of forcing the peasants off the land into new industrial enterprises Marshal Tito's Government is reversing itself.
Thank you, thank you very much, indeed, Mr. Vice President, Chairman Hall, my very dear friends here and throughout the United States.
TRENTON, Jan. 20--Gov. Robert. B. Meyner and other state officials appealed today for Federal participation in the erection of a $60,000,000 dam on the upper Delaware River.

Our society is growing older, and this presents the problem of how better to care for those who are advanced in years but still vigorous. An interesting and valuable experiment has been started here in New York as an outgrowth of the annual Hobby Show for Older Persons that was presented by the Welfare and Health Council.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Jan. 20--For want of a piston, a vacation was lost--or a part of it, anyway. A party of six Canadians, who had expected to be gazing upon the warm sands of Miami Beach, has been staring instead at cold fields of snow.

New-issue activity in the capttal market will continue in second gear next week because underwriters will be preoccupied with the need for getting up more than $1,000,000,000 to meet commitments related to the Ford Motor Company stock offering...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20-- Pittsburgh's Arnie Sowell stepped out on his own for the first time this year and accounted for the most striking performance of the twelfth annual Philadelphia Inquirer track meet.
PARIS, Jan. 20--The widow of Louis Renault, French motor car manufacturer, charged today that he died in 1944 from torture and beatings in prison.
Four months of planning went into the Salute to Eisenhower last night at Madison Square Garden. But, as with many ambitious projects, what came off was not like clockwork.

Read in connection with a report presented at a meeting of the American Public Health Association on Nov. 15, 1955, by staff members of the Public Health Service, a paper which appears in the current issue of the New England Journal of Medicine by Dr. Alton S. Pope and his...

HARTFORD, Jan. 20--Sherman Adams, the assistant to the President, advised the Republican party tonight that it must recruit more members if the "Eisenhower kind of Republicanism" was to be perpetuated.
PARIS, Jan. 20 (UP)--France denied today that she had assured Britain that obsolete war surplus tanks sold to a French scrap concern would not be reexported.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (UP) --The houses ran as a good-sized crowd gathered today at the Fair Grounds despite picketing by some sixty parimutuel workers demanding that the track recognize their union.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 20 (UP)--Gil Turner of Philadelphia won another majority ten-round decision over Jackie LaBua of East Meadow, L.I., tonight in their nationally televised fight at War Memorial Auditorium.
Lenders and borrowers in coming weeks will focus their attend tion on New York City, headquarters of the nation's money market, to watch for any change in Federal Reserve policy.

The investigation into wiretap practices of private detectives has pointed up the necessity for "completely rewriting" the laws under which the detectives are licensed, Sidney Squire declared yesterday. He is executive deputy secretary of state.

A nation-wide survey has indicated that supplies of steel scrap are ample in virtually all steel-making districts despite the record pace of steel production. This was reported yes terday by the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., which said it had polled the presidents of its chapters to obtain information about the scrap situation.

The Port of New York Authority and the New Jersey Turnpike Authority said yesterday they had reached a tentative agreement on two road-constrution projects in New Jersey. The cost of construction was estimated at $18,000,000.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 20 (UP)--Yuri Mikhailov of Russia set a world 1,500-meter record of 2 minutes 9.1 seconds today to give the Soviet Olympic team its third straight victory in the Swiss international meet.

WASHTNGTON, Jan. 20--Senator Paul H. Douglas took the Senate floor today for what he said would be a four-day speech against the pending bill to exempt natural gas producers from direct Federal regulation.
The seventeenth annual White Elephant party, held in the ballroom of the Ambassador last night, drew a capacity number of guests.

ABOARD U.S.S. WYANDOT, in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica, Jan. 20--Antarctica is to have a full-fledged dentist. Lieut. David Knoedler, D.D.S., of Mosinee, Wis., is one of eightynine Navy volunteers who will spend the winter at the United States outpost now being constructed a few miles from here at Hut Point on Ross Island.
LONDON, Jan. 20--Two of London's younger designers, Ronald Paterson and Michael, were outstanding at the second day of the "Big Twelve" spring fashion openings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) --National Airlines went directly to the White House today with its fight against a merger of Eastern Air Lines and Colonial Airlines.
Winter sent another glancing blow at the city yesterday, but it had its snow punch cocked for another try late tomorrow.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad got a new president yesterday. So did the Boston and Maine Railroad.
ALBANY, Jan. 20--A Republican program bill to provide hospitalization insurance for present and retired state employes will be introduced in the Legislature Monday.

The proposed acquisition by the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company of the National Fire Insurance Company of Hartford has been blocked by a ruling from New York State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--An officer of one of the country's largest grain marketing cooperatives said today that he had charged Harold E. Stassen with lying and had invited him to sue for libel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--An electronic counterfeit detector, designed to throw out bad bills automatically, was patented this week by Carl G. Sontheimer of Riverside, Conn. He assigned it to C.G.S. Laboratories, Inc., Stamford.
MOSCOW, Jan. 20--Pravda charged today that the Roosevelt Administration had proposed the dismemberment of Germany, against Soviet opposition.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP)--New York, sparked by Gene Shue in the first half and Kenny Sears in the second, gained a 122-109 National Basketball Association victory tonight over Minneapolis at the Boston Garden.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would reappoint Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy, whose present tenure expires Feb. 21.
The woes of the presidency of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad traveled the length of the line yesterday from lower Broadway here to State Street in Boston.

Twenty-seven years ago Alvin Weil worked in a factory turning out cheap celluloid toilet articles so that he could pay his way through Brooklyn Law School. He toiled at the celluloid bench during the day and attended law classes at night. It was a struggle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)-- The Civil Service Commission, under prodding by a House committee, has told its employes that they have a responsibility "to assist in the task of keeping the public informed."
New YorK and New Jersey Republicans took over Madison Square Garden last night to salute President Eisenhower and give the party treasury a million dollars--or nearly that much.
New York can expect only piecemeal answers and continued confusion, conferees on the city's traffic problem were told yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 20--In gingerly fashion the present Soviet Government is trying to instill some spirit of initiative into a population little accustomed to the habit of selfreliance. The trend, faltering and uncertain, is toward decentralization. It is hoped there will be more individual enterprise and less passivity.
A former headwaiter at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was indicted yesterday for income tax evasion. He was charged with failure to report $67,070 in tips received over a fouryear period.

William Black, president of the Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation, has sold his contract to the three-story industrial building at 414-24 West Thirteenth Street to Pegi Paris, Inc., manufacturer of handbags. The Charles F. Noyes Company was the broker. Kelly Schwartz were attorneys for the buyer and Jesse L. Goldberg acted for Mr. Black.
Two gunmen not in the cast put on an unscheduled act at the Mark Hellinger Theatre last night, but the show went on as usual.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20-- Mrs. Mollie Woods Hare, founder and honorary president of the Woods Schools in near-by Langhorne, died yesterday at her residence there. She was the widow of John Ridgeway Hare.

LONDON, Jan. 20--The British Foreign Office rebuked Ambassador Eliahu Elath of Israel today for a statement on his interview with Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd. The statement said that at the interview yesterday the Ambassador summarized Israel's attitude on the Palestine problem, emphasizing her demand for arms and her intention to reject any outside pressure for a settlement.
The Texas Company plans to split its stock on a two-for-one basis, subject to stockholder approval of an increase in the capital stock at the annual meeting on April 24.

Stocks went down yesterday for the fourth time this week. This time, however, the decline followed an early rally and the net loss was moderate. Factors for weakness in the market included the afternoon announcement that Chrysler was laying off 10,350 workers.
TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 20 (AP) --Mike Souchak, with another round of sub-par golf, stretched his lead to three strokes today as play reached the midway mark of the $12,500 Caliente oven tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- Rowland R. Hughes, Director of the Bureau of the Budget, resigned today. His resignation will become effective April 1.
Tomorrow has been designated "Theological Education Sunday" by Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
TOKYO, Jan. 20--Japan expects to balance her projected $2,875,000,000 budget during the fiscal year starting April 1.
BERLIN, Jan. 20--Willi Stoph, youngest member of the Communist party's Politburo, has been named East Germany's Defense Minister.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 20 --Charles W. Dingle, veteran character actor of stage, screen, television and radio, died yesterday in Worcester Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Dingle, who was 68 years old, had been an actor for fifty-four years.

The Republican party took a new step in United States politics last night with its "Salute to Eisenhower" closed-circuit telecast. The program reached fifty-three large gatherings of its faithful in fifty-two cities.

LONDON, Jan. 20--Herbert Morrison, former Deputy Leader of the Labor party, charged tonight that Sir Anthony Eden "doesn't know where he is" and the Conservative government "doesn't know where it is going."
Dr. Royal Storrs Haynes, retired specialist in pediatrics, died Thursday in his home, 440 East Twenty-third Street, after a long illness. He was 78 years old.
The Dodgers yesterday signed two infielders to bring their total of players under contract to sixteen.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20-- Governor Harriman cast President Eisenhower today in the role of master buck-passer.

LONDON, Jan. 20--The porters of Smithfield Market gave a raucous reception today to five dignified London housewives who marched on the wholesale meat center to protest against restrictive labor practices.
BOMBAY, India, Jan. 20--Political experts think the rioting in Bombay threatens to break the control of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party over its traditional stronghold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--The new Soviet Five-Year Plan promises to strengthen Moscow's hand for an all-out economic contest with the West.
Sales and earnings of the General Foods Corporation for the nine months ended Dec. 31 were the highest for any similar period in the company's history.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 20 --Noisy rebellion against Gov. James E. Folsom broke out today in the Legislature and tonight it was not clear whether the special session called by the Governor was still in session.

For the time being, at least, the political crisis in Indonesia seems to have been calmed down. The Harahap Government will apparently stay in office on a caretaker basis. The delegation in Geneva had been instructed to wind up the talks with the Dutch without agreement, but those instructions have apparently been reversed and the talks are to continue.

LEGS of lamb, plentiful meat this week-end, can be as practical for the small family as for the large. Most of the lamb now coming to market is heavy, with legs weighing from eight to ten pounds. But many stores cut these into half-legs of about five pounds each.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)-- Senator A.S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today he would "strike at the core" of automobile bootlegging with a bill to require that the ownership record of all new cars be shown on their windshields.
COLOGNE, Germany, Jan. 20 --In the last six months the Soviet bloc has consistently outbid Western companies in competition in South Asia and the Middle East.

"BORIS GODUNOV" returned to the Metropoli tan Opera repertory last night in a performance filled with the power and brooding compassion that Mussorgsky poured into it. Once again the chief architect of a first-rate revival was Dimitri Mitropoulos.

The annual reports of the Citizens Budget Commission are always useful documents, informative on city governmental affairs, reasonably critical of official performance, confident and determined in approach to improvement of municipal management.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 20 (AP)-- The Maryland Athletic Commission disclosed today it had voided the license of the Arena Sports Club, headed by Benny Trotta, to promote boxing in Maryland.

LONDON, Jan. 20--The British Government is planning to set a time limit on its negotiations over the future of Cyprus. No specific date has been fixed. However, when Field Marshal Sir John Harding, Governor of the island colony, returns to Cyprus next week, he is due to take back special instructions on the question.

NEW semi-abstract sculpture by Rhys Caparn, at the Meltzer Gallery, 38 West Fifty-seventh Street, bears out her statement that her forms are derived from "man, animals, birds; the lines of trees, the bulk of rocks, the shadows of ravines and the slope of hills under snow." HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 --Rosemary Clooney has signed as the star of projected series of thirty-nine half-hour musical television films. They will be made by the production unit of the Music Corporation of America.

LONDON, Jan. 20--South African gold mining stocks again were the only shares that, were really firm today. British Government issues closed dull and industrials were able to recover only part of their losses.
Evander Childs successfully defended its Public Schools Athletic League indoor swimming title for the fourth consecutive year last night in New York University's Quigley Memorial pool.

The three-story apartment house accommodating twelve Families at 1037 Forty-sixth street in Brooklyn has been sold by Sarah Oliver to Helen Korn. The property occupies a plot 40 by 100 feet and is assessed at $33,000. Henry Futterweit was the broker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UP) --A Government authority said today that all available evidence "clearly" pointed to the contaminated air of America's industrial cities as the chief cause of lung cancer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP)-- The Census Bureau reported today that California was outstripping all other states by a wide margin in population growth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20--Senator Paul H. Douglas demanded today that the Federal Reserve Board make public the vote by which its open market committee decided last month to buy Treasury certificates, in a reversal of previous practice.

Prices of cotton futures declined 7 to 23 points (35 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday. The market opened active and easier. It sold off to losses of 21 to 30 points ($1.05 to $1.50 a bale) on active months, but later recovered some of the losses.
New York's five-day fuel strike ended yesterday, and coal and oil trucks made overtime rounds last right to replenish nearly depleted supplies.
Thomas M. Goodfellow, president of the Long Island Rail Road, said yesterday that he had traveled in the line's much-criticized three-passenger seats and found them "very comfortable."
Futures prices on the New York Exchanges generally rose yesterday. Cottonseed oil was active but most other trading was light and generally limited to evening of holdings for the week-end.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20--In a fighting speech received by an enthusiastic Republican audience here tonight, Vice President Richard M. Nixon ridiculed the Democrats and defended the first three years of the Eisenhower Administration.
ALTHOUGH 1956 is only a few weeks old, anglers at Cabo Blanco, Peru, have been ringing up fishing records with unusual regularity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- President Eisenhower moved today to calm the foreign policy scene as the Senate again rang with debate over the policies and conduct of John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State.

The Rev. William Howard Melish will be able to conduct services tomorrow at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

Eleven men were honored yesterday for upholding "the finest tradition of the sea" in the rescue of two injured seamen last Nov. 17. The rescue took place off the Grand Banks of Newfoundland.

Platinum, never exactly plentiful, is likely to continue to be unusually scarce for at least two years more. Heavy industrial use of the precious metal, especially by oil refineries, has created a world-wide shortage.

A price-conscious crowd flocked to the General Motors Motorama at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. With many thrifty motorists consideration of the wallet outweighed the charm of the cars. Bargain hunters drifted about, matching wits with alert salesmen.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation suffered a net loss of $1,037,000 in the final quarter of last year as a result of a bitter strike that has impaired production since Oct. 17. PARIS, Jan. 20--An attempt to unseat four of the fifty-one Poujadist Deputies elected to the National Assembly was under way today.

Market bids for Ford stock fell yesterday to a little more than a point above the issue price of 61 . The selloff was linked to two factors: the general heaviness of the stock market and the continued unloading of stock by-speculators out to capture a quick profit.
BOSTON, Jan. 20--A Navy transport vessel was seriously damaged today when she was dashed against a leg of the Texas Tower station on Georges Bank, 110 miles off Cape Cod.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 20--Gov. Luis Munoz Marin signed today three bills making changes in territorial taxes. One bill increased the excise taxes on automobiles having an import cost of $1,800 or more.

ALBANY, Jan. 20--Maj. Gen. Karl F. Hausauer, Commander of the New York National Guard, denied today that there was wasteful spending in the State Division of Military and Naval Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20-- The United States Consumer Price Index fell 0.3 per cent between mid-November and mid-December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor reported today.
