HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 --Cecil B. De Mille sounded a forthright message of warning and encouragement last night for the motion picture as an art form and as a business.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican, has agreed to testify Thursday as a Government witness in the perjury trial of Paul H. Hughes, Washington private investigator.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--A bill to require suspension of a driver's license for at least seven days on conviction for speeding or reckless driving was introduced today.
LONDON, Jan. 23--Sir Alexander Korda, one of the great figures in Britain's motion picture industry, died of a heart attack today at his London home in Kensington Palace Gardens. He was 62 years old.
The common stock of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, a spectacular performer recently on the New York Stock Exchange, dropped 20 points yesterday.

A "limited night traffic court" will be instituted next week in four of the city's five boroughs, Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday. At about the time Mr. Murtagh was announcing this, the Police Department reported that during a sixtyfour hour period from Friday till 8 A.M. yesterday 10,461 summonses were issued.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UP) --Senator Paul H. Douglas said today that passage of the natural gas bill would mean that "the interests of wealth and power" were running the Government.
TORONTO, Jan. 23--Representatives of Toronto and its metropolitan area painted a picture today of vast expansion for the city. They envision a doubling of the population to 2,800,000 by 1980.

The president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology urged the Government last night to have a master plan drafted for maintaining the nation's technological lead in the face of swift Russian gains.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (UP)--An advertising executive today ad vised newspaper publishers "to hit the road to sell space" to meet steadily rising production costs.
Bankers were urged yesterday to undertake a nation-wide study of banking and thrift institutions to help solve conflicts within the industry that arise from overlapping operations.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--The Democratic leader of the State Senate said today that an income tax cut this year would necessitate an increase in the gasoline tax.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies warned today the Government might have to step into the nation-wide waterfront strike. The strike began at midnight last night.
The Seventh Regiment of New York--one of the nation's oldest and most famous military units --has announced the schedule for its 150th anniversary celebration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- President Eisenhower sought today to restore bipartisanship in foreign policy. He had an hourlong discussion with the principal Democratic foreign affairs spokesman, Senator Walter F. George of Georgia.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Secretary of State Dulles was reported today to have sent a message to the British Government urging it to strive to avoid a breakdown in the negotiations with Cypriote leaders over the island's future.
The local baseball signing parade continued yesterday as the world champion Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Yankees each brought three players into the fold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The man responsible for the Economic Report of the President finally knocked off work about 6 A.M. today, took a last pull on the furnace he calls a pipe and went home to bed.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 22--Proposals for piecemeal integration of the Scandinavian economies to provide an enlarged "home market" supporting mass production industries will be considered by the Nordic Council.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 23--Tenley Albright, who had returned to the ice briefly yesterday following her injury last week, skated through-morn ing and afternoon workouts today under the watchful eyes of both her coach and physician.
Another shadow that could grow to ominous proportions is rising above the troubled Near East as a result of new party groupings in Greece in preparation for the national election on Feb. 19.

A 23-year-old patrolman was raised to the rank of third-grade detective yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy. He was cited for his "courageous arrest" of three persons, including another patrolman, charged with committing a robbery Sunday morning.

THE sailfish appear to be offering complete coopera tion with contestants in the annual Silver Sailfish Derby at the Palm Beaches, in Florida. A total of 343 fish was recorded during the first eight days of the contest.

Television station WABD will try the debonair approach with a program titled "Tune in Anytime Theatre." The show, which begins Feb. 6, will present a feature-length motion picture three times in succession.
President Eisenhower hailed yesterday the twenty-year partnership of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in combating pollution in interstate waters.

After more than four years of study, the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it would build a $120,000,000 aluminum plant on the Ohio River near Clarington, Ohio. Production is to begin by mid-1958.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 23 --Gov. Frank G. Clement rejected an appeal from a delegation of pro-segregationists today to "lead the fight for states' rights."
Miss Marguerite Patricia Henry Cullman was married yesterday afternoon to Allan Barry Stone in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Charles J. McManus.
Salary increases, totaling $150,000 for 1956-57, were approved last night by the Board of Higher Education for 700 clerical and staff employes of the four municipal colleges.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points (60 cents a bale) off to 8 points (40 cents a bale) up yesterday.
Hugh M. Clark of La Jolla Calif., one of the world's foremost philatelists, died of cancer Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 23 (UP)--America lost a skier, Russia lost a world speed skating record and California was in danger of losing the 1960 Games today amid an outbreak of squabbles that threatened to overshadow preparations for the 1956 Winter Olympics, which open Thursday and run through Feb. 5.

A record number of 570 "finalists" have been chosen from the thousands of entries received in the 1955 Brand Name retailerof-the-year competition. Each finalist has been invited to submit a detailed and illustrated presentation of his 1955 advertising and other sales promotional activities to compete in the selection of top winners.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--Authority to transfer Grant's Tomb to the Federal Government for a national monument is being sought from the Legislature.

If the fight for the preservation of civil liberties in the United States could be charted on a graph the line would show a sharp rise during 1955 from the depression of the several years preceding. This unmistakable fact gives ample justification for the note of restrained...

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--Planning now to meet the housing needs of fast growing population of this country was urged here today by John M. Dickerson, executive director of the National Association of Home Builders.
CAIRO, Jan. 23--Dag Hammarskjold said today he felt "continued optimism" that a solution could be found for the Arab-Israeli conflict.
Deliveries of fuel oil and coal after last week's five-day strike of teamsters were being "pretty well taken care of" yesterday, an industrial spokesman said.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23-- The Philadelphia Orchestra Association and Local 77, American Federation of Musicians, are involved in a dispute over the forced retirement of three musicians.

MANILA, Jan. 23--The Philippine Congress began its annual hundred-day session today. It was almost entirely devoid of organized party opposition to President Ramon Magsaysay's program of social reform and national growth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Administration is wracked by a struggle over farm policy.

MANCHESTER, Conn., Jan. 23--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Hayes of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Mary Hayes, to Thomas Emmett Toomey. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Toomey, formerly of White Plains.

Offerings of corporate securities priced at more than $18,800,000 will be made to investors today. Among the issues are straight and convertible debentures and common stock of industrial enterprises and capital stock of a Western bank. The offerings are as follows:

Net profit of the F.W. Woolworth Company and its foreign subsidiaries for last year amounted to $34,155,898, according to the preliminary figures released today. Last year's earnings were 26.7 per cent larger than the $26,948,193 earned in 1954.
New Yorkers shopping for a car place function before art, according to General Motors researchers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23-- President Eisenhower was informed today that the "salute to Eisenhower" rallies Friday had netted about $5,000,000 for the 1956 Republican campaign.
Ninety-five per cent of the merchants in this country are opposed to keeping their stores open on Sundays, the general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States said yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 23--Leaders of the left-of-center Republican Front were reported today to have differences on the composition of the Cabinet they may be asked to form soon. The Republican Front is composed of Socialists and Radicals.
Announcement yesterday of the Olin Mathieson aluminum project in the Ohio River Valley brought to light plans for the eventual construction of the world's largest steam generating station.

After thirty years of publicizing the maritime industry as a ship news reporter and public relations director, James F. Roche will leave the MooreMcCormack Lines Feb. 1 to join the Stanley Works, hardware manufacturers of New Britain, Conn.
Calendar congestion in the Manhattan and Bronx Supreme Courts has been eased by a new system of using court-appointed experts to provide medical testimony in personal injury cases.

THE other day when I was reading "The Windward Road: Adventures of a Nat uralist on Remote Caribbean Shores"* I was struck by the thought that I have never yet read a book by a naturalist who didn't seem deliriously in love with his work. What is more, in this age of anxiety and of neurotic writers afflicted with ulcers, alcohol and divorces, naturalists seem chronically happy.
WINNIPEG, Man., Jan. 23 (AP) --Canada's two professional football leagues are going all out in an effort to make peace with the National Football League.

Ford stock sold momentarily in the public market yesterday at $64.50 a share, the same price as that designated by underwriters in the big offering last Tuesday. Influenced by the weakness of the stock market as a whole, Ford declined by about 1 point during the morning trading yesterday.

With Arthur Kennedy and Richard Kiley starred, "Time Limit!" will begin its career at 8 o'clock tonight at the Booth. Produced by the Theatre Guild, the drama represents the combined output of two newcomers to Broadway, Henry Denker and Ralph Berkey. Both are experienced TV and radio writers.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., Jan. 23 --Dr. Adolph Eichhorn, an authority on animal husbandry, died today at his winter home in Miami Beach after a short illness. He was 82 years old and lived here at 55 South Magnolia Avenue.
The prospect of Soviet leadership in nuclear energy development by 1960 is causing concern among United States specialists in the field.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 --The apparel industry can catch up with national prosperity by a positive approach to fashion merchandising, Max E. Weinstock, chairman of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, asserted here today.

Ned Irish, director of basketball and executive vice president of Madison Square Garden, said yesterday that every effort would be made to "improve the personnel" of the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association.
LONDON, Jan. 23--The stock market continued unsettled today. Despite a late improvement British Government loans finished lower. Industrial shares were especially dull at the close.

ONE of the strongest convictions which I brought to the office of President was that the antiquated defense set-up of the United States had to be reorganized quickly as a step toward insuring our future safety and preserving world peace. From the beginning of my Administration I began to push hard for unification of the military establishment into a single department of the armed forces.

An analysis of vessel activity at the country's eleven leading ports reveals that nearly 23 per cent of all ship traffic of last year--both inbound and outbound--called at this port. The results of this study were made public yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

WILLIAMSON, W.Va., Jan. 23 (UP)--An engineer died at the controls of his train today and thirty passengers and crewmen were injured when the locomotive and five cars plunged down a riverside embankment.

LONDON, Jan. 23--The drop in British tramp steamer tonnage, from 3,000,000 tons before World War II to 2,500,000 now, was cited here today as an example of how high taxation could endanger the nation's shipping position.

LIKE love and marriage or even a horse and carriage, the New York Knicks have kept company steadily with the Minne apolis Lakers of late. After a long estrangement they paired off on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Then they have a date in Minneapolis tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP)--Hogs sold above $13 today for the first time this year as butchers jumped 50 cents and sows 25 to 50 cents in an active market. The strength reflected small arrivals and a good demand from packers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, said today that Life Magazine's "brink of war" article was "a partisanly inspired effort to glorify" John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, by a "house organ" for the Eisenhower Administration.

HUT POINT, Ross Island, Antarctica, Jan. 23--Twelve of the least hospitable acres in the world, cradled on a series of dead volcanoes, are being converted into a United States outpost in the Antarctic by 100 Navy Seabees.

BETWEEN the characters of Cornelia Otis Skinner and the chicanery of that versatile magician Fred Keating, "Characters and Chicanery" turned out to be a most diverting bit of entertainment at the Phoenix Theatre last night.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 23-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that his Government would not surrender to mob violence. He warned that an "orgy of violence" jeopardized India's future.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 23--The history lesson in the fifth grade at P.S. 80 today for pupils 8 to 10 years of age was "the strike in Svarov."
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday that he would do all in his power to help Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy obtain the 5,000 new policemen for whom he has asked.

International transactions of the United States during 1956-- including trade, services and financial transfers--are expected to total a record $42,100,000,000, according to a review and forecast released yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 23 --United States Ambassador Horace A. Hildreth said today that neutralism did not pay so far as economic aid from the United States was concerned.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23--Negotiations are under way for a cultural exchange between the United States and the Soviet Union involving the Everyman Opera Company and the Igor Moisseyev Folk Dance troupe. High Soviet officials have indicated their approval of the project.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP)-- William George (Billy) Evans, widely known baseball executive and formerly an American League umpire for twenty-two years, died tonight in North Shore Hospital. He was 71 years old.

One of the key issues in General Eisenhower's campaign for the Presidency in 1952 was the issue of recapturing control over a Federal budget that at that time was completely out of hand. Mr. Eisenhower selected Joseph M. Dodge, a Detroit banker, as his first Budget Director.
THE trail of a gourmet twists and turns. In New York it may lead to such an out-of-theway store as that owned by Platon Stasiuk, at 124 First Avenue (near Seventh Street).

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Jan. 23--In the East and the nation, they know Charlie Speidel as one of college wrestling's top "salesmen." The role, while somewhat removed from his official job as Penn State coach, still pays handsome dividends.

Stocks swung widely yesterday. They opened mixed, gained ground, slumped in the second hour to the lowest levels since Nov. 2 and then staged a broad recovery. The rally was still in progress at the bell.
A state legislative committee is investigating whether the Harriman Administration tried to hamper efforts to rid the docks of racketeers.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 23--John R. Tucker of 180 Seventh Avenue, a Pennsylvania Railroad police lieutenant for many years, died of cancer yesterday. He was 64 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson of Woodgate, Sunnyhill, Hawick, Roxburghshire, Scotland, have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annie Allen Wilson, to George Terhune Peck. He is a son of Mrs. Robert Bruce Burns of Santiago,...
The Stuyvesant swimmers who set a Public Schools Athletic League record for the 150-yard medley relay last Friday had not competed as a unit before the trials for the event.

ROME, Jan. 23--The spring fashion collection of the three Fontana sisters harkens back to the turn of the century, when beautiful women wore beautiful clothes. These are the hallmarks of their silhouette: pinched Edwardian waistlines, draped and bustled; skirts, reminiscent of Queen Alexandra, that narrow in at the knee.
Cecil Smith of San Antonio, Tex., a ten-goal performer since 1938, retained that rating yesterday in the 1956 handicaps announced by the United States Polo Association.
BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP)--The general counsel of the Boston and Maine Railroad said tonight that Patrick B. McGinnis had sold his stockholdings in the New Haven Railroad.

SOLINGEN, Germany, Jan. 23 --A rehabilitation center has been established near here to help refugees from the Soviet-bloc countries to re-establish themselves. The refugees have spent years of inactivity in inadequately equipped camps in West Germany.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 255 pints of blood yesterday from members and employes of Wall Street companies. The collection was made at Federal Hall, Wall and Nassau Streets, with Keith Funston, president...
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23-- The Government announced today that several groups of "subversive" plotters had been arrested over the week-end.

Rory Calhoun, unbeaten White Plains middleweight, defeated Jerry Luedee of New Haven for the second time in the ten-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The first time had been in a four-round preliminary at Madison Square Garden in November, 1954.
ROME, Jan. 23 (AP)--Renato Ricci, who was once vice secretary of the Italian Fascist party, died at his home here last night after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The $19,000,000 increase asked by the Administration for hospital construction next year will go into building diagnostic centers, chronic disease hospitals, nursing homes and rehabilitation facilities. The increase is from $111,000,000 to $130,000,000, or 17 per cent.
The President and Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, former Army Chief of Staff, are talking at cross-purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) --Senator Clinton P. Anderson demanded today to know why the Atomic Energy Commission did not give Congress "the full story" of attempts to tame the hydrogen bomb for peacetime uses.

George Alpert, new president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, for the present is going to concentrate on the roads serious locomotive needs. Financial problems, also considerable, will be handled by top aides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- President Eisenhower reported to Congress today that the national economy, nearing $400,000,000,000 in total output, appears to be still on the upswing, despite recent hesitations in automobiles and housing.
LONDON, Jan. 24--The British Government firmly rejected today Labor Opposition demands that the Soviet Union be asked to "join in discussions to safeguard peace between Israel and the Arab states."
A man who renounced thirty years ago a $100,000 legacy, from a woman he had advised, was killed last evening by a Third Avenue bus.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 24--A new historical portrait of Thomas Masaryk, the "George Washington" of Czechoslovakia, is being drawn for this country's high school students.
MR. JOHN, master chef when it comes to whipping up millinery, has just produced the most delicious recipe yet soft-as-air, light-as-cake icing fabric hats.
A City Administration bill introduced yesterday in the City Council would bring operation of the Correction Department's commissary funds under close control of the Controller's office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, called on Americans tonight to support the work of the newly organized National Monument Commission.

In reply to the American statement regarding the Sino-American talks in Geneva, the Chinese Communists have issued another declaration which in effect repudiates the earlier Geneva agreement for the release of all American prisoners as "one-sided" and makes their liberation dependent on two conditions.
The city's public-assistance caseloads in December dropped below the 1955 peak month of March by 10,308 persons and 5,957 cases, Commissioner of Welfare Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 24--India's Communist party opened an attack today on the Government's attempts to solve regional feuds that have flared into violence and strikes.

Oscar Karlweis, one of the few actors whose reputation was equally high in the United States and Europe and on Broadway and in Hollywood, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 57 West Fifty-eighth Street. He was 61 years old.

Some 220,000 refugees from Eastern Europe are now living in camps in West Germany. The problem of providing for their needs, of integrating as many of them as possible into a free society as productive members of that society, is a serious one.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Air Force was reported today to have refused a plea by Robert Moses to close down Mitchel Field in congested Nassau County.
Prices of coccoa futures tumbled to new seasonal lows yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot price fell to the lowest level since 1950.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 24--An antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was settled today on terms described by Government lawyers as a major victory.
The need of the Police Department for additional men must be considered before the city can undertake the repeal of any nuisance tax, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.
PARIS, Jan. 24--The movement led by Pierre Poujade was branded as anti-Semitic today by a member who had resigned.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24--The local character of the trade was reflected in choppy fluctuations in grain and soybean futures today.
THE life of the late John Golden, producer of the old school, generous benefactor of many causes, lover of publicity and man of many friends, was told last night in the National Broadcasting Com-...
A thorough study of the operation of the film industry's self-regulation code was ordered yesterday. The likelihood of some considerable changes in the present system was foreseen.
PANAMA, Jan. 22--A new press law is being written for Colombia, arousing cautious, hopes it will bring an end to the Government's arbitrary measures against Colombian news papers.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Jan. 24--For the second straight day, Italy's Eugenio Monti today lowered the Olympic course record tor two-man bobsleds. Monti zoomed down the one-mile run in 1 minute 21.98 seconds.
Counsel for Paul H. Hughes stressed yesterday the view that the Washington private investigator's perjury trial was obscured by political motivations.
Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, retired, former Ambassador to China, differs sharply with Harry S. Truman on some points made by the former President in the installment of his Memoirs published today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24 --Betty Hutton will resume movie acting in May by costarring with Dana Andrews in "Spring Reunion."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Democratic National Chairman charged today that Republican leaders had "sabotaged" a $10,000,000 bipartisan advertising campaign to encourage political campaign contribtions in 1956.

PARIS, Jan. 24--In Otchko, a card game widely played in the U.S.S.R., it is illegal to deal off the top of the deck. Statesmen seeking to comprehend the ins and outs of Soviet policy might be advised to master this pastime.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- legislative recommendations in President Eisenhower's Economic Report reflected today the Administration's concern over thg growing rate of business mergers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) --Senators James O. Eastland and William E. Jenner have asked Robert Morris, now a New York City Municipal Court judge, to return as chief counsel of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee.
Senator William F. Knowland of California defended yesterday calculated risks taken by the Eisenhower Administration to keep the peace.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 24-- West Germany is preparing to order $600,000,000 worth of military equipment abroad.
ALBANY, Jan. 24--The State Thruway Authority submitted today a proposed route to con nect the Thruway with New Jersey's Garden State Parkway at the New York-New Jersey border.
Fannie May has grown up to be a big girl in the mortgage family.
Yesterday the President sent to Congress his Annual Economic Report. This is a document prepared for him by his Council of Economic Advisers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that the Administration had no intention of withdrawing the nomination of Robert R. Bowie to be Assistant Secretary of State.
A relic of the Mesozoic era that was old when dinosaurs were young was put on display at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. Called a tuatara, the live creature is one of the two specimens in this country.
Television and radio coverage of the Democratic and Republican national conventions will be sponsored over the American Broadcasting Company networks by the Philco Corporation.
Net income of the Erie Railroad last year increased to $7,892,354, or $2.97 a common share before capital and sinking funds, from $6,378,652 or $1.78 a share in the previous year.
Scientists in and out of Government are sharpening their weapons for a joint expedition against a recurring natural threat to life and property--the hurricane.
A new method of light amplification, which engineers say can almost "see in the dark," was demonstrated here yesterday.
Buying continued brisk yesterday at the exhibit at the New York Furniture Exchange here.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 24 (AP)--Ask some American sports fans, "What's a slalom?" and they wouldn't know whether to eat it, run it or shoot it.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (UP)--Newspapers are planning a "frontal assault" on television in the battle for advertising revenue, a newspaper advertising expert said today.
A rocket-firing electromechanical "brain" has been developed to direct from shipboard the destruction of ground-troop concentrations ashore.
Harvie Ward Jr. is paying his first winter visit to New York tomorrow. The nation's top ranking amateur golfer, a native of Tarboro, N.C., prefers the balmy weather of the South.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- Louis S. Rothschild, Under Secretary of Commerce, said today that Frederick B. Lee was ousted as Civil Aeronautics Administrator partly because he was not a good enough salesman or planner of aviation policies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, in a belated report, said today Harold E. Talbott and Hugh W. Cross had "acted indiscreetly" in their Government posts, and their resignations under fire had been "quite proper."
The $1,500,000 estate left by Miss Kathryn Henesey, 87-yearold Park Avenue spinster, will go to her next of kin, Surrogate William T. Collins ruled yesterday.
BRIDGETON, N.J., Jan. 23 (AP)--Fire destroyed a small frame home in this southeastern New Jersey community today and six young children were believed burned to death.
Stocks yesterday made the widest gains in more than two months, but registered them on markedly lower volume. Turnover for the day was 2,160,000 shares, against 2,720,000 on Monday.
Seventeen-year-old Susan Strasberg will be graduated to stardom today at a time when most of her contemporaries will be chewing their pencils over Regents exams.

THE dispute grew so bitter that it seemed the baseball game would have to be canceled. The umpire had failed to appear for the Class D meeting of the Youngstown and Homestead teams and the managers could not agree on a replacement.

Plans for manufacturing Volkswagen automobiles in the United States have been canceled. The announcement by Heinz Nordhoff, director general of Volkswagen G.M. B.H. of Wolfsburg, Germany, was issued here yesterday.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Wednesday, Jan. 25--Sir Anthony Eden hopes to negotiate a joint British-United States statement on "colonialism" in Africa and Asia during his talks in Washington.

LONDON, Jan. 24--Government loans continued their recovery today in the stock market and were joined by some industrial shares. But industrials showed more falls than rises at the close.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24 --The National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board was briefed today on the basic need of its fair-trade practices and the steps leading to a largescale industry promotional campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UP) --Background on the Economic Report sent to Congress today by President Eisenhower:

General Motors closed its $2,000,000 Motorama last night after selling $1,300,000 worth of cars. An attendance record of 275,316 was set during the sixday run, plus the preview. Yesterday 68,310 persons saw the exhibition.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 24-- Finland's reluctant role in the Kremlin's game of Scandinavian power politics was underscored in a new Soviet move today.
Directors of the Southern Railway Company yesterday proposed a 2 -for-1 split in the preferred and common stock. The splits are subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting in May.

Increases ranging up to $1,480 annually were won last year by workers on various types of New York City floating equipment, according to a review made public yesterday by Local 333, United Marine Division, A.F.L.
David S. Meister, real estate operator and investor, has purchased the two three-story buildings on plot 50 by 110 feet at 1227-1229 Third Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-first Street.
OUT of a simple case of prison camp treason the authors of "Time Limit!," put on at the Booth last evening have written a stunning drama.
The Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity requested yesterday increases of $4,196,045 for its operations in the 1956-57 fiscal year.
The Waterfront Commission has voted steamship lines and employing stevedores a 25 per cent reduction in payroll assessments. The commission uses the assessments to finance its activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Surgeon General Leonard A. Scheele asked Congress today for extension of the Federal poliomyelitis vaccine program to July 1, 1957. The current legislation expires Feb. 15.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 24-- W.S. Hackworth resigned today as president of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway to become president of the Nashville Trust Company, a local banking house.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- A half-dozen business groups today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to block the proposed 7 per cent increase in railroad freight rates.
First-nighters will assemble at the John Golden Theatre tonight to pass judgment on "The Hot Corner." Curtain time is 8 o'clock.

The New York Telephone Company said the average of 312,000 more telephones in service last year than in 1954, and the high level of 1955 business activity, helped to increase its operating revenues last year.

MIAMI, Jan. 24 (AP)--The Maine Chance Farm's Myrtle's Jet furnished a mild surprise at Hialeah Park today when she rallied, after being headed at the sixteenth pole, to beat Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Sometime Thing by a nose in the $6,000 Orange Blossom Purse.
ROBERT GOLDSAND, who was heard last night at Carnegie Hall, is an unrelentingly serious pianist who has pursued a strikingly independent course since his debut here in 1927 as a youth of 16.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Mrs. Dwight D. Eisennower resumed a limited social program today. She announced a series of eleven engagements between tomorrow and March 3.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 24 (UP)--President Maurice Podoloff of the National Basketball Association agreed today to meet with representatives of the players within two weeks to discuss various demands made by the players.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Secretary of State Dulles is trying to arrange an agreement with leading Democrats to keep the Israeli-Arab dispute out of debate in the Presidential election campaign.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 24 (UP)--Brilliant performances by Bob Pettit and Vern Mikkelsen, and some clever strategy by Coach Charley Eckman, helped the West rally to upset the East tonight, 108--94, in the National Basketball Association's annual All-Star game.

DETROIT, Jan. 24--George W. Troost of this city, financial vice president, director and a member of the finance committee of the Chrysler Corporation, died tonight in Grace Hospital after an operation for a brain tumor. His age was 53.

On the question of compulsory automobile liability insurance and related problems of indemnifying the victim of the financially irresponsible motorist it seems to us that an unusually bright opportunity exists for some teamwork at Albany.
BOMBAY, India, Jan. 24 (AP)-- The Indian Government today ordered an end to hedge trading at the East India Cotton Exchange, Asia's largest cottontrading center and one of the largest in the world.
Newspaper advertising for all of 1955 came to 2,843,394,974 lines for fifty-two cities measured by Media Records, according to an analysis of that organization's data.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24--An effort to spur repairs to housing throughout the country soon will be made by Congress, it was disclosed here today at the convention of the National Association of Home Builders.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--The Legislature was asked today to set up a special committee to study the causes of marital break-ups in New York and to suggest means for reducing the number of divorces, separations and annulments.
MADRID, Jan. 24--The Ministry of Commerce authorized export of olive oil today in shipments approved under licenses expiring Jan. 31.
FEW can speak better of the table art in Italy than Gio vanni Buitoni, macroni magnate. Head of a company known for pasta here and abroad, Mr. Buitoni often returns to Italy.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Jan. 24-- The Ceylonese Government has decided to set up an $11,000,000 fund to maintain at certain levels the prices of all grades of rubber produced on the island in the event of a slump in prices.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 24 (UP)--Black-and-white crash helmets were issued to the United States men's ski team tonight when lack of snow pushed the pre-Olympic injury list to twenty-seven.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Secretary of State Dulles said today that President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden were likely to discuss the possibilities of controlling or limiting nuclear bomb tests.
The Boeing Airplane Company has set up two new operating divisions and an over-all corporate headquarters organization.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Applications for 246 tax certificates covering investments in defense production projects were reinstated today by the Government.

From-the-scene statements that Villanova's Phil Reavis had leaped higher over his own head than any other athlete in clearing the high jump bar at 6 feet 9 7/8 inches in Boston and 6 feet 10 inches in Philadelphia have not withstood research.
A 33-year-old stockbroker fell or jumped to his death from his sixteenth-floor apartment at 35 Park Avenue yesterday, the police reported. He was identified as Charles Blyth Martin Jr.

HONG KONG, Jan. 24--Communist China warned the United States tonight it must take responsibility for "all the consequences" if the ambassadorial talks at Geneva break down on the questions of Taiwan (Formosa) and civilian repatriation.
The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on $19,350,000 of notes for the temporary financing of Forest Houses, a state-aided project in the Bronx.
MOSCOW, Jan. 24--The Premier of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic, which occupies three-quarters of the Soviet Union, has resigned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- Representative Clarence Cannon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said today Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, had "dodged" questions about the relative strength of United States and Russian armed forces.
OTTAWA, Jan. 24--A formula for peace in the Middle East was outlined today in the House of Commons by Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs.
A two-year, $12,000,000 wage agreement was reached yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company and two unions representing 23,000 workers.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 24-- The Governors of four Southern states agreed here today to stand together in challenging the United States Supreme Court's ruling outlawing public school segregation.
MOSCOW, Jan. 24--David Oistrakh, the Soviet violinist who recently toured the United States, called today for "broad and systematic cultural exchanges" between the United States and the Soviet Union.
AS unlikely as might appear at first glance, the big and handsome Winter Antiques Show, which opened yesterday, is far from off-limits to the small or "amateur" collector.

Cooperation between Government and private enterprise "is clearly the answer" to the "terrible problem of urban blight," David Rockefeller, executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said yesterday.
GREENSBORO, N.C., Jan. 24 --Dr. David Dallas Jones, president of Bennett College, a private college for Negro women, died here today. His age was 68.
ALBANY, Jan. 24--A bill was introduced in the Legislature today to free New York City from big initial outlays on capital projects financed with shortterm borrowing.
The question of whether Colombia is going to have press freedom is important. Tad Szulc, our correspondent, devotes the third of three articles on Colombia to that subject in today's paper.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 24--Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, announced today that Egypt had accepted three proposals to ease tension in the vicinity of the demilitarized zone at El Auja (Nitsana).

ALBANY, Jan. 24--A renewed state effort to make highways in the Adirondacks straighter, broader and smoother ran into stubborn opposition today from representatives of conservation groups and garden clubs.
TRENTON, Jan. 24--Between 600 and 1,000 New Jersey public school teachers are expected to retire between now and March 31. This compares with 400 retirements in all of 1954.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 24 --Mme. Soong Ching-ling, widow of the founder of the Chinese Republic, was greeted here today with pomp and ceremony as an envoy of Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Following is the State Department transcript of the news conference held today by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State:
PARIS, Jan. 24--A Leftist majority of Communists, Socialists and Radicals elected 71-yearold Socialist, Andre Le Troquer speaker of the new French National Assembly tonight.
A fading athlete and a rising star, both big names in baseball, were signed yesterday by the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Yankees, respectively.
A one-story building at 616 Merrick Road in Lynbrook, L.I., has been leased by the Dantomuro Furniture, Inc., manufacturer of custom-made furniture, from the National Vending Corporation.
Mal Whitfield, twice an 800meter Olympic track champion, intends to train for a place on the 1956 United States Olympic team as a hurdler.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 23 points up to 4 points off yesterday. Only the July, 1957, option was down; July, 1956, was the strongest month.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24--Albert E. Monk, president of the Council of Trades Unions, described as grim today the situation produced by the strike of Australian dock workers.

QUEBEC, Jan. 24--The revised text of Premier Duplessis' newsprint control law includes several changes based upon objections expressed in the last ten days by representatives of the pulp and paper industry and provincial newspapers.
MOSCOW, Jan. 24--Marshal Vasily I. Chuikov, Commander of the Kiev Military District, has asserted that the Soviet Union has surpassed the United States in "hydrogen armament."
HARRIMAN, N.Y., Jan. 24-- Chairman Benjamin F. Feinberg of the Public Service Commission said tonight that bus companies should be relieved of the state's 2 per cent gross receipts tax.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The House fight over the $1,600,000,000 school construction bill got under way today. It gave promise of becoming one of the bitterest of the new session.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24. --The wide acclaim Dinah Shore received last week as a result of her one-hour television show with Perry Como and Gisele MacKenzie might lead to bigger and better things for the popular singer.

MARCO POLO, who introduced the treasures of the East to thirteenth-century Venice, has inspired twentieth-century decorators. This week Abraham Straus built a series of room settings around the travels of the explorer.
Dr. Raphael Ginzberg, a specialist in diseases of the aged, died of a heart attack Thursday in Tomah, Wis. His age was 60.
ALBANY, Jan, 24--A legislative commission decided today, with bipartisan alacrity, to do battle with Robert Moses. But some of its members soon afterward began to be assailed with misgivings.
Stephen (Tex) Sullivan was the principal witness at the boxing hearing conducted by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.
R. Kirby Shirley, senior vice president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 56 years old. His residence was 43 Gateway Drive, Great Neck, L.I.

Charles L. Patterson, Transit Authority chairman, said yesterday he favored removing the seats from I.R.T. shuttle trains to increase the passenger load.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 24 (AP)-- The Democrats won an easy victory tonight in the nation's first Congressional election of 1956.
Yonkers Raceway is prepared to spend $14,500,000 for extensive remodeling of the harness racing track in the event proposed legislation in Albany becomes law.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York started its annual campaign for funds yesterday. It seeks $505,000 from individuals, churches and denominations toward a total budget of $565,000.

Two personnel changes in the Army's Atlantic Transportation Terminal Command have been announced by Brig. Gen. James Glore. Col. Herbert M. Fitzgerald has been named director of services and Maj. Robert W. Lalk has been appointed transportation officer.

Maurice Walter, New York realty broker, reported the sale of business property in Meriden, Conn., for the West Main Street Realty Company, also of New York. The property consists of the two-story building occupied by the F.W. Woolworth Company at 33-37 West Main Street.

A Waterfront Commission hearing officer has recommended the granting of a stevedore license to the Nacirema Operating Company, Inc., it was learned yesterday. The company was charged by the bi-state agency with "bribery," "perjury" and "payoffs."

George Silber of the Rek-OKut Company has been elected president of the Institute of High Fidelity Manufacturers, Inc. Walter Jablon of the Presto Recording Corporation was elected vice president and Vinton K. Ulrich of the David Bogen Company, Inc., secretarytreasurer.
CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 25 (AP) --Senator Estes Kefauver formally entered the New Hampshire Presidential primary today and said he thought his chances to repeat his 1952 victory here "are very good."

LAHORE, Pakistan, Jan. 25 (Reuters)--England's Marylebone Cricket Club A team and Pakistan drew in an unofficial test today. The final score was M.C.C. 204 and 322 for 7, Pakistan 363 for 9 declared.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Leading all the way, the Minneapolis Lakers defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 104--95, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 25-- After deliberating almost a week a jury found Burton W. Abbott, a 27-year-old student of accounting, guilty today of the kidnapping and murder of Stephanie Bryan, 14. The jury made no recommendation for mercy to Judge Charles W. Snook of the State Superior Court, thus condemning Abbott to death.
A 62-year-old man identified as Phillip Brooks leaped to his death at 11 o'clock last night, the police said, from his office in the thirty-second floor of the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway.

LONDON, Jan. 25--Industrial shares helped by Wall Street extended their rally today despite a reaction in Government stocks. The latter opened higher but lack of "follow-through" left prices irregular, with War Loan one shilling threepence (17 cents) cheaper.

The 1955 "ingenious deal" contest of the Westchester County Realty Board has been won by Walter Rostenberg of White Plains. Presentation of the award, a $750 United States Savings bond, was made last night at a dinner of the board at the Larchmont Shore Club in Larchmont.

The election of Vance Johnson as vice president of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company has been announced by Paul C. Smith, president and editor-in-chief. Mr. Johnson, who was appointed general manager last month, previously had been assistant to Mr. Smith for editorial direction.

Saudi Arabia has expanded and intensified the blacklisting of companies dealing with Israel. The blacklist was originated by the Arab League three years ago. At least twenty-five names have been added to the list, Saudi Arabian sources have confirmed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--A bill to extend distribution of free polio vaccine, to the states to July, 1957, was approved today by the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee. The authority otherwise would expire on Feb. 15. The bill contains an appropriation of $30,000,000.

A young refugee countess from Hungary has come here to learn economics and commerce. She hopes to use the knowledge later in the reconstruction of a liberated Hungary.

ROME, Jan. 25 (AP)--Budget Minister Ezio Vanoni announced tonight that foreign movie people working in Italy would have to pay taxes from now on. Italian film producers have been ordered to withhold percentages of salaries to guarantee payments to the Government.

Brooklyn Union Gas Company's net income increased to $5,039,000 in 1955 from $4,650,000 in 1954, according to a preliminary annual report released yesterday.

AMERICAN women will see spring through new eyes if Guy Nicolet of Elizabeth Arden's Paris salon has his way. He has created a wide-eyed genteel look he calls "Patrician."

Former Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams was one of five new members elected to the board of directors of the Police Athletic League yesterday. A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Paul Jacobson of 1225 Park Avenue on Sunday in French Hospital. Mrs. Jacobson is the former Miss Norma Fabian.

A "Colombo Plan" for the countries of the Middle East was proposed yesterday by Sir Percy Spender. The Australian Ambassador to the United States was the propounder of the mutual aid plan now in force for the development of south and southeast Asia.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 25 (AP)--Italy spent more than $8,000,000 on this Winter Olympics.
HARTFORD, Jan. 25--Isidore Wise, a business, civic and religious leader here for more than sixty years, died today after a brief illness.

Joseph W. Higman, chief clerk in the New York office of the Public Service Commission, will retire Jan. 31. He has completed forty-two years of service with the commission and predecessor regulatory bodies. Dividends and other corporate developments put sparkle into the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. There were good gains on light volume early in the day and, though the market drifted lower as the session grew older, it showed a net advance at the close.

The six-story apartment house at 1226-30 Sherman Avenue, the Bronx, which was bought recently by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, has been resold to the Namrehs 1230 Realty Corporation subject to mortgages of $287,000.

The New York Central Railroad had greater earnings in 1955 than in any year since wartime 1943. The road reported yesterday gross revenues of $762,666,356 last year, and net income of $52,283,814, equal to $8.03 a share.

The Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn issued a call to a new rector last night. He is the Rev. George William Barnes, who for nine years has been rector of St. Thomas' Protestant Episcopal Church in Hollywood, Calif.

VIENNA, Jan. 25 (AP)--"Porgy and Bess" has opened its Warsaw run to a capacity house and "frantic applause." Radio Warsaw described the opening performance of the opera last night by the touring American company as a smashing success.

The New York Rangers yesterday released a forward, Jim Bartlett, and a utility skater, Aldo Guidolin, to the Providence Reds of the American Hockey League. Larry Popein, injured two weeks ago, has recovered. He accompanied the Rangers yesterday to Detroit, where they oppose the Red Wings in a National League game tonight.

To people who think of New York as a city of concrete and steel the number of trees in it may be a surprise. For on city-owned property alone, along streets and in the parks, there are estimated to be 2,300,000 trees.

Roger Berg, 12 years old, of 926 Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn, accidentally electrocuted himself last night in the basement of his home. The police said he had run a double wire from a socket to a television antenna. He was the son of Irving Berg.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)--Hog prices climbed to $14 here today as butchers jumped 25 to 75 cents in a very active market.

Donald A. Quarles, Secretary of the Air Force, predicted last night that national defense would become increasingly expensive as the weapons of warfare become more complex and technical competition stronger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) --The State Department announced tonight that it had replaced Edwin A. Plitt, a diplomat since 1921, who was heavily criticized in the freeing last fall of Sepp Dietrich, Nazi war criminal.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 25 (UP)--Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff said today he had no national political ambitions. The Governor issued the statement after Joseph Cronin, Mayor of Hartford, attempted to boom Mr. Ribicoff for the Democratic Vice Presidential nomination.

White snapdragons and gladioluses formed a background in the chantry of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jacqueline Orde Hale to Robert Oldham Forsyth.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 25--Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, led a parade of the Communist world's political and military chieftains into this flag-bedecked capital today.
Michael J. Quill led 250 members of his Transport Workers Union in a demonstration yesterday inside Pennsylvania Station.

LONDON, Jan. 25--A committee appointed by the Government reported today there had been no widespread extravagance in the use of money and manpower in the National Health Service. The committee has been investigating for two and a half years.
The Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot has issued its first invitation for bids on clothing contracts under a new system that will permit bidders to set their own delivery schedule.

Judge Archie O. Dawson of the United States District Court has purchased an apartment in the cooperative building at 1088 Park Avenue through Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker. Mrs. Dorothy Liebes Morin bought an apartment in 131 East Sixty-sixth Street through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.
The National Recreation Association, at a ceremony marking its fiftieth anniversary yesterday, was urged to continue its high standards of research and promotion of leisure time activities.
SINCE Allen Boretz was one of the two authors of "Room Service," it would be logical to expect "The Hot Corner" to be at least half funny.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--This was a bad day for the Republicans. President Eisenhower not only sounded wistful about those black Angus cattle in Gettysburg, but also virtually scratched Chief Justice Earl Warren from the Presidential race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Paul Blanshard said tonight that "the Catholic school system may emerge as the only winner" if Southern states finance private schools as a way to prevent racially integrated public schools.
TORONTO, Jan. 25 (UP)--The Toronto Maple Leafs jammed three third-period goals behind Hank Bassen to whip the Chicago Black Hawks, 3--1, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

Donald Campbell, the world speed-boat record-holder, arrived from England yesterday to start a search for a fresh water site in preparation for his attempt to raise the record to 250 miles per hour. The record is 216.25. The Englishman arrived on the United States liner United States.

COPENHAGEN, Denumark, Jan. 25--Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, will visit Denmark during the spring. He has accepted an invitation from Copenhagen University's Students Association to give a talk on the international situation.
ALBANY, Jan. 25--The State Parole Board decided today to release Joseph C. (Joey) Fay, labor racketeer, from prison.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)-- The Senate confirmed by a voice vote today President Eisenhower's nomination of Herbert V. Prochnow of Chicago to be Deputy Under Secretary of State. Isaac W. Carpenter Jr. of Omaha, Neb., was confirmed as Assistant Secretary of State.
The radar airplane pilots use for getting around thunderstorms might be even more useful with a little modification, a University of Chicago meteorologist suggested yesterday.
The Singers Club of Plandome, L.I., has announced auditions for its $500 Olive Dutton Voice Scholarship.

Rubber prices were strong yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York following declines in five consecutive trading days. The strength was termed a technical reaction to the recent weakness. Higher foreign cables influenced trading.

He may be America's most contented sportsman. If not, he'll do until another comes along and is identified. Ralph G. Klieforth's life and business are in one sport. He spends his surpluses on the hobby of another sport. He gets his fun and satisfaction both ways. There is no drudgery in his life.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Jan. 25-- Traffic between Algiers and Constantine was interrupted last night when a phosphate train struck an explosive charge.

ALBANY, Jan. 25 (UP)--Governor Harriman today proclaimed February as Heart Month and urged support of agencies waging the fight against hearth disease. He said last year 70,000 persons in the state died from heart disease.

ALBANY, Jan. 25--The Public Service Commission took its fight to strip the State Power Authority of rate-regulating functions to the Legislature today.

LONDON, Jan. 25--Once again Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor party's left wing, is bidding for a place in the party's top ranks. He has entered as a candidate to succeed Herbert Morrison as deputy leader of the party.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25--Nikita S. Khrushchev said today he believed President Eisenhower and other United States leaders were sincerely striving for peace. Prime Minister Eden and Premier Edgar Faure ef France also opposed war.
MIAMI, Jan. 25 (UP)--Nineteen of Nashua's racing mates brought a total of $301,300 at a thoroughbred auction at Hialeah Park today.
A subcommittee of the House of Representatives' Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee yesterday opened a four-day hearing here into the foreign freight forwarding industry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) --President Eisenhower sends to Congress tomorrow a special message on health legislation.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP)--A Yugoslav delegation is in Moscow to negotiate commercial loans and credits. V. Guzina, manager of the People's Bank of Yugoslavia, is chief delegate.

The sand siren's figure is melting away. According to a sales survey by Rose Marie Swimsuits, smaller sizes are becoming more and more salable.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 12 to 36 points (60 cents to $1.80 a bale) yesterday. Old July and new crop months showed the greatest strength.

Lane Bryant, Inc., announced yesterday that it would accept tenders of its 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock at $51 a share and that, at the meeting of directors scheduled for Jan. 31, proposals to retire the issue would be considered.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25--The Soviet Encyclopedia has considerably reduced Franklin D. Roosevelt from his position of eminence in the wartime and early postwar Communist propaganda.

The Metropolitan Opera presented "Andrea Chenier" last night. Frank Valentino replaced the indisposed Ettore Bastianini as Carto Gerard, and Clifford Harvuot took over Mr. Valentino's original role of Roucher.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 25 Desegregation of Nashville municipal golf courses was ordered today by a Federal District Court here.
TOKYO, Jan. 25--The Japanese Diet resumed today after its long New Year's recess. It held only a brief session and then adjourned until Monday.
Hank Greenberg and Joe Cronin, great ball players who now are top executives in the game, yesterday were elected to the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y.
The Dodgers yesterday signed the highest-paid player in their history--Roy Campanella, star catcher and three times the National League's most valuable player.
Executives of advertising agencies are to get some firsthand advice, at $100 each, on how to be sure the "other" products in their advertising are as up-to-date as the product they are selling.

A new kind of mink--a natural pale brown mutation--will go on sale to manufacturers for the first time on Feb. 29 at the New York Auction Company. Developed by the Mutation Mink Breeders Association, the "Diadem" brand mink will be presented only once this year, in an offering of 14,000 pelts.

John Sherman Cooper, United States Ambassador to India, returned here yesterday after ten months in New Delhi. He will attend conferences with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles.

Directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation surprised financial circles yesterday by voting to maintain the regular quarterly dividend on the common stock.

President Eisenhower will be among the golfing enthusiasts honored tonight at the annual award dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Hertz Corporation announced today the purchase of Atlantic National Insurance Company, Miami, Fla., for more than $1,000,000. The company was a pioneer in the field of car and truck rental insurance.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25-- President Eisenhower reasserted today the United States policy of even-handed friendship for Arabs and Israelis.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25-- The Donner Foundation announced today that it would donate twelve powerful Van de Graaff X-ray generators to twelve hospitals and clinics for nonprofit treatment of cancers. The machines, valued at $822,000, are to be delivered beginning late this year and before the end of 1957. The recipients are to be selected within three months.

William N. Enstrom, chairman of the Irving Trust Company, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting that he "hopes and sincerely trusts" the bank's directors will increase the dividend rate again this year.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Corn and wheat futures showed a weak tone today, while soybeans, oats and rye were quite steady.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 25 --Worthington Miner, producer of the television series "Frontier," and his two writers, Mort Fine and David Friedkin, are considering taking a recent "Frontier" script to Broadway as a stage play.

The Navy has announced the appointment of Vice Admiral Charles R. Brown as Deputy Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet. He reported for duty this week at Atlantic Fleet headquarters in Norfolk, Va. He will serve under Admiral Jerauld Wright.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 25-- The Very Rev. Dr. John T. Sheehan, former head of the Order of St. Augustine in the United States, died here today in the rectory of St. Nicholas of Tolentine Roman Catholic Church. He was 75 years old on Jan. 9.

Dr. Paul Schwarzkopf, owner of several score patents in the metallurgical field, announced yesterday the formation of a new concern, the Schwarzkopf Development Corporation, to function as a parent company of all his enterprises.

Mrs. Dave Hennen Morris Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in her home at 455 East Fifty-seventh Street for members of the committee arranging a "Come and See" tour of the work done here by the Young Women's Christian Association.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 25--The privilege of using the "political contacts and influence" of the Mayor of near-by Union City cost a New York engineering firm $184,000, it was charged here today.

LYDDA, Israel, Jan. 25--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of United Nations flew to Amman, Jordan, today. He departed amid signs that a local tempest over his "nonrecognition" of Jerusalem, which the Israelis claim as their capital, had evaporated.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25-- The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today that it made more money in 1955 than in any year since 1945. Net income last year amounted to $41,183,533, or $3.13 a share, compared with $18,552,235, or $1.41 a share, in 1954.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 25 (AP) --The Mississippi House of Representatives today passed, 121 to 2, a bill seeking to curb the desegregation activities of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25-- President Eisenhower opened the door almost imperceptibly today for a possible tax cut this year in the event that present estimates of Federal revenues proved too low.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 25 (AP)--Australia's Dave Stephens, who copies the training methods of Emil Zatopek, today lowered the Czech's world record for the six-mile run.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP)--Diego Rivera, Mexican muralist, left a Soviet hospital today saying he had been cured entirely of skin cancer. He said treatments given him with radioactive cobalt at Botkin Hospital for four months had effected a "miracle cure."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission has been asked by the Iroquois Gas Corporation of Buffalo, N.Y., for authority to develop a new underground storage area for natural gas in Chautauqua, Cattaraugus and Erie Counties, N.Y.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP)--Celebrations began today for the 100th anniversary of Niagara University. A solemn pontifical mass was held in the student center, in which tribute was paid to present and former members of the faculty.
IN at least thirty-one homes in this city this morning, one process of nature was reversed-- daddy and the children saw mother off to exams.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 25--Squaw Valley, Calif., will be confirmed as the site for the 1960 Winter Olympics providing the State of California Legislature approves an additional $4,000,000 appropriation for the games.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25-- President Eisenhower received today a "friendly letter" from Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, containing "certain ideas" about promoting world peace.

BRISBANE, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Protesting a requirement to make three appearances on the courts in one day in bad weather, Gil Shea and Herb Flam of California lost in the men's doubles quarter-finals of the Australian national tennis championships today but continued in the other brackets.
ALBANY, Jan. 25--John P. McGrath received informal assurance today that the Senate would confirm his appointment by Governor Harriman to the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.
WEISBERG, Ind., Jan. 25 (UP) --Three New York Central Railroad freight trains collided in a snowstorm on slippery rails today, killing one crew member and injuring at least two others.
The property at 1047 Madison Avenue and 42 East Eightieth Street has been purchased by the Manhattan Church of Christ as the site for a new edifice.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, was back at his desk yesterday after a seventy-eight-day trip around the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The Senate Rules Committee approved today and sent to the Senate floor a bill to create a joint Congressional "watchdog" committee to supervise activities of the super-secret Central Intelligence Agency.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP) --The White House announced today it would speak out soon on whether it believed steps were needed to lighten the work load of Presidents.
Louis E. Wolfson, who unsuccessfully waged a proxy fight for control of Montgomery Ward Co. last winter and spring, will resign tomorrow as a director of the Chicago mail-order house.
The Navy has awarded to the Seattle division of the Todd Shipyards Corporation a contract for the design and construction of two large floating pile-drivers.

LONDON, Jan. 26--The British Government made clear today that it was going to press for an early conclusion to the four-month-old negotiations between Governor Sir John Harding and Archbishop Makarios over the future of Cyprus.
Shareholders of Federated Department Stores, Inc., yesterday approved a 2-for-1 stock split, effective today.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks dropped by a modest $4,000,000 in the week ended on wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Federal Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of John T. Watkins, a labor union organizer, for contempt of Congress.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 26--Broad hints that the Warsaw treaty powers will take some new measures to strengthen the Communist world's military alliance were dropped by the press here today.

A supermarket building recently completed at 6301-23 Eleventh Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by the Kinos Realty Company, of which Joseph Angelo is president, to Louis R. Fisher. The property is occupied under lease by Dilbert Brothers.

HOME cooks who keep an eye on the market should riffle through their files of chicken recipes. The bird that stands for a good meal the world around is so abundant that broilers and fryers have been averaging as much as 6 cents a pound less than a year ago. And, trade sources say, prices on young chickens are in for another fall.

CAIRO, Jan. 26--In the view of United States and British diplomats in the Middle East, Saudi Arabia's intensive campaign of bribery throughout the Arab world has proved a tre mendous advantage to the Communists and a most costly disadvantage to the West.
The Fulbright-Harris bill to exempt independent producers of natural gas from Federal price control is in our opinion socially, economically and politically wrong.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, testifying yesterday for the Government in the perjury trial of Paul H. Hughes, attacked the reputations of two previous prosecution witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The White House and British Embassy officials announced today a tentative program for the foreign policy discussions next week between President Eisenhower and Sir Anthony Eden, British Prime Minister. The subjects were not elaborated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Organized labor split at the top today over strategy in meeting the issue of Federal aid to school districts that practiced racial segregation.

A brief stay at the John Golden Theatre is destined for "The Hot Corner." On Wednesday night the Allen Boretz-Ruby Sully collaboration was introduced by Eleanore Saidenberg. Tomorrow night the baseball farce, in which Sam Levene and Vicki Cummings are the leading players, will strike out after its fifth performance.
President Eisenhower asserted in a message yesterday that "considerable success" had been achieved in the Administration's civil rights and civil liberties program.

ATLANTA, Jan. 26--The State of Republic Committee of the Georgia House of Representatives today approved a newspaper libel bill. The one opponent said it was a measure that could harass daily newspapers out of business in the state. The vote was 24 to 1.
BERLIN, Jan. 26--East-West rivalry will mark the celebration of tomorrow's two-hundredth anniversary of Mozart's birth.
ALBANY, Jan. 26--The State Motor Vehicle Bureau came out today in favor of permanent license plates with staggered renewal dates.
THERE is still time to get in a few week-ends in pursuit of the snowshoe rabbit, and reports from the Catskills and the Adirondacks indicate that these big white bunnies are plentiful.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-- The Soviet Union has agreed to attend a twelve-nation conference here Feb. 27 on a world agency to promote the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

MOSCOW, Jan. 26--Maxim Z. Saburov, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, said tonight that the working day in the Soviet Union would be reduced from eight to seven hours under the new fiveyear plan. At the same time he said output per man-hour would be increased "at least 50 per cent."
An "imaginative and sustained" effort must be made by the United States to maintain its technological superiority over Russia, Brig. Gen. Carlton S. Dargusch declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The National Science Foundation warned Congress today that the promotion of science was an urgent problem.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 26-- The new president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad tonight became involved, unwittingly, in a controversy with his official family.
PARIS, Jan. 26--Two arches of an unused viaduct were turned into "apartments" for two large and destitute families early this morning.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP)--Hog prices jumped an average of 50 to 75 cents a hundred pounds today in the fourth straight day of sharp advance.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 26--A roar of approval from 12,000 throats echoed off the sheer walls of the Dolomites as President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy opened the seventh Olympic Winter Games today.

The United States Army is stronger now than ever before in peacetime, Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, its Chief of Staff, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--A Senate committee opened an inquiry today into major television problems, but one Senator predicted at the start they might never be solved.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The State Department announced today that it would ask Congress for authority to abandon special rights that the United States had exercised in Morocco for 168 years.

Wednesday gains disappeared in Thursday trading on the New York Stock Exchange as volume continued to fall. Turnover yesterday was only 1,840,000 shares, the smallest since Nov. 2, compared with 1,950,000 on Wednesday.

There is a simplicity in some saintly men that confounds the world. In 1954, when Paris nights were grievously cold for shanty-dwellers, a gaunt figure in a frayed black cape, beret and a crook-handled cane sped through the city's streets in a tiny green Renault.
The Board of Estimate put muscle yesterday into Mayor Wagner's program for strengthening the city's crime-fighting forces.

TRENTON, Jan. 26--Senate President Wayne Dumont Jr., a Republican, was sworn in today as Acting Governor of New Jersey. A leading political rival of Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, he will serve while Mr. Meyner is absent from the state.
LONDON, Jan. 26--A voluminous British dossier on alleged Saudi Arabian moves against Western interests in the Middle East has been shown to the United States Government officials in Washington.
The Government's release of surplus foods to the needy overseas has done more than anything else to win friendship for the United States, Cardinal Spellman declared yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 26--Sir Bernard Docker, one of Britain's best known industrialists, began today a national campaign for a 1 per cent cut in national and local government spending.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wilfred Watts of 277 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Watts' daughter, Miss Susan Strite Chapman, to Albert Palmer Loening Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Loening of 1 East Sixty-sixth Street and Lallinden, Southampton, L.I.

SALZBURG, Austria, Jan. 26 --A Salzburg still suffering financially from the departure last year of the United States Army, its biggest employer, is being helped to close the economic gap by one of its oldest and youngest citizens--Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

LONDON, Jan. 26--Demand for industrial shares dwindled today, and prices moved irregularly. Government loans erased small losses before the close. The War Loan closed unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-- Clarence A. Davis, Under Secretary of the Interior, told Congress today that he alone had been responsible for awarding the controversial Al Sarena mining claims.
MIAMI, Jan. 26 (UP)--Willie Hartack put on another fine riding exhibition today at Hialeah by riding three winners, including the Calumet Farm's Tollesboro in the Gold Coast Purse.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 26-- State Senator E. Frank Branon of Fairfield resigned from President Eisenhower's Agricultural Advisory Commission today over what he termed "matters of policy and politics."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26 --Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer appears to be getting nowhere fast in selecting prospective starring roles for Ava Gardner.

LONDON, Jan. 26--A spokesman for the Foreign Office said today that it was not aware of any facts that would substantiate the allegation that the British were making a major contribution to the Communist Chinese war economy.
ALBANY, Jan. 26 (AP)--There were unmistakable signs today of a thaw in a cold--and sticky-- war over the maple tree that has embroiled three or four states and spilled into Canada.
The Monsanto Chemical Company and its consolidated subsidiaries last year had a net income of $42,169,970, according to the unaudited figures issued yesterday.

Federal and state officials pleaded with the city yesterday to fluoridate its drinking water to combat dental diseases.
ALBANY, Jan. 26--Local governments could get state aid to help pay public defenders in juvenile delinquency cases under a bill introduced in the Legislature today.

The Transit Authority has begun letting contracts for a $3,750,000 fluorescent-lighting program in the I.R.T. and B.M.T. subway stations. The conversions would not cover the entire systems, but would embrace most major transfer points.

A reorganization of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City is being considered. The move is hopefully designed to bring coordination, religious harmony and solvency to the central agency for the city's sprawling health and welfare services.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Army ended today a double standard that was impairing discipline and damaging troop morale in the six-month Reserve Training Program.
A "poor man's radar" to help pilots avoid thunderstorms was described yesterday at the meeting of the American Meteorological Society.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26-- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize a fiveyear 250,000,000 Federal program to expand construction of medical research and teaching facilities.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation raised its dividend to $2.50 a share yesterday after reporting that earnings, billings and production set records in 1955.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26--Wheat futures, especially the new crop deliveries, were strong today on the Board of Trade, but as usual upturns encountered liberal selling and there was hesitancy in following the rallies.

Representative Jack Westland of Washington, the 1952 national amateur golf champion, accepted on behalf of President Eisenhower the Ben Hogan Trophy at the annual dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association last night.
TORONTO, Jan. 26--A strong growth of manufacturing and a sharp increase in urban development in Ontario were forecast by Premier Leslie Frost today.

DETROIT, Jan. 26 (UP)--The Detroit Red Wings took sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League tonight, defeating the New York Rangers,' 3--2 before a sell-out crowd of 13,860 at Olympia. The Rangers had been tied for second.

ROME, Jan. 26--No festival or other official celebration of Mozart's bicentennial will be held in Italy. The New York State Bar Association has appointed a fifteenmember committee to study the state's antitrust laws and recommend more effective enforcement methods.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP)-- One of the worst rainstorms in Southern California history slackened tonight. The rainfall reached 7.24 inches here.

Directors of United Air Lines, Inc., yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 37 cents a share, payable March 15. In previous quarters the airline paid 25 cents. It distributed a year-end extra of 50 cents in December.
Two top industrial leaders disclosed yesterday that they would step down from their posts in April.

GALESBURG, Ill., Jan. 26-- Scientists have discovered--and they value the discovery--that chemicals can be used to make rabbits circle endlessly like toy locomotives. They can be made to go clockwise or counterclockwise.

Reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System continued under pressure through the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point up to 9 points off yesterday.

Workmen began yesterday the task of pumping 2,500,000 gallons of muddy water out of the flooded section of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

THE world has always been filled with wonders, but their nature changes. Once upon a time all sensible persons knew that there were werewolves in the forest, fairies in the garden and mermaids in the sea. With the spread of scientific knowledge such marvels have become rare, although sober citizens still catch glimpses of a mysterious monster in Loch Ness.
