A new farm revolution appears to be brewing in the Soviet Union. Its organizer appears to be Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party chief, who was defeated five years ago in his effort to transform the collective farmer into a rural counterpart of the factary worker.
THE United Nations received a formal request from the British for General Assembly consideration of the Pales tine problem on April 2, 1947. The British
Walter (Smokey) Alston, the man who guided the Brooklyn Dodgers to their first world series triumph last year, dominated the baseball news yesterday.

CORTINA D'AIVIPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 30 (UP)--Italian four-man bobsled crews strengthened their bid for another Olympic gold medal today aboard sleds that the United States team coach said looked "well-nigh unbeatable."

TAKE one child, bored, nervous or worried. Place in a room without benefit of television set. Surround with books, including some from mother's childhood, if possible. Allow excessive sun-- or rain--to beat down outside.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) --Senator A.S. Mike Monroney said today Sinclair Weeks had a "disgraceful record of vetoing every progressive thing that we have tried to do for aviation."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 30 (AP)--A fight between white and Negro spectators during a concert here late tonight sent six persons to hospitals with injuries. Nine others were arrested on disorderly conduct charges.
Several dozen patrolmen who are studying to be detectives will be assigned to ferret out more than 19,000 New York scofflaws.
NEWARK, Jan. 30--About 225 chilled, rain-soaked stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) braved an icy downpour here today to hear some warming news.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Supreme Court ruled today that butchers could not be required to sharpen their knives on their own time when sharp knives were indispensable to their productive activity.

"Uncle Vanya" will be presented at 7:30 tonight at the Fourth Street Theatre, 83 East Fourth Street, near Second Avenue. Franchot Tone, Signe Hasso and George Voskovec are costarred in a company that includes Clarence Derwent and Peggy McCay.

LONDON, Jan. 30--The Birtish Government announced today it was preparing to jam Athens radio broadcasts to Cyprus. It said it sought to preserve Cypriote and British lives from "outrages directly provoked" by the hostile transmissions.
MIAMI, Jan. 30 (AP)--Hilarious, owned by W.L. Huntley of Miami, ran six furlongs in the excellent time of 1:101/5 to capture the $10,000 Sunshine State Purse before 20,064 fans at Hialeah Park today.

GUATEMALA, Jan. 30--Construction of buildings to house workers in the great Mayan dead city of Tikal has begun. This is the first work stage in the joint restoration effort by the Guatemalan Government and the University of Pennsylvania to bring back to life a city dead for eleven centuries.
CAIRO, Jan. 30--The Egyptian-Iraqi feud grew more tense today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP)-- The Senate Democratic whip, Earle C. Clements, announced today that he would vote against the natural gas bill.

Two fires in New York during the past few 'days have given grim warning of the dangers of delay in turning in alarms. On Saturday afternoon some deep-fry fat boiled over in one of the kitchens of the Waldorf-Astoria. Employes tried for half an hour to put out the fire it started.

Rubber futures tumbled yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York on the largest trading volume of the year. Prices dropped to new lows for the move. The near-by months were weakest and the market closed near the lows of the day.
THE Florida and Bahamas fishing seems to be reaching a peak, for reports from both areas covering the past few days indicate action offshore and on rivers and bays.
Record operating income and profits were recorded by the International Business Machines Corporation in 1955.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30--A drive to put twice as much animal protein on the Soviet dinner table by 1960 is encountering serious difficulties. The drive has been described as "the most important task of the national economy."
The San Francisco Dons led the United Press college basketball ratings yesterday for the ninth straight week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UP) --Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, said today there must be a "realistic partnership" for sound development of the nation's natural resources.

PARIS, Jan. 30--Guy Mollet, Socialist Premier-designate of France, will go before the National Assembly tomorrow to try to win a majority for the left-of-center government and the program he has proopsed.
Lewis Conger, a store that has sold quality housewares to New York shoppers since Civil War times, may have a new home next summer.
TRENTON, Jan. 30--President Eisenhower's name will be entered in the New Jersey preferential Presidential primary. It will appear on the Republican ballot at the April 17 election.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Governor Harriman will ask the Legislature for a $2,100,000 increase in programs aimed at juvenile delinquency.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Jan. 30 --William Holden's independent film production unit, Toluca Productions, has acquired television rights to a radio series, "English Coronets,". for its initial project in the TV field.

Proof of the existence of the anti-proton, the electrically negative counterpart of the positive proton, was outlined here yesterday. It is one of the two fundamental constituents of the nuclei of all atoms.
Nutritionally, dogs eat better than many of their masters, a retired frozen food specialist declared yesterday.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP)--The United States hockey team ran up a 7-0 lead today against Germany in the opening game of the Winter Olympics championship round, then relaxed to conserve its strength for a "must" game with favored Canada tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP)--The Penn-Texas Corporation filed suit today to block a trade of stock that would give Fairbanks, Morse Co. control of the Canadian Locomotive Company, Ltd.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Republican legislative leaders offered today their plan for a $50,000,000 reduction in the state personal income tax.
Massachusetts Investors Trust had record assets of $957,467,354 as of Dec. 31, 1955, according to the annual report issued yesterday. This compared with $791,073,860 a year earlier.
DETROIT, Jan. 30 (AP)--Effects of recent lay-offs in the auto industry are beginning to show up in production volume.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 30 --The Magnavox Company has agreed to buy "certain assets" of the Sparton Radio-Television division of the Sparks-Withington Company, and expansion of the Magnavox plant in Greenville, Tenn., is expected.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 30-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told his countrymen today that they had slipped from the path that Mohandas K. Gandhi had tried to mark out for them.
Another office building is planned for the midtown Manhattan area.

TRENTON, Jan. 30--The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has engaged a firm of consulting engineers to plot an alignment for the extension of that artery from its present terminus at Ridgefield Park to the New York State line. There it would be linked to the New York State Thruway.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 30--A three-man committee of tellers split 2 to 1 today with the majority ruling that stockholders of the A. M. Byers Company had rejected a proposal to remove the present management.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 30-- West German leaders said today that the exchange of letters between President Eisenhower and Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, might provide an opportunity for reopening the question of Germany's reunification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) --Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, announced today his concern had borrowed $100,000,000 to increase its own lending. He called the action a vote of confidence in the economic outlook.

A BLANKET of silence will be wrapped around the Polo Grounds this autumn. No longer will Coogan's B1uff echo to the boom of punts or the crunching of bodies. For the first time in more than forty years there will be no football at that historic site. The New York Giants, gridiron variety, have moved their blocks and tackles across the iver to the Yankee Stadium.
Trading in Ford stock continues pretty much in low gear as Wall Street awaits the next crossroad in the big marketing transactions.

Two additional airlines will start serving the New York area next month. Delta Air Lines, starting tomorrow, and Braniff International Airways, beginning Feb. 15, will fly between Newark Airport and cities in the South and Southwest.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Jan. 30 (UP)--Four persons were rescued today fro man L-20 National Guard plane. It had crash landed in zero weather three days ago.
The Police Department has assigned two patrolmen instead of one to all radio cars of the city's traffic task force.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 30Formation of a militant committee to save railroad commuters in Westchester County from a "quite deplorable situation" was asked today by James M. Landis, new Supervisor of Harrison and former head of New Deal agencies in Washington.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Governor Harriman called upon the Legislature tonight for the immediate passage of a $2,000,000 appropriation for emergency relief from the ravages of last year's floods.
Dr. Charles Burchell Phillips of Orange, Va., got the thrill of his life yesterday when he learned his son, Alfred, raced 100 yards in 9.8 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30-- Eight soldiers from Fort Dix asked the Supreme Court today to halt Army proceedings that could result in their dishonorable discharge before their appeal for an injunction could be argued in lower courts.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 30--The funeral of H.L. Mencken, author, editor and critic, who died in his sleep at his home here yesterday, will be held tomorrow at 1 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A Federal statute insuring that contracts between new car dealers and automotive manufacturers could be enforced in court was called for today by Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a case involving a long strike at the Kohler Company, Kohler, Wis.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The United States' investment in atomic energy has climbed to $14,298,300,000.
The New York City Housing Authority has designated Feb. 15 for the sale of $64,113,000 of short-term notes to help finance twelve low-rent projects.

As a whole, the stock market showed virtually no change yesterday, closing in the neighborhood of its lows. A few steels, aircrafts, rails, coppers, oils and utilities made gains, but profits were reduced at the close.
President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden began yesterday a series of talks that might have a profound influence on the strategic situation in the Middle East.
A visitor from another planet or another century might be happily astonished by the activities projected this year by various agencies of the United Nations in the field of technical assistance.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30--Hope of ending the Australian dock strike now centers on a meeting in Sydney tomorrow of the interstate executive of the Australian Council of Trades Unions.

The New York Shipping Association has unanimously voted to establish a new port-wide policy on truck deliveries and pickups. Cargo will be received from or delivered to trucks in line at piers on weekdays, if the truckers' papers have been filed with a receiving or delivery clerk by 4 P.M.
Robert M. Weitman resigned yesterday as vice president in charge of programming and talent for the American Broadcasting Company.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 30--A 50 per cent increase intrade between West Germany and Czechoslovakia has been agreed upon. A pact calling for the exchange of the equivalent of $74,000,000 worth of goods in 1956 is to be announced officially tomorrow.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30 (UP)--John Landy and Dave Stephens, the two gunners who will carry most of Australia's hopes in the 1956 Olympic Games at Melbourne, scored easy victories today at the Victoria State track championships.

TOKYO, Jan. 30--Premier Ichiro Hatoyama told the Japanese Diet (Parliament) today that cooperation with the United States and other democracies would continue to be the keynote of Japan's foreign policy.
PARIS, Jan. 30--Although today's collections by Jean Patou and Jacques Heim showed no new trends, they displayed a feminine, wearable look.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Ambassador Abba Eban of Israel appealed to President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden today to "rise to the level of their inescapable moral duty" by making it possible for Israel to buy arms.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The seizure of dietetic candies allegedly misleading in labeling on salt and sugar content was reported today by the Food and Drug Administration.
LONDON, Jan. 30--The British ship Theron arrived at a base site in Antarctica today. The ship reached the continent after a four-week battle against Antarctic ice.
Mayor Wagner made a television appeal last night to New Yorkers to help him get the bulk of the $42,900,000 in state aid he has requested from Albany.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 30 --Dag Hammarskjold heard a plea today from Pakistani officials for his "cooperation" in persuading India to agree to an early plebiscite in Kashmir.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Jan. 30 (AP)--A seventy-fourth birthday anniversary wreath from President Eisenhow was laid today on the grave of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the presence of Mrs. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30--Curves at ninety miles an hour and closed circuit television marked the first run today of the Rock Island Railroad's new lightweight streamliner, the Jet Rocket.

THE Metropolitan Opera began its twelfth week last night with an opera that generally crops up far earlier in the season. It was one of the "bread and butter" items of many an opera company, including the Metropolitan, Puccini's "La Boheme."

The International Longshoremen's Association gave its tentative approval yesterday to various general ethical sections of a proposed code of waterfront "fair dealing."
Koppers Co., Inc., announced yesterday plans for the public marketing of a new issue of 300,000 shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Government filed today a $2,000,000 suit to recover windfall profits on the Linwood Park housing project at Fort Lee, N.J.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 30--An old New York tie kept Adlai E. Stevenson today from sewing up solidly Arizona's thirty-two delegates-to the Democratic National Convention. The delegates will have sixteen votes.

Colonial Williamsburg, the Rockefeller-restored capital of the Virginia Colony, has acquired a pair of rare portrait miniatures of George and Martha Washington. The miniatures were discovered only recently in Paris.

The thriving young frozen food industry, now holding its tenth annual convention here, boasts not only tremendous sales increases but also a diversity of new products. Some of these items are displayed in an exhibit (not open to the public) of frozen foods at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.
Scientists are ready to apply automation to management of the home of the future. But they cannot decide whether the master switch will be marked "his" or "hers."

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Werner of Oshawa, Ont., on Jan. 12 in the Terrace Heights Hospital, Holliswood, Queens. Mrs. Werner is the former Miss Florence Joseph, daughter of Sol Joseph of Cedarhurst, L.I., and the late Mrs. Joseph.

A new insecticide, designed to aid the housewife in her battle against insects, is available, among other stores, at the Whelan Drug Store, Broadway at Thirty-third Street. Called RealKill, it is made by, the Cook Chemical Company, and is odorless and stainless.

PARIS, Jan. 31--Organized religion has been pretty effectively squashed in the Soviet Union. Churches, mosques and synagogues still function, but their number steadily diminishes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --A Silver Spring, Md., woman was convicted of contempt today for refusing to tell a House subcommittee on Un-American Activities whether she ever worked for the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--A former Government economist charged today that there was a "basic inconsistency" between the economic assumptions behind President Eisenhower's budget and those behind his Economic Report.

Jack Coffey, the Fordham graduate manager of athletics who has memorized 3,000 birthdays of friends, had his 68th birthday remembered yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at Toots Shor's restaurant. Joe E. Brown, the entertainer, was the toastmaster.
Bache Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have announced the admission of Edward B. Conway, Harry A. Jacobs Jr., Julius Balogh and John M. Goldsmith as general partners.

THE well-earned moments mothers have away from home usually demand a little thought and planning. For those who would like to spend part of this time in parent-education programs, here are a few to be held soon.

IF had heeded the desire of my family, I would have made plans to leave the White House at the end of my first term. I took no steps and made no moves at any time to discourage anyone from seeking nomination to succeed me.

While the nation's top track and field athletes are sharpening spikes for Saturday's Millrose Games, the local collegians will be grimly engaged in one of their own big competitive tests of the indoor campaign. That's the fourteenth annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate championships.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (Reuters) --The British Government today awarded a medal to a Northern Irish policeman. The George Medal was given to Sgt. William Morrow who, although sustaining seven bullet wounds, fought off a raid by a party of Irish Republicans.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Jan. 31--The sale of United States Treasury bonds and stamps-- now banned in the Horace Mann School here--probably will be resumed soon following a directive issued today by the president of the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--A commission of ten specialists reported today that every organization bigger than a "neighborhood crochet club" has something to promote in the public schools.
BOSTON, Jan. 31--Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Jost J. Michelson of Boston and Annisquam of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Michelson, to Donald Tufts.
Dr. Fredric Wertham charged yesterday that the New York City Youth Board was a "confused and confusing agency."

WAKE FOREST, N.C., Jan. 31 (UP)--Taylor Sanford resigned suddenly today as coach of Wake Forest, the National Collegiate champion baseball team, because "I was given no assurance by anyone that I will have a job after June 30."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 31 (AP)--Ten persons, including a New York stockbroker and three other Americans, were killed when a private plane crashed Saturday near the Caribbean coast, Venezuelan authorities announced today.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 31-- Juscelino Kubitschek became President of the United States of Brazil today.
BASKETBALL burlesque does not have the fundamental appeal that is found in the theatre. In fact, it can be a dreadful bore--the basketball burlesque, that is.
Frozen meat distributors were urged yesterday to keep their mark-ups at a level that will not discourage storekeepers from handling their products and consumers from buying them.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will spend $8,000,000 this year on research to support its Orlon acrylic fiber. The company says 60 per cent of the sweaters produced in the United States are made of Orlon.

Four major producers raised their prices of bulk shortening and edible oils 1 cent a pound yesterday. They are the Procter Gamble Company, Durkee Famous Foods, Division of the Glidden Company, Swift Co., and The Best Foods, Inc.

The appointment of John H. Pierpont as public relations director for the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, a new position, was announced yesterday by Clarence G. Michalis, board chairman of the Seamen's Bank for Savings and president of the association. Mr. Pierpont formerly served as an executive of Selvage Lee, public relations organization.

MEDIA, Pa., Jan. 31. (AP)--A Pennsylvania Railroad train and an automobile crashed at a grade crossing near neighboring Secane today, killing all five occupants of the car. The dead were identified as Joseph Serafini, 68 years old, of Secane; his daughter, Mrs. Emily P'Ascenvo, of Drexel Hill, Pa.; her two children, Joseph, 5, and Donna 3, and Mrs. Esther Benedetto, 58, also of Drexel Hill.

SHOOTERS will find quite a bit to interest them in the forthcoming Sports, Travel and Vacation Show, which, in addition to a "gun clinic," will offer visitors an opportunity to sharpen their shooting eyes on traps and targets.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 31 (UP)-- A first baseman, Bob Boyd, signed for 1956 today with the Baltimore Orioles. The ex-member of the Chicago White Sox was obtained by the Orioles in the draft this winter. He batted .309 last year with Houston in the Texas League.
DONCASTER, England, Jan. 31 (Reuters)--The Doncaster Rovers beat the Bristol Rovers, 1--0, tonight in a replay of their fourth-round Football Association Cup tie.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--Corn futures moved up sharply on the Board of Trade today, and wheat made smaller gains. Buying incentives were light country offerings and local receipts of corn and reported large sales of both red and hard winter wheat from Chicago for the Gulf.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 21 (AP)--Gov. Paul L. Patterson of Oregon died unexpectedly here tonight. His age was 55.
This year should see more family businesses become public corporations than ever before, according to James J. Minot, partner of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis.

Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks increased $358,000,000 in December. This was the second largest monthly increase in eight years, exceeded only by a gain of $380,000,000 in December, 1954, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

The election of Douglas Agren as president of Industrial Wire Cloth Products Corporation, producer of air cleaners and filtering equipment, and reorganization of the company's board of directors has been announced.

TORONTO, Jan. 31--Canada should reduce its "excessive" taxation on cars because it is "definitely restraining the buying of motor vehicles" and is thus contributing to keeping cost-levels far above those of the United States, the Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects was told today.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Jan. 31--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Heymann of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Myrna Jean Heymann, to Robert Leonard Greenhall. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Greenhall of East Orange. Miss Heymann is a student at Douglass College. Her fiance, who is serving with the Navy, is a graduate of Brown University.

Next Wednesday evening's performance of "No Time for Sergeants" at the Alvin Theatre has been selected for the thirtyseventh annual theatre party of the woman's board of the Church Charity Foundation of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

The Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Herbert von Karajan, will make its second tour of the United States and Canada next fall, it was announced yesterday by Columbia Artists Management.

William Johnson, star of "Pipe Dream," has been chosen as "the most outstanding young male star of the year" by students of the Bernard M. Baruch School of Business and Public Administration at City College. After tonight's performance, the actor will receive a plaque from the president of the student body at the Statler Hotel.
MIAMI, Jan. 31--The Maine Chance Farm filly Royal Lark, a winner at 10 to 1 in her last start, won at Hialeah today at a flossy 58 to 1. Why the long odds?
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was often in the best public interest to withhold information handled by the S.E.C.

Joseph W. Gannon, who has been an executive in the busi ness department of The New York Times since 1927, retired yesterday. During most of his service he has been manager of the advertising acceptability division. He will be succeeded as head of that division by D.V. Redding.
BOMBAY, Jan. 31--United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold arrived in Bombay from Pakistan tonight. He said he valued "very highly" India's contribution to easing world tension.
The Tobacco Industry Research Committee announced yesterday a third allocation of $500,000 to continue its support of a program to investigate the relation between smoking and health.

KITTERY, Me., Jan. 31 (AP)-- Capt. C.S. Sebring, who is retiring Feb. 29 as commander of the Portsmouth (N.H.) Naval Shipyard, has been named director of research and development for Alco Products, Inc.
IT'S a wise audience that knows where to turn for fresh and personal performances of Mozart.

Word has been received here of the birth of a son to Mr. and Mrs. William Lowenthal on Jan. 24 in Santiago, Chile. Mrs. Lowenthal is the former Miss Alice Messenger, daughter of Mrs. Peter. Messenger of Belle Harbor, Queens. The child, who will be named Harry S., is a grandson also of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Chapin Rogers of New York.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (UP)--The University of San Francisco swept to its forty-first straight basketball victory tonight by crushing San Jose State, 67--40.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 31-- South Carolina moved today to join other Southern states in official protest against school integration.
Seven defendants admitted yesterday to Kings County Judge Nathan R. Sobel that they had participated in the killing of a 21-year-old Brooklyn man on July 4 last.

The TelAutograph Corporation, for the first time in its sixty-seven-year history, will sell its telescriber communications systems outright, Jerry S. Frank, general manager of the communications division, announced yesterday. Heretofore the company leased its equipment, which is used for electronic transmission of handwritten messages. Mr. Frank said that lease customers may purchase their equipment if they desire, while new customers have the alternative of purchasing or leasing.

Mayor Wagner bought yesterday the first two tickets for the opening night performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on April 4. All proceeds from the premiere at Madison Square Garden will be contributed to the Police Athletic League.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Public Health Service today released 2,265,912 cubic centimeters of poliomyelitis vaccine, bringing the total amount released to date to 33,245,274 cubic centimeters.
Forty patrol cars, assigned to the Police Traffic Division but not used between midnight and 8 A.M., were added to the general patrol force starting last midnight.
Marcel Marceau, French pantomimist, will begin an engagement tonight at the City Center. Curtain time is 8 o'clock.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 (AP) --The new West German Army will have a special unit for rocket research, military sources said today. It will test rockets and guided missiles for land and air defense. The Unit will include about 600 men and will be stationed on the North Sea coast.
QUEBEC, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press)--A Quebec Government bill to double municipal and school taxes of a "defiant" newsprint manufacturing company has been modified, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. demanded today that Maj. Gen, Eugene M. Caffey be dismissed as Army Judge Advocate because of his remarks before the Georgia State Legislature.

The State of Connecticut yesterday set Feb. 28 as the sale date for a $100,000,000 second issue of serial bonds to further the financing of the 129-mile Connecticut Turnpike now being built to connect Greenwich and Killingly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- Congress was cautioned today that atoms in agriculture might compound the farm surplus problem.

Charges incurred by credit cardholders of the Diners' Club, Inc., for the quarter ended Dec. 31 amounted to $8,961,000, Ralph E. Schneider, its chairman, has announced. This was 57 per cent above the volume of $5,695,000 registered in the corresponding period of 1954. Membership now exceeds 220,000, a record, Mr. Schneider reported.
Tyrone Guthrie will direct the new production of "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera next season, the company announced yesterday. Oliver Smith will design the sets and Rolf Gerard the costumes.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31--Jean Hersholt underwent major surgery today at St. Vincent's Hospital.

An official of the Metropolitan Museum of Art left by plane yesterday for Iraq on an assignment demanding a knowledge of science and art, a talent for diplomacy, a taste for an Oriental cuisine and sleeping in tents.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., achieved new highs last year in total operating revenues and sales of electricity and gas, according to the preliminary annual report released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Following are short sketches of the eight members who served under Robert McKinney on the Panel on the Impact of the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy:
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan, 31--Brooks Dodge of Pinkham Notch, N.H., finished fourth in the men's special slalom at the Winter Olympics today.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--A bill that would give legal support to one of the two factions disputing control of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn was introduced in the Legislature today.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics increased to 89.5 on Monday from 89.3 on Friday. The figure for Jan. 31, 1955, was 92.1.
Former President Truman gives full vent to his bitterness against the American press in the installment of his memoirs that we publish today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Government was urged today to explore the economic feasibility of atomic-powered ships and locomotives to keep pace with national transportation needs.
LONDON, Jan. 31--The nationalized electricity industry was criticized today by a committee appointed by the Government to study it.

PARIS, Wednesday, Feb.1--Guy Mollet, French Socialist leader, became Premier of France's twenty-third postwar Cabinet early today By a vote of 420 to 71, the new National Assembly confirmed M. Mollet as Premier together with a left-of-center Republican Front Cabinet of Socialists and Radicals.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Jan. 31 (AP)--The Saar's Parliament approved by a vote of 84 to 2 tonight a declaration calling for immediate return of this ...
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 31--The Australian Cabinet decided today to make a new effort to end the nation's nine-dayold dock strike.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 31--Finance Minister Fritz Schaeffer renewed today his demand that the United States finance part of West Germany's $9,000,000,000 armament program.
A political neophyte with more knowledge of sporting events than election contests was chosen yesterday to head the reactivated National Citizens for Eisenhower.

Seton Hall University yesterday became the second team to accept a bid to play in this year's National Invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden, March 17-24, according to Walter T. McLaughlin of St. John's, chairman of the selection committee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 31--The 1955-56 wheat crop is officially estimated at 188,600,000 bushels--20,000,000 more than last year. An average yield of 18.3 bushels an acre is forecast, the highest since the 19521953 record of 19.1. The area sown to wheat is estimated at 10,800,000 acres, slightly less than in the three preceding years.
Orson Welles, by breaking his left ankle and spraining the other, has come close to breaking the treasury of the New York City Center of Music and Drama.
Burglars departed hurriedly with loot valued at $41,000 yesterday when Mrs. Nicholas Stavroudis returned to her duplex apartment at 241 East Sixtyfirst Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 31--The Soviet Union challenged today the right of the Nationalist Chinese regime on Taiwan (Formosa) to a seat on the United Nations Peace Observation Commission.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. called officials of another hotel on the carpet yesterday, for tardiness in reporting a fire.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Jan. 31 --Dr. Edward Corbin Jenkins, former president of George Williams College, Chicago, and a lifelong leader in the Young Men's Christian Association, died today after a long illness. He had suffered a series of heart attacks. He was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield urged the Senate Republican Policy Committee today to support postal rate increases that would bring in an extra $406,500,000 a year in postal revenues.
A truck driver who had been indicted for first-degree murder received a suspended sentence yesterday from Kings County Judge George J. Joyce.
Former President Harry S. Truman breezed into New York yesterday with a fistful of fast answers to spice the political stew.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 31 (UP)--The Olympic Winter Games Program for tomorrow, with United States competitors in parentheses and times in Eastern standard:
Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Fund for the Republic, pleaded last night for preservation of "sacrosanct" individual rights as a weapon against communism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Dr. Roderick Murray was promoted today as director of the division of biologics standards of the National Institutes of Health. He has been a member of the staff since 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The chairman of a joint Congressional committee investigating the controversial Al Sarena mining claims charged today that the Interior Department's handling of the case represented "a shabby and shoddy way for Government to operate."

The traffic pattern of the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel will be altered today to speed travel into the city. The twin tubes normally carry balanced traffic, with two lanes in each direction, but now will handle three lanes westbound and a ...
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Congress received today a detailed and comprehensive blueprint for the nation's peacetime atomic future.

NEWTON CENTER, Mass., Jan. 31--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bloomberg of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nathalie Ann Bloomberg, to Kenneth M. Sussman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Sussman of Brooklyn, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, charged today that Senate investigating committees were "running wild" in hiring staff members.

ALBANY, Jan. 31--.The perennial legislative battle over new branches for savings banks was rejoined today. The same branch bank bill that has been shuttling around the legislature for several years but has never quite passed was introduced again--but with a new sponsor who may make a difference.
Paperboard production in the week ended on Saturday was 15.1 per cent above the like week last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 31--By taking a leaf from the politicans' book and holding a $100-a-plate dinner, music-lovers have saved the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra from dissolution.
TOKYO, Jan. 31 (Reuters)-- Fourteen men were killed and five were injured today when an avalanche of snow engulfed a workers dormitory at a sulphur mine in central Japan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Jockey Club, famous thoroughbred racing organization, today lost a fight to escape payment of approximately $167,000 in Federal income taxes.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 31 (AP)--The United Automobile Workers' ratified a three-year contract at Lear, Inc., today, ending a 103-day strike of about 1,800 production workers.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 31 --The University of Alabama has agreed to accept its first Negro student when registration for the next terms opens tomorrow.

NEWARK, Jan. 31--A fiveyear dispute over whether the 119th Fighter-Interceptor Squadron of the New Jersey National Guard should be stationed at Newark Airport will end officially tomorrow when the squadron is transferred to McGuire Air Force Base near Fort Dix.

OTTAWA, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press)--The average weekly pay in Canadian industry reached a record of $62.07 a week on Nov. 1, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. The previous high, on Oct. 1, was 58 cents less.
MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP)--A syndicate today bought the Dickey stables of Ocala, Fla., thoroughbred breeding and training farms owned by William E. and Magdeline Leach, for a reported $700,000.

The rise in shipbuilding order. which got under way late in 1954, continued through last year in the construction centers of the world. This was reported yesterday by Walter L. Green, president of the American Bureau Shipping.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The members of a House of Representatives subcommittee voted today to examine in public hearing "basic discrepancies" in previous. Sworn testimony concerning a $43,000,000 expansion of the Government's $100,000,000 nickel-producing project in Cuba.

George Mandel of Astoria, Queens, won the men's singles final in the New York Tennis Club's indoor invitation tournament at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. Mandel defeated Dick Highley of Montclair, N.J., 3--6. 10--8, 6-2.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad presented an amended plan today to buy the bankrupt Florida East Coast Railway for $51,000,000.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Governor Harriman asked the Legislature today for $200,000 for a state study of the causes of poverty.
Payments from four trust funds to the Community Service Society brought $1,037,30 to the forty-fourth annual Neediest Cases appeal yesterday.
A local law avowedly designed "to stop real estate speculators from making a profit out of human misery" was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Council.

Henry A. Wallace, protesting former President Harry S. Truman's accusation that there were "sinister aspects" in the Progressive party's campaign of 1948, has asserted that all modern parties and governments have been similarly plagued.
OFTEN, if not always, cooked vegetables should have their own importance on the menu. Only monotony can come from serving the same old peas with the same old dab of butter.
Clarence E. Eldridge is leaving his post as executive vice president of the Campbell Soup Company, in charge of its marketing activities, to devote himself to other interests.

The American Tobacco Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of $1 a share. In addition the directors voted to distribute an extra dividend of $1 on the same day. Last March shareholders received a similar extra dividend. The previous quarterly rate on the common stock was 85 cents a share.
A fifteen-foot square section of the pavement at Essex and Rivington Streets collapsed at 9:30 A.M. yesterday and broke a four-inch gas main. The odor of gas permeated the area.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --The House Interior Committee today approved a measure to establish a national park on the Virgin Islands.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Dr. Paul Dudley White, the President's unpredictable heart specialist, is going to sea to record the heartbeat of a whale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP)-- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Pan-American World Airways be authorized to operate between New York and Nassau so long as no Government subsidy was required.
Kenneth P. Steinreich was installed as president of the Yorkville-Mid-Manhattan Chamber of Commerce yesterday in the Jacob Ruppert Brewery, 1639 Third Avenue, by Mayor Wagner.
A net increase of $609,543,410 has raised to a new peak the assessed valuations of real estate and special franchises in New York City.

The first precise measurement of the size of the proton, one of the two basic building blocks of the cores of all atoms, was described here yesterday at the annual New York meeting of the American Physical Society.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 31 (UP)--A Government decree today increased by 46.5 per cent the salaries of 211,000 civil servants, including the members of the armed forces. The percentage represents half the rise in the cost of living in Chile in the last thirteen months.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 31--Adlai E. Stevenson stepped up tonight the tempo of his direct political attacks upon President Eisenhower personally.
The W.S. Wilson Corporation, a mill supply concern, has leased a new one-story building at 3711 Forty-eighth Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, through the Greiner-Maltz Company broker.
LONDON, Jan. 31--A.A. Milne, author, poet and playwright, died today at his home in Sussex at the age of 74.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31--The missile division of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation will be transferred from near-by Van Nuys to Stanford University and Sunnyvale near San Francisco, it was announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31 (UP)-- A twin-engine B-25 Air Force bomber flying from Las Vegas Nev., to Washington ran out fuel and ditched in the swift moving Monongahela River her today. Four of the five Air Force men aboard were rescued. The fifth man was missing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Dr. Willard F. Libby, Atomic Energy Commissioner, painted a grim picture for Congress today of the awesome death and destruction that would follow a nuclear explosion in a United States city.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 31 (Reuters)--West German President Theodor Heuss worked at his desk as usual today. It was his seventy-second birthday. He declined to received wellwishers and asked that no special ceremony should mark the day.
ALBANY, Jan. 31--Two men who may have key roles at the Democratic National Convention are scheduled to confer with Governor Harriman in New York on Thursday.
MOORESTOWN, N.J., Jan. 31--The engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Ann Sue Hallman to Thomas Fraser Pettigrew, son of ...
BUFFALO, Jan. 31 (UP)-- Welles V. Moot, a member of the State Board of Regents since 1947, will retire April 1.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)--George (Buck) Weaver, third baseman for the Chicago White Sox from 1912 until the Black Sox scandal of 1920, died today, apparently of a heart ailment. He was 64 years old.

DUISBURG, Germany, Jan. 31--Leading Ruhr industrialists are prepared to participate in a Western economic program to neutralize or eliminate Soviet economic penetration of the Middle East and South Asia.
Twenty-five states and fourteen major cities reported increases in 1955 in syphilis or gonorrhea or both, three associations disclosed yesterday.

The election of Leroy A. Peterson as a director of the Corn Products Refining Company has been announced by Dr. E.W. Reid, president. Mr. Peterson is president of the Otis Elevator Company and chairman of Otis Elevator Company, Ltd., Canada.
PUTNAM, Conn., Jan. 31-- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff laid it on the line again today to another Connecticut community striving to recover from last year's disastrous floods.

Fighting off a fourth-quarter bid by the visitors, the New York Knickerbockers checked the Philadelphia Warriors, 105 to 95, in a National Basketball Association clash at Madison Square Garden last night.

HONG KONG, Jan. 31-- Greater material rewards, more prestige and further "ideological remolding" are in prospect for Communist China's intellectuals under a twelve-year scientific development program now being charted in Peiping.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Two powerful Congressional leaders were received tonight by President Eisenhower and Sir Anthony Eden at the end of the second day of the British-American negotiations.
The Yankees and Giants each came up with an important contract signer yesterday.

Red Cross bloodmobiles today will visit American Airlines at La Guardia Airport, Queens, and Grace Methodist Church, 21 South Franklin Street, Valley Stream, L.I., for a collection arranged by the Christian Council of Churches of Nassau County.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 31-- Juscelino Kubitschek de Cliveira who became President of Brazil today, looks and acts like a modern business executive.
ABOARD U.S.S. ARNEB, in the Ross Sea, Antarctica, Jan. 31 (AP)--A United States trailmaking party deep in Marie Byrd Land will have to quit about 200 miles short of its goal, it was announced today.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 31 --Mrs. Elinor Dana Pearson, widow of William W. Pearson, was married here this afternoon to David Bing Livingston Jr. in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leo I. Dana.

RABAT, French Morocco, Jan. 31--French soldiers and Mobile Guards were a sent into a Moslem area of Casablanca today to restore order. The troops acted after two Europeans had been wounded by a Moroccan mob.
The city's high school teachers issued an attack yesterday on the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools, Dr. William Jansen.

The Grace Line yesterday appointed Joseph S. Blackett as general manager of its terminal on the Hudson River at West Fifteenth Street. Lewis A. Lapham, Grace president, also announced that Hendryk S. Weeks had been named assistant freight traffic manager.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa threatened yesterday to sue the Port of New York Authority if it continued to "break its promises" on modernization of local airports.
OTTAWA, Jan. 31--After taking a new look at the question of recognition of Communist China, the Canadian Government intends to stand pat on its present policy of non-recognition.

Some outstanding performers shone in yesterday's generally firm stock market. Santa Fe jumped 11 7/8 on news of a 5for-1 split. Standard Oil of New Jersey advanced 3 Points. Du Pont rose 3 , Gulf Oil 2 7/8 and Kennecott Copper 2 1/8.
Waiters on American passenger ships average only $2.51 a day in tips. Night stewards fare even worse, receiving an average of about 98 cents a day, while headwaiters receive $3.36 a day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Following is the text of the conclusions and recommendations from the report of the Panel on the Impact of the Peaceful Uses of Atomic Energy to the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.
"PLAYWRIGHTS' 56" offered "This Business of Mur der," a play by David Swift, on Channel 4 last night. Mr. Swift is best known as the creator of the once-popular situation comedy, "Mr. Peepers."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Federal Court of Claims has under consideration a challenge to President Eisenhower's power to dismiss a United States Marshal appointed by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- House Republicans and Democrats voted 387 to 0 today to give farmers $60,000,000 of tax relief by letting them get refunds on excises they paid for gasoline and special fuels to run their equipment.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 31 (AP) --Eugene M. Lokey, a journalist and a former vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, died at his home here today. He was 63 years old.

DID you ever notice with what fervor and nostalgic affection authors write about occupations they have given up? Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Boyling of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Catherine Boyling, to Donato Paul Leo. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Rocco Leo of Flushing, Queens. The couple plan to be married in May.
EACH of the Chekhov productions at the Fourth Street Theatre has been better than its predecessor. "Uncle Vanya," which opened there last evening, continues that pleasant tradition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- John Sherman Cooper, United States Ambassador to New Delhi, urged the Senate today to give more economic aid and sympathy to India.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP)-- Two Senators charged today that big oil companies were applying pressure "fair and foul" in an unusual lobbying campaign for passage of the natural gas bill.

PROGRESS'S chrome-andconcrete heel is poised now over Fourth Avenue's antiquarian book row and the timid dealers in secondhand books, pamphlets, old maps and old prints shudder helplessly in their littered Dickensian dust bins.

Schuyler Fisher, a former vice president of the Irving Trust Company, 1 Wall Street, and a descendant of early settlers of New Amsterdam, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, East Orange, N.J. He was 68 years of age.
The election of Carlton S. Proctor of New York as president of the American Institute of Consulting Engineers has been announced.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 31. (AP)-- Jimmy Beecham of Miami extended his winning streak to thirteen tonight by outpointing Georgie Johnson of Trenton in a ten-rounder tonight.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 31 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leon A. Mnuchin of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Renee Carol Mnuchin, to Alan Safir.
BUCK FALLS, Pa., Jan. 31-- The Rev. Max H. Webster of Burlington, Vt., was elected today president of the Congregational Christian Churches Conferences Snperintendents Association.
The 224th anniversary of the birth of George Washington will be observed by the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York at a dinner on Feb. 22.
The Board of Education and the budget director clashed sharply yesterday over the financing of the pay increase for the city's school teachers starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- President Eisenhower and Sir Anthony Eden surveyed today the possibility of stationing United Nations armed forces on the Arab-Israeli frontiers to prevent an outbreak of open war.
Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway recommended yesterday a fivefor-one split of the company's preferred and common stocks.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--Moscow last night shivered through its coldest night in sixteen years.
ALBANY, Jan, 31--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits disagreed today with Governor Harriman's proposal for enactment of a state atomic energy law this year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- The Government asked negotiators today in the 108-day Westinghouse Electric Corporation strike to transfer their talks from Pittsburgh to Washington, beginning tomorrow.
The Save the Children Federation has elected Faith Baldwin, the novelist, to the board of directors.
Net income of the National Biscuit Company amounted to $18,276,751 in 1955 and $19,911,929 in 1954.

Leon Barzin has been named artistic director of the Symphony Foundation of America. In addition to directing the artistic policies of the Symphony of the Air, he will be one of the orchestra's conductors on its tour of the Near East this fall.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) --Refusing to exact "legal revenge," a judge freed today under suspended sentence a wealthy mother who arranged the abortion that killed her 22year-old married daughter. The couple who performed the illegal operation received prison terms.

The United States Steel Corporation's profits, sales and shipments were larger in 1955 than ever before. The company, biggest steelmaker in this country, achieved a net income of $370,197,625, equal to $6.45 a common share.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31-- Astronomers at the University of Pennsylvania are studying whether the "twinkle" of starlight indicates the speed and direction of certain high-altitude winds.

TRENTON, Jan. 31--Gov. Robert B. Meyner disclosed today his intention of replacing Joseph Weintraub as New Jersey member of the Bi-state Waterfront Commission. The new member is slated to be Assistant Attorney General Harold Kolovsky.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (AP) --Willy Mosconi of Haddon Heights, N.J., beat Jimmy Caras, Upper Darby, Pa., in two 150-point games today to lead, 600 to 455, in an 1,800-point pocket billiard match billed for the world championship. The scores were 150--115 and 150-80.

LONDON, Jan, 31--Stock market business ended the month quietly today with Government loans uncertain and industrial and commodity shares drifting still lower.
Both sides rested yesterday in the Federal Court perjury trial of Paul H. Hughes, 36-year-old Washington private investigator.
NYNASHAMN, Sweden, Jan. 3 (UP)--The police today investigated the possibility of sabotage in the explosion of a tank containing 3,000,000 gallons of oil in Scandinavia's largest oil refinery.
Abe Rosen retained the metropolitan open three-cushion billiards championship by defeating Art Rubin, 40--34, at McGirr's Academy last night.
A possible strike by bakers in the city and on Long Island was averted last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31.-- Walter P. Reuther called today for greater speed in developing peaceful uses of atomic energy to assure United States' leadership in blocking Communist efforts to "forge poverty into power."
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31-- The city has filed six appeals with the State Supreme Court from the decision in which the Orphans' Court here refused to upset a provision in the will of Stephen Girard.

A syndicate headed and represented by Joshuah Sidney Schultz, New York attorney, has leased the thirty-three-story Lewis Tower Building at Fifteenth and Locust Streets in Philadelphia, Pa. Charles S. Glassman and Louis Karsh of New York were the brokers.
Maj. Gen. Robert E. Condon, Director of Civil Defense for New York City, presented awards yesterday to forty members of the Manhattan Post of the Ground Observers Corps.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)--Fairbanks, Morse Co., agreed today to hold up its plans for an exchange of stock with a Canadian concern pending a Federal Court ruling on the transaction.

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals acclaimed last night "great advances" made toward ending congestion in the Federal Courts of the Southern District of New York.
PARIS, Jan. 31--European officials expressed today the firm conviction that the British Government was actively opposing the proposal for a European nuclear pool on a federal basis.

The advertising of Philip Morris Cigarettes is to be shifted on May 1 from Biow-Beirn-Toigo, Inc., to N.W. Ayer Son, Inc. The account is worth close to $10,000,000 in billings.
Paul S. Dopp of Joseph P. Day, Inc., has been elected chairman of the Real Estate Committee of the Young Men's Board of Trade. He succeeds Bert French of Cushman Wakefield, Inc.
The Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that sales of new insurance last year were up 20 per cent to $405,323,379 from $337,639,565 in 1954.

Mayor Wagner has ill-advisedly joined forces with Controller Gerosa in criticism of the Port Authority's airport operations and we are disappointed in him for doing so. A few days ago the Mayor went so far as to say that New York International Airport was a "disgrace."
