LAGOS, Nigeria, Jan. 31-- The most impressive ceremony of the royal tour of Nigeria took place today in the House of Representatives when the House presented a loyal address to Queen Elizabeth.
The New York Athletic Club won the Class A team championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday.
The United States Count of Appeals in the District of Columbia has ordered an indefinite postponement in establishment of a proposed dual-rate system for steamship cargo from Japan.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31--As far as the Soviet people know the United States has not replied to Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's proposal for a twenty-year treaty of friendship and cooperation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --The Post Office Department is trying a new stamp machine that makes change and thanks the customer for his business.
TOKYO, Jan. 31--The Netherlands has accepted a Japanese offer of $10,000,000 to reimburse Dutch citizens for mistreatment and losses at the hands of the Japanese military in World War II.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) Gov. George N. Craig of Indiana said after a White House conference today that he was confident that President Eisenhower's name would be entered in the Indiana primary May 8.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 31 --Down here in the Wyoming Valley there's a top-flight referee named Harry Rudolph, who has taught the tricks of his trade to many youngsters.
The advertising of Philip Morris Cigarettes is to be shifted on May 1 from Biow-Beirn-Toigo, Inc., to N.W. Ayer Son, Inc. The account is worth close to $10,000,000 in billings.
Paul S. Dopp of Joseph P. Day, Inc., has been elected chairman of the Real Estate Committee of the Young Men's Board of Trade. He succeeds Bert French of Cushman Wakefield, Inc.
The Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that sales of new insurance last year were up 20 per cent to $405,323,379 from $337,639,565 in 1954.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 31--The four-man bobsleds tore huge ruts in the Olympic course during trials today, but a red-haired Italian driving a red sled set a course record despite the difficult travelling.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Representative Frank J. Becker, Republican of Lynbrook, L.I., said today that United ...

Mayor Wagner has ill-advisedly joined forces with Controller Gerosa in criticism of the Port Authority's airport operations and we are disappointed in him for doing so. A few days ago the Mayor went so far as to say that New York International Airport was a "disgrace."

J. Irwin Shapire, State Investigation Commissioner, announced yesterday that he would name a special prosecutor to handle any case arising out of an inquiry by his office into allegedly fraudulent land deals by Suffolk County officials.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- Prison terms and heavy fines for bootleggers of new automobiles were recommended today by Senator A.S. (Mike) Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31--Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, admonished the nation's meat marketers today to tighten marketing costs.

Negotiations have been completed by the Jersey Screen and Storm Window Company, Inc., for the addition of 30,000 square feet of space to its present plant on Route 17 at Summit Boulevard in Hackensack, N.J.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Interlake Iron Corporation's sales and revenues reached a new high of more than $100,000,000 last year. Net income was $8,500,000, or about $4.38 a share, compared with $1.61 a share in 1954.
The record-breaking Ford stock offering and a number of large Government-backed bond issues dominated new financing in January.
Albert Sprague Coolidge said yesterday the Library of Congress had invited some one else to fill a post that he was invited to fill two years ago.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 31 (AP)--Following is a list of champions crowned in the seventh Winter Olympics:

PARIS, Jan. 31--Castillo's designs for Jeanne Lanvin and Balmain's collection have several things in common: the bolero and sport jacket, the collarless neckline, finished with drapery lake a cowl collar or other detail; ornamentation with bands of fabric that contrast in color with the garment, and high waistlines.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31 --Walter A. Tibbals has been appointed a vice president of Four Star Films, Inc., William Cruikshank, president of the television film company, announced today.
PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 1-- Mild in manner and speech to the point of timidity, Guy Mollet, France's new Premier, is nevertheless a hard-headed fighter when he has to be.
BUFFALO, Jan. 31 (AP)--Joey Giambra, a middleweight contender, underwent surgery today for the removal of cyst under his left arm.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Senate Banking Committee today scheduled a one-day open hearing for next week before completing action on its bill to control bank holding companies.

Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers in the recent sale of the Jefferson Hotel in St. Louis, Mo. The property was acquired by the Sheraton Corporation of America from the Hilton Hotels Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (UP)--Master Sgt. Paul Woyshner, 61 years old, ended a forty-year career in the Marine Corps today.
Sales and earnings of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in 1955 were the highest in its history, Morse G. Dial, president, said yesterday in a preliminary report.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31--The American Library Association began a five-day annual meeting in the Edgewater Beach Hotel today. About 1,400 librarians from all sections of the country are attending.
The 722 members of the syndicate underwriting the Ford stock offering were released yesterday from major obligations. They are now free to trade Ford stock at any price in the open market.
MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP)--The Valiant, an eighty-foot yawl from Texas, led a fleet of twenty-four tonight in the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)--Most of the nation's railroad yardmasters will get a $43 monthly pay increase under a settlement announced today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala, Jan. 31 (UP)--Two pro-segregation groups today offered rewards totaling $1,000 for information leading to the conviction of those responsible for the bombing last night of the home of a Negro who had led his race's boycott of city buses.

Potato balls no longer are the only potatoes in tins. Lord-Mott of Baltimore, now in its second century of packing food and the first to can French-style green beans, is introducing sliced white potatoes in eight-ounce and onepound containers. Indistinguishable in flavor from the fresh vegetable, these potatoes may be buttered, sauteed, escalloped, etc.

News from Tokyo indicates that Japan has not been deceived by the blandishments of the Soviet Union. Both the Premier and the Foreign Minister have stated to the Diet that there can be no deviation from Japan's close association with the United States.

Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador to Italy, left Idlewild Airport yesterday for London, ending a four-week visit during which she consulted with the State Department and also helped arrange for the visit on Feb. 27 of Italian President Giovanni Gronchi to the United States. She will spend one day in London.

The emergence of the Ford Foundation as the philanthropic giant of all time has focused fresh attention on the function of foundations in a free society. Its size alone has vastly increased the stakes in foundation operations--for public good or evil.

The appointment of Leonor F. Loree 2d as a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank has been announced by J. Stewart Baker, president. Mr. Loree, a second vice president since 1951, will continue to be associated with the managerial group handling the bank's business in Pennsylvania and Ohio. He formerly served in the aviation department.
Contracts were signed last night for architectural and engineering services for the $15,000,000 national church center to be constructed on Morningside Heights.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 31--Norwegian Navy patrol boats opened fire today on Soviet fishing trawlers that invaded territorial waters.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York.
The total of bonds called for redemption before maturity declined sharply in January to $64,682,000 from $134,317,000 in December and $283,775,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--A newspaper man from the old West gave official Washington some efficiency and economy marks to shoot at today. He not only met his deadline on a Government job but turned back a third of his appropriation as well.

PORTERVILLE, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP)--A Navy guided missile that crashed in an orange grove yesterday "went out of control" and then was deliberately directed into the ground by its escort planes, the Navy said today.
CORTINAD' AMPEZZO, Italy, Jan. 31 (UP)--The United States defeated Canada, 4--1, in a major upset in the Olympic hockey competition today.
MANIZALES, Colombia, Jan. 31 (UP)--The newspaper La Patria failed to appear today because of censorship regulations.
City officials and leading Roman Catholic clergymen were among those to pay final tribute yesterday to Joseph. V. McKee, one-time acting Mayor and president of the Board of Aldermen.

The fifteen-story and sixteenstory apartment houses at 110 and 118 Riverside Drive, which occupy the blockfront from Eighty-third to Eighty-fourth Streets, have been purchased by M.M. Clairmont in association with Leon Fromer and Simon Bond.
HONG KONG, Jan. 31-- A Chinese Nationalist F-86 Sabre Jet from Taiwan, (Formosa) made an emergency landing in this British colony today.
A nurse in training, a fire captain and a fireman suffered minor injuries in two mishaps that began with the explosion of an oxygen bottle in St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn early yesterday morning.

BEVERLY, Mass., Jan. 31-- A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. George Leonard Brewer of Beverly on Jan. 23 at the Beverly Hospital. Mrs. Brewer is the former Miss Erna B. Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Fisher of Lawrence,...
Three new films open at firstrun theatres today.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 31 (AP)-- President Eisenhower signed a bill today authorizing a $3,000,000 survey to determine the cost and economic feasibility of the Passamaquoddy tidal power project. The survey will be made by the International Joint Commission on United States Canadian Boundary Waters.
A city magistrate sitting in jam-packed Manhattan Traffic Court blasted the Police Department yesterday for handing out summonses "without rhyme or reason."
CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 (AP)-- The Cincinnati Redlegs today traded a left-handed pitcher, Jackie Collum, back to the St. Louis Cardinals for a righthanded pitcher, Brooks Lawrence.

ORLANDO, Fla., Jan, 31 (AP)-- Dr. Walter. C. Coffey, president of the University of Minnesota in 1941-45 and former acting president of Hamline University in St. Paul, was reported in critical condition tonight at Florida Sanitarium and Hospital. His physician said had a heart attack Friday and had been in the hospital since then. Dr. Coffey will be 80 years old tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- President Eisenhower threw his support today to a road-building program involving tax increases on gasoline and other products associated with highway use.
Alice B. Toklas, associate or the late Gertrude Stein, has her own way of doing a prune dessert. The recipe appears in the Florence Crittenton League's cookbook, "Specialty of the House."
ALBANY, Jan. 31--The Unemployment Insurance Advisory Council recommended today that unemployment insurance coverage be extended to all wage earners in the state.

NOME, Alaska, Jan. 31 (AP) --Alaska's National Guard commander died in a Nome hospital last night a few hours after his rescue from a mountainside. His plane had crashed there Friday with four aboard.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points up to 10 points off yesterday.

The American Meter Company yesterday proposed an increase in authorized capital stock from 640,000 to 1,000,000 shares and announced that the directors intended to declare a 10 per cent stock dividend in May if the increase were granted. Stockholders will act on the increase at the annual meeting on April 18.

IGUALA, Mexico, Jan. 31 (AP) --Donald Pullen, a young United States businessman and his Mexican friend were killed yesterday when Mr. Pullen's private plane crashed in an attempted emergency landing near this southwestern Mexican town. Mr. Pullen, 25, was flying from Acapulco to Mexico City with Margarita Escalante de Landaverde. Witnesses said he crashed while trying to land on a highway.

Billy Daniels, night club singer, was booked last night for felonious assault and illegal possession of a pistol. His arrest followed a shooting yesterday morning in an "after hours" club in Harlem, according to the police of the West 135th Street station.
Plans to raise money for further research on multiple sclerosis were discussed at a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza...
YPSILANTI, Mich., Jan, 31 (AP)--The stork overtook an American Airlines passenger plane on a nonstop flight from New York to Chicago today.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 31--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Llewellyn Lithgow Cooper of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Cooper, to Lieut, Peter Gilbert Rich of the Army.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UP) --Senator Estes Kefauver named Frank Reeves, a Negro attorney, today as an assistant chairman of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 31 (Reuters)--Premier Samir elRifai of Jordan said tonight "It is not our policy to join the Baghdad pact."
The Metropolitan Opera will visit seventeen cities on its annual spring tour during April and May.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 25:
CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (UP)--Jim Davis, a left-handed knuckle ball pitcher, and Clyde McCullough, a catcher, signed with the Chicago Cubs today.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits obtained a temporary injunction yesterday preventing Batkin Co. of 30 Broad Street from engaging in further securities dealings in this state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, announced today a 15 per cent cut in the national acreage allotment for the 1956 commercial corn crop to help curb surplus production.
SATURDAY, 11:30 A.M.: A story hour in which four stories will be told is to be held at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, Brooklyn Avenue and Park Place.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)-- The Moscow radio today demanded the return of fourteen fishing boats detained by the Norwegians, and insisted that they were not inside Norwegian territorial waters when they were seized.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 1 (Reu ters)--British security forces in Kenya have killed Mau Mau "general" Gathaka, gravedigger at the sacrificial burying-alive of an elderly British farmer, in October, 1954, a Government spokesman announced today. The spokesman also disclosed that the terrorist "general" Abasweni and a Mau Mau "colonel" had been captured, and three other terrorists killed.
Juvenile delinquency here still is rising, but the rate has slowed, John Warren Hill, Presiding Justice of the Domestic Relations Court, reported yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 1 (AP)--Earl Long, Governor designate, sprang a political sensation today when Louisiana Democratic leaders called off a Feb. 21 second primary and nominated two Long candidates facing run-off rivals.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation lifted its net income in the nine months ended Nov. 30 to $12,692,655 from $3,988,501 for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden revived today an all-but-forgotten document--the Potomac Charter.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1-- Princeton's basketball team scored a 74-40 basketball victory over Rutgers in Dillon Gymnasium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- The House of Representatives unanimously voted an extra $10,000,000 today to provide free or cheap milk for school children during the present school year.
BILOXI, Miss., Feb. 1 (AP)-- The National Cotton Council has selected St. Louis for its 1957 meeting and named Francis J. Beatty of Charlotte, N.C., its president for the coming year.
Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, took issue yesterday with the charge that Americans do not get proper nutrition.
LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)-- Sir Michael Balcon, British movie producer, announced yesterday he was ending his association with the J. Arthur Rank organization, Britain's biggest movie-makers.

A son, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Lyle Stuart of 241 Sixth Avenue on Jan. 9 in French Hospital. Mrs. Stuart is the former Miss Mary Louise Strawn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Strawn of Orange Heights, Hawthorne, Fla. The child has been named Rory John.

Fordham Prep's two-mile relay team turned in the fastest time, 8:22.7, to qualify for the event in the first Mayor's AllCity schoolboy track and field meet, which will he held at Madison Square Garden Saturday.

A worker's pneumatic drill pierced an underground cable at Fifty-first Street and Third Avenue yesterday, leaving the Pickvick Arms Hotel and thirty other consumers without electricity for three hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Following is the text of a statement today by Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, commenting on yesterday's report by a citizens panel blueprinting the country's peacetime atomic future:

Fairfax County, Va., announced yesterday that it will receive bids on Feb. 15 on an issue of $4,000,000 of bonds to finance the construction of public schools. Dated March 1, 1956, the bonds will come due serially on March 1 from 1959 to 1983.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Following are the texts of a joint declaraton and communique summarizing this week's conferences between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden:

HAVANA, Feb. 1 (AP)--The Cuban tanker Telco foundered today off the port of Baracoa, but its nine-man crew was rescued. The vessel was carrying a cargo of kerosene to Santiago de Cuba when it sank under the buffeting of strong winds and high seas near Cuba's eastern tip.
A second company of Yugoslav folk dancers will visit North America next season. It is "Kolo," a group of fifty-five dancers, singers and musicians, with headquarters in Belgrade.
The Lee Higginson Corporation, investment banking house seeking larger offices, has leased a floor in the twenty-seven-story office building going up at 20 Broad Street next to the New York ...
Ray Robinson, the world middleweight champion, agreed yesterday to defend his title on April 27 against Carl (Bobo) Olson.
Everett D. Benson, a 21-yearold automobile mechanic, was sentenced yesterday to a ten to twenty years in prison by Kings...

WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 1--Mrs. Elisabeth Egan Sears of 6 Rockledge Road, Hartsdale, a former newspaper writer and magazine editor, died of a heart ailment last night in White Plains Hospital. Her age was 85. She was the widow of Frank Sears, a cattle man in the Middle West.
Federal Judge William B. Her lands was elected yesterday as chairman of the advisory board of the Counselor to Jewish Students at Columbia University. He succeeds Abraham M. Davis, New York lawyer.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1 (UP)--John Landy, the world mile record holder, streaked 880 yards tonight in 1 minute 53 seconds as part of a relay race at the Geelong athletic carnival.

Rush-hour subway travelers to Brooklyn were delayed up to nineteen minutes yesterday evening. Motor trouble on a B.M.T. Brighton local caused the delay, which was most serious at three east side Manhattan stations.
Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, put his finger on a problem that has been worrying the aircraft industry in a speech in the Senate yesterday afternoon.

Six characters from the novels of Charles Dickens came to life yesterday to wish Mrs. Mabel Morris a happy seventyfifth birthday. They were introduced by an 82-year-old man portraying the English author.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 2-- The Soviet and Australian Antarctic expeditions were reported today to have established direct contact and to have begun exchanging meteorological information. The contact was made on the initiative of Mikhail M. Somov, head of the Soviet expedition.

Gurney's Inn, an oceanfront hotel and restaurant on the Old Montauk Highway in Montauk, L.I., has been purchased by Nick Monte, Brooklyn restaurateur. The seller was Mrs. Maude Gurney, who has operated the property since 1926. The Osborne Agency of East Hampton was the broker in the deal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The United States moved today told accelerate its guided missile program in what was described in the Senate as a "terrible race" with the Russians for primacy in this ultimate weapon.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb.1. (AP) --President Eisenhower and Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, winners of the New Hampshire Presidential primary in 1952, will have no competition in this year's contest on March l3.
UNFORTUNATELY, there are no laws by which Marcel Marceau can be confined to New York permanently. In view of the foolish laws already on the books, this is a grave oversight.

A girl on a white horse, dressed as a crusading knight, appeared on Wall Street yesterday to open the annual appeal of the New York Heart Fund. Volunteer canvassers gathered on the steps of Federal Hall Memorial at Nassau Street to await her "orders."
Hot coffee is the bracer for a cold day. It may be a cup of the ordinary brew or one of those exotic concoctions prepared in coffee houses around town.
LONDON, Feb. 1--Start of a new bookkeeping account brought slightly firmer prices but no increase in business to the stock markets here today.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (AP)--A new $3,500,000 passenger terminal was in operation at Hopkins Airport today. The terminal marks the latest phase of a $22,000,000 development program at the airport. It will be dedicated officially Apri1 28.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party chief, has further increased his power through the latest shift in the Interior Ministry, diplomatic observers here said today.
Jerome Seder, president of Frank Seder, Pittsburgh department store, will take an extended leave of absence as its directing head, it was announced ...
HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. 1--A proposal to build here a 15,000kilowatt nuclear power plant to supplement the city's conventional power supply system has been made public.
The Delta Tank Manufacturing Company reported yesterday that it had built and shipped as a single unit one of the largest fractionating columns in the world.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wolff of 911 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Wolff, to Stephen Charles Gross, son of Israel T. Gross of Huntington, W. Va., and the late Mrs. Gross.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UP) --Jack Meyer, a right-handed relief pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies in his rookie season last year, signed his 1956 contract today.
The Rev. Neil Boyton, educator and author of books for boys, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at Loyola Seminary and College, Shrub Oak, N.Y. His age was 71.
Proposals to bar discussion of United States policy in the Middle East during the Presidential campaign were denounced last night by Zionist leaders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- The notion that wars could be fought and won by remote control with machines and push buttons was called "a dangerous myth" today.
BOULDER, Colo., Feb. 1 (UP) --Will Walls, who caught Sammy Baugh's passes at Texas Christian, was named assistant football coach at the University of Colorado today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 1-- Four of South Vietnam's many political parties joined ranks today and asked President Ngo Dinh Diem to modify a Government ordinance on electoral rules and a National Assembly. The law provides for elections on March 4.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--A finding that Chicago's motion-picture censorship ordinance is unconstitutional was submitted yesterday to Judge Joseph Sam Perry of Federal District Court by David J. Shipman, Master in Chancery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today he was seriously considering a rapid build-up of the Ready Reserve by reducing the two-year service of some draftees to eighteen months.
Devereux Milburn Jr. of Old Westbury, L.I., who has a sixgoal handicap outdoors, has been re-elected chairman of the United States Polo Association, it was revealed yesterday.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 1-- A remarkably improved Army hockey sextet tripped Yale, 2 to 1, at Smith Rink today.
Staten Island Social Service, Inc., elected Arnold V. Schwartz president of its board at the agency's thirty sixth annual meeting last night.
A new organization to help overcome a shortage of technicians in various fields was announced yesterday. It is the Career Training Council.

The Downtown A.C. finished in first place in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B teams race last night. In the final match of the season, Downtown won on its courts, 4--1, from the Yale Club.
"The Innkeepers," a first play by Theodore Apstein, starring Geraldine Page and featuring Darren McGavin, will open at the Golden Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--Following are excerpts from Governor Harriman's 1956-57 Budget Message, submitted to the Legislature today:
GALVESTON, Tex., Feb. 1 (UP)--The Badgett quadruplets celebrated their seventeenth birthday today and said they felt "grown-up" enough to look ahead to a career in singing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Manufacturers' sales last year topped those of 1954 by 13 per cent to reach a record of $317,000,000,000.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 3,162,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, gasoline supplies amounted to 178,947,000 barrels, compared with 175,785,000 a week earlier and 169,612,000 a year ago.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--March wheat was firm today, advancing to a new crop high at $2.13 on covering by shorts and lifting of hedges against export sales from Chicago. But prices for most other futures on the Board of Trade declined.
AUSTIN, Minn., Feb. 1 (AP)-- Secretary Benson told farmers today that a Government program to buy hogs at supported pikes "would hurt you more than it would ever help you."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Two hundred senior officers of West Germany's new armed force have been approved by the citizens' committee. The committee, appointed by Parliament, has the power to veto the appointments of colonels and above. It has to screen ninety-two more candidates to complete the nucleus of the force's leadership.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP) --The chemicals division of Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation today announced a $3,000,000 expansion program to increase its capacity to produce refractory and magnesia products at its Moss Landing, Calif. and Columbiana, Ohio, plants.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The dismissal of Lavrenti P. Beria's successor as Interior Minister is interpreted here as a further step by the Soviet leadership to strengthen loyalty among key officials in preparation for the party congress this month.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--The Harriman Administration asked for power today to reject any unneeded frills at the state's expense in construction of a "dream track" for New York.
Ford stock sagged below its offering level here yesterday. This occurred as, in Detroit, the Ford Motor Company declared the anticipated first dividend of 60 cents a share on the stock
PARIS, Feb. 1--Today Jean Desses revealed his new "dis ciplined line"--or high bust, barely noticeable waist, low neck (even on coats) and floating back movement.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 1--The Union of South Africa ordered the Soviet Union today to close its consulates in Pretoria and Capetown. Discontinuance of many other Soviet agencies that may exist in the country also was ordered.

BRUNSWICK, Germany, Feb. 1 (AP)--Two airmen of Communist East Germany's fledgling air force fled into West Germany near here today. Border police said they were believed to be the first military deserters since the Eastern Government turned its "people's police force" into an army, navy and air force two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- A regulation issued by the Atomic Energy Commission to safeguard atomic secrets turned over to private industry becomes effective tomorrow. The chairman, Lewis L. Strauss, said more than 600 organizations or individuals had obtained "access permits" entitling them to obtain secret data for use in the civilian atomic energy industry.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 1 (AP)--Alexander Vouxinos of the Greek Olympic team suffered chest bruises and a possible broken rib in a skiing spill today while practicing for Friday's downhill race.

Caleb Stone, a mayor figure in arranging multimillion dollar borrowings for the investment of life insurance funds, is no longer the top bond investment executive of the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America.
"Assignment: Children," a film made by Danny Kaye for the United Nation's International Children's Emergency Fund, will be shown at the Brooklyn Museum Wednesday at 2 P.M.

HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 1 (AP)-- While driving to see Grace Kelly last night, Prince Rainier III of Monaco became involved in a traffic collision, he said today. His car "lightly tapped" the car in front, he said.
Prof. I.I. Rabi, Nobel Prizewinning physicist of Columbia University, asserted last night that American esteem for science and scientists was now "lower than it has ever been in this century."

The Grand Street Boys' Foundation has notified the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by letter of its intention to put before the annual meeting on April 18 two proposals that would split the stock and increase the dividend rate.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. opened a comicbook leaflet campaign yesterday to warn New Yorkers against the dangers of kerosene heaters.
KADUNA, Nigeria, Feb. 1 (UP)--Moslem "knights" sporting the medieval armor their ancestors wore to the wars against the Crusaders paid homage to Queen Elizabeth today.

The engagement of Miss Colette Nadine Dressel to Lieut. (j.g.) David William Johnson, U.S.N., of Washington has been announced by her parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Elmer C. Dressel of Erskine Lakes, N.J., and the Bronx, Lieutenant Johnson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Johnson of Brooklyn and Barbados, B.W.I.
Paul Henson Appleby has a profound respect for politics. He calls it "the art of getting things done."
WHAT are the chief characteristics of German music? Sincerity, gravity of theme, purity of sentiment and a masculine vigor tempered by touching sensibility --these are certainly among...
LONDON, Feb. 1--Nikolai A. Mikhailov, a Soviet Minister of Culture, arrived by air tonight for a week's visit to Britan under the auspices of the Soviet Relations Committee of the British Council.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 1--Virginia's Legislature approved today a resolution of interposition challenging the Federal Supreme Court's ruling that outlawed segregated public schools.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Directors of Butler Brothers, mail order house, have voted to distribute shares of the Canal-Randolph Corporation, wholly owned real estate subsidiary, to shareholders of Butler Brothers common stock.
The Rockwell Manufacturing Company, Pittsburgh maker of valves, meters and regulators for liquids and gases, is entering the field of special machinery.

The Norfolk and Western Railway, one of the nation's leading coal carriers, has purchased fifty general purpose Diesel locomotive units. The equipment, representing an investment of $9,300,000, will be used by the system on its Shenandoah division between Roanoke, Va., and Hagerstown, Md.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- Mayors and Senators held a strategy session today to map what several conceded was a final uphill fight against Senate passage of the natural gas bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Atomic Energy Commission said tonight that it was preparing new proposals to provide "still greater assistance to friendly countries in the development and use of peaceful atoms."

Dancing and gaiety on April 6 will benefit the city's ill and injured pets. Those persons who attend the eighth annual Spring Frolic of the Humane Society of New York at the Plaza will help to raise funds for the society's hospital and free clinic for animals.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday to close 13 points (65 cents a bale) higher to 6 points (30 cents a bale) lower than on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- The Government today rejected an Italian concern's low bids to install equipment in two United States power projects on the ground that its workers are Communist-dominated.
TOKYO, Feb. 1--A Japanese report has concluded that the United States is losing the battle of economic aid to Southeast Asia and the Middle East.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 1--The strains of The Star Spangled Banner swelled over the Winter Olympic ice stadium tonight. At long last the United States had won its first event, the men's figure skating, sweeping all three medals.
Although 1955 was the best year in the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's history, "1956 will be equal to it, probably even better," according to Cyrus Eaton, chairman, and Walter J. Tuohy, president.

New York Central Railroad executives will present an optimistic picture of the line's operation in Albany this morning before the New York State, Public Service Commission. The commission called the line in an investigation of the service.

The fourteen-story office and showroom building at 302 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-first Street, has been sold by the Georose Corporation to a buyer in the textile business who plans to use large space there.

Nathaniel B. Barclay has been elected president of the Daystrom Furniture division of Daystrom, Inc. Samuel J. Childs has been elected vice president and general manager of the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation, an operating unit of Daystrom.
DETROIT, Feb. 1 (UP)--The board of directors of the Detroit Football Company appointed a committee today to investigate the "practicability" of buying Briggs Stadium or the Detroit Tigers or both.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1--A United States contribution of $6,000,000 was turned over today to the United Nations Technical Assistance Program. The gift represents the first contribution from Washington on the Government's 1956 pledge of $15,500,000.

Dizzy Gillespie and his band will make a ten-week tour of India, the Near East and the Balkans beginning in April. It will be the first tour abroad by a jazz band to be sponsored by the International Exchange Program of the American National Theatre and Academy.
OTTAWA, Feb. 1 (Canadian Press)--Merger of the Imperial Bank of Canada and Barclay's Bank (Canada) was formally approved today by the Government.

BOSTON, Feb. 1--A son, their second, was born today to Dr. and Mrs. Waldo Lewis Fielding at Allerton Hospital. Mrs. Fielding is the former Miss Suzanne Benjamin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Benjamin of New York. The child will be named Andrew.
MADRID, Feb. 1 (AP)--A letter circulated by university students here today demanded an end of Falange party control over the "thought, expression and corporate life" of Spanish universities.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 1 (UP)--Burglars cracked two safes at the University of New Mexico last night and escaped with about $26,000.

New York State's expenditures will increase $173,600,000 in the coming year while a "special dividend" income tax cut of $40,000,000 is delivered to the voters in the $1,494,700,000 budged submitted to the Legislature yesterday by Governor Harriman.

A drive to raise $275,000 for a new building to house the Professional Children's School, 1860 Broadway, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Norman Smith, president of the board of trustees. The school plans to purchase and remodel a building at 132 West Sixtieth Street, now occupied by Columbia University's School of Optometry.
KARLSRUHE, Germany, Feb. 1(AP)--The West German Supreme Court today rejected a plea to release Dr. Otto John, former intelligence chief, on bail.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 1-- Clarence B. Randall, chief economic adviser to President Eisenhower on foreign economic affairs, arrived here today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Following are excerpts from the text of a speech on the great strength of the Soviet Union delivered in the Senate today by Senator Henry M. Jackon, Democrat of Washington.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Eisenhower again asked Congress today to consider raising the first-class mail rate to 4 cents an ounce.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 1 (UP)--Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of the General Motors Corporation, has contributed $515,000 to match alumni gifts, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said tonight.
ALONG with the prediction that American men are about to emerge from the charcoal gray shadow comes the story of how it all began, as told on Savile Row.
EACH year finds an assortment of new "gadgets" to tempt the shooter, most of them of questionable value.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP)--Gover nor Harriman wants to bolster the staff of his tax collection bureau to continue cracking down on tax evaders and chiselers. The Governor's budget included an appropriation of $1,800,000 to provide for about 550 new staff positions in the bureau.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 1-- Archbishop Makarios ended today his series of consultations with other Greek Cypriote leaders on the British proposals for the political future of Cyprus.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The United States and Britain moved slowly but definitely today toward increased world trade with Communist China.

Duquesne Light company reported yesterday that fourth quarter business activity in the Pittsburgh area was marked "not only by near peak industrial production but also by a high level of trade at wholesale and retail levels."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --The Federal Reserve Board said today that the public increased its debt for consumer goods and loans during December by over one billion dollars.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 1--A link between the New York State Thruway and New Jersey's toll road system was assured here today with the signing of an agreement between
SINGAPORE, Feb. 1 (UP)-- Communist terrorists killed two men and wounded three others today in an ambush in the Geyland Patah area of Johore.
New York City's Boy Scouts received yesterday their largest single gift ever--a $1,000,000 resort camp on the outskirt of Holmes, N.Y., eighty miles north of the city.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Feb. 1 --Two hundred employes of Lehn Fink Products Corporation, cosmetic and pharmaceutical manufacturers in Bloomfield Avenue here, struck today after negotiations for a wage increase collapsed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board turned down today a proposal by North American Airlines to start cut-rate trans-Atlantic air coach service.
A proposal to take the relocation of families on subsidized slum clearance sites out of the hands of private developers will be debated at City Hall this morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) --A Congressional hearing produced a hint today that America's atomic scientists might be planning, if not working, on a hydrogen bomb with the wallop of fifty million tons of TNT.
A WOMAN'S clothing around her home seldom approaches perfection.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 1--Theatregoers began to boycott motion picture theatres today in an attempt to force them to restore admission prices in effect prior to the rise initiated two weeks ago. Since the price increase attendance was said to have dropped 50 per cent in many theatres.

Prof. Simon Lissim, a member of the City College's art department, has been elected an hoorary corresponding member of the Royal Society of Arts of England. Professor Lissim has been a fellow of the society since 1950. His work is on permanent display in museums in London, Paris, Vienna, Prague and the Hague and at the Brooklyn Museum.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- Officials of Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers discussed "contract language" today in separate five-hour meetings with Federal mediators.
Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday eased to 11,512,000,000 kolowatthours from 11,521,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
The New York Community Trust yesterday named Second Lieut. John J.C. Herndon Jr. as the winner of the Robert P. Patterson Memorial Award.
Gratifying results were report ed yesterday by the city from warnings handed to twenty-five hotels last November. The warnings gave the hotels two months to comply with fire protection laws.
PEORIA, Ill., Feb. 1 (AP)--Gov. William G. Stratton filed a petition today in opposition to an effort by the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway to purchase the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad.
The new French National Assembly, elected last month, starts with still another weak, unstable Government.

CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 1 (AP) --William F. Judd, an airline pilot, arrived in Cairo today in the single-engine plane in which he flew non-stop from New York to Paris earlier this week. Mr. Judd also flew non-stop to Cairo from Paris "so I'd be on time for work tomorrow morning." A pilot for Trans World Airways, he is scheduled to make a T.W.A. flight back to the French capital tomorrow.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 1--Yugoslavia expects to send observers to the Soviet Communist party congress opening in Moscow Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities sharply rebuked a radio-television union head today for having underrated what it called the "concerted" Communist infiltration of the entertainment industry.

The New York chapter of the American Red Cross announced yesterday the appointment of Norman H. Strauss as public information chairman for its annual fund drive beginning in March. Mr. Strauss, who is president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, will be assisted by Bruce C. Forbes, president of the B.C. Forbes Sons Company, publishers.
BANGALORE, India, Feb. 1 --The economic battle of Asia has shifted for a couple of weeks to this city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--On display at the Library of Congress is a childhood portrait of Albert Sprague Coolidge, Who has been barred from an advisory position at the library because of "derogatory information" about his associations.
Federated Department Stores, Inc., has declared a quarterly dividend of 40 cents on the new common stock, payable on April 28.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1--The BorgWarner Corporation has appropriated $10,000,000 for construction of a chemical plant at Washington, W. Va., near Parkersburg, Roy C. Ingersoll, president, announced today.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (Reuters)-- Sir Hubert Houldsworth, a lawyer who went into the coal mining business because mining law fascinated him and became head of Britain's nationalized coal industry, died at his home here today. He was 66 years old.

The Brooklyn Red Cross, in cooperation with the Board of Education Evening Community Center, will begin a free course in senior life saving on Monday at 7 P.M. in Prospect Heights High School, Classon Avenue and Union Street, Brooklyn.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 1-- Streets were normal and theatres played to crowded houses in riot-affected parts of the city today as the Bombay Government withdrew its dusk-to-dawn curfew. The week-long rioting had protested the Indian Government's decision to sever the city from the state of Maharashtra.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 2-- The Soviet people have still not been told about President Eisenhower's rejection of the Soviet Union's proposal for a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--The Republicans called the Democrats a new name today, but few persons knew what it meant.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 (AP)--The Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation has obtained an option to buy a 700-acre tract of land in Louisiana as the site of a new chemical plant. The site is between Baton Rouge and New Orleans.
TORONTO, Feb. 1--Dr. Claude T. Bissell, vice president of the University of Toronto for the last three years, was named president of Carleton College in Ottawa today.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP)--At least ten men were injured this afternoon when a scaffold collapsed on Gandy Bridge. The workers were thrown to a barge in Tampa Bay. The men were working on the new span alongside the old bridge linking Tampa and St. Petersburg.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 1--Benjamin F. Wright, president of Smith College, in an annual report to 29,000 alumnae, said that "talk of a liberal college education for all, or for half of those from 17 to 22, is sentimental and dangerous nonsense."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- The United States used a record total of 1,522,554 tons of new rubber last year, the Department...

OTTAWA, Feb. 1--Canadian Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent celebrated his seventy-fourth birthday today. The leader of Canada's Liberal party went as usual to his office, where he read his congratulatory telegrams and letters. In the afternoon he appeared in the house of Commons.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP) --A hotel manager reported today that patrons insisted on tipping even in places that frowned on the practice.

BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP)--A great volcanic eruption in Alaska in 1912, which affected nearly the whole earth, has been attributed to the wrong mountain, Dr. G.H. Curtis, University of California geologist, declared today.
Three airline employes at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, were arrested yesterday on charges of profiting from overweight luggage on airplanes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Members of the National Automobile Dealers Association invaded Capitol Hill today with leaflets containing their program of desired automotive legislation.
The city's firemen are to benefit from some of the latest ideas in auto safety equipment.
CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Miniature electric batteries are being built into children's legs to stimulate bone growth when the legs are of unequal length.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today its first public offering of debentures.

OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 1-- Adlai E. Stevenson summoned Democrats today to regain possession of the Federal Government from the concentrated forces of "big money, big business, big industry and big press."
OTTAWA, Feb. 1--Canada and the Soviet Union began negotiations today toward a trade treaty intended to foster a greater exchange of commodities between the two countries.
C. Harvey Bradley has been elected to the board of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1--The International Business Machines Corporation announced today a major new expansion of its West Coast operations. Thomas J. Watson Jr., president, said the program, to cost fifteen to eighteen million dollars, would represent the greatest regional expansion in the company's history.
Motorola, Inc., producer of television and radio receivers, announced plans yesterday for a $3,000,000 addition to its military electronics engineering, research and production facilities ...

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 1 (AP)--Col. Henry Beeuwkes, U.S.A., retired, who organized and commanded the Valley Forge General Hosiptal at Phoenixville, Pa., died at a hospital here yesterday. His age was 74.

Supreme Court Justice M. Henry Martuscello postponed in definitely yesterday an action asking the removal of the Rev. William Howard Melish as supply priest of the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1 (AP) --Mr. and Mrs. Edward Margolin today are the sole owners of the Ambassador, second largest hotel in Atlantic City.
Wages for thousands of workers in the oil industry were increased yesterday by 6 per cent --or $26 or more a month.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--Five Republican legislators from Queens challenged Mayor Wagner today to try out permanent personal registration of voters this year in Queens and Staten Island.

THE recent bandying of the notion that Christopher Marlowe wrote Shakespeare's plays would seem rather old hat to Henry Watterson (1840-1921), who for half a century or so was the dynamic editor of The Louisville Courier-Journal. He gave that idea a splendid run for his money a long time ago.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--Governor Harriman took a look in the fiscal crystal ball today and saw $40,500,000 worth of extra revenue in store for the state next year.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 1--An agreement leading to the purchase of the Walker Bank and Trust Company of Salt Lake City by the Transamerica Corporation was announced today by officers of the institutions.

The Mining and Metallurgical Society of America has elected Philip D. Wilson president Mr. Wilson, a consulting mining engineer and geologist, has been associated for some years with Lehman Brothers and the Lehman Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Senator Paul H. Douglass charged today that if the revenue estimates in the President's budget were right, there would be nearly 5,000,000 persons out of work this year.

The violinist Fritz Kreisler is 81 years old today. A spokesman for the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mr. Kreisler is board chairman, said that because the violinist's wife has been hospitalized, the birthday celebration for Mr. Kreisler would be kept to a minimum.
The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has announced the election of James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, to its board of director.

A grant of $9,000 for cell research has been awarded to the Rev. Charles A. Berger, chairman of Fordham University's biology department, by the National Science Foundation. The gift was announced by the Rev. J. Franklin Ewing, director of research services for the university.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 1 (AP) --Penn State, with an 11-point lead at half-time, survived a Navy surge for a 70-65 basketball victory today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 1 --Leon Uris, author of "Battle Cry," has sold the screen rights to his next novel, to be titled "The Big Dream," to MetroGoldwyn-Mayer.

WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn., Feb. 1 (AP)--The Hamilton Standard Propeller Division of United Aircraft Corporation announced today that after three years of service testing and operation experience it virtually had eliminated abrasion and erosion damage to propeller blades. It is done by coating the blades with a layer of nickel several thousands of a ninch thick.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Judge Robert P. Anderson ordered an indefinite recess today in the Smith Act trial of eight alleged Communists after the Government had rested its case. The purpose of the recess, the court announced, was to give Government and defense lawyers time to prepare various motions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1-- The Government--or at least an expert part of it--had some bad news today for men who are bald and don't like it.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--The old argument as to whether New York City is being shortchanged by the state was reopened today by Governor Harriman.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 1 (UP)--A retired candy salesman today became the eight millionth person to go on the Government's old-age pension payroll.
Dr. Harry R. Radin, 71 years old, of 107 Clinton Avenue, Newark, a dentist, collapsed and died here yesterday while testifying before Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern in a $25,000 damage suit.
MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP)--Criollo, a 67-foot yawl owned by Luis H. Vidana of Havana, finished first tonight in the Miami-to-Nassau yacht race.

IN a small Greenwich Village basement at 100 Seventh Avenue South, a well-staged and competently acted production of Leonid Andreyev's tragi-comedy "He Who Gets Slapped" is being performed nightly from Tuesday through Sunday.

Although some magazines are not doing well, the industry as a whole is in sound condition. Figures just reported by the Magazine Advertising Bureau put total advertising revenue for 1955 at $653,394,533, an increase of 9.4 per cent over the 1954 figure of $597,000,000.

A son was born to Dr. and Mrs. Henry R. Dwork of Tenafly, N.J., on Jan. 28 in the French Hospital, Mrs. Dwork is the former Miss Joyce Kraus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto E. Kraus of 860 Fifth Avenue, New York. The child, who has been named Andrew Philip, is also a grandson of Sol Dwork.
Delta Air Lines, for thirty years the air carrier of the Deep South, invaded Yankee territory yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Governor Harriman submitted to the Legislature today an Executive budget proposing state expenditures of a record $1,494,700,000. This would be $99,600,000 more than expected tax collections.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (UP) --Ronnie Holmberg of Brooklyn, the national junior indoor tennis champion, enrolled today at Tulane University.
Yielding to truck industry pressure, Mayor Wagner has blocked Operation Crosstown, a key item in the city's proposed traffic relief program.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 1--Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange said today that the recent violations of the Norwegian fisheries border by Soviet trawlers were more extensive than any incursions since the line was established in 1869.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Feb. 1 (UP)--The death of a 19-yearold cat named Punch will result in the transfer of an estate valued at $60,000 to the First Church of Christ, Scientist, Boston, it was disclosed today.

MIAMI, Feb. 1 (AP)--Major league baseball club representatives reaffirmed today an earlier stand that the clubs--and not the players--owned revenues received for sale of world series and All-Star game radio and television rights.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- Senator William Langer, North Dakota Republican, formed a one-man audience composed of himself today and listened patiently to his own ninety-threepage speech.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 1 (Reuters)--The first installment of a promised supply of Western arms was delivered to Libya today. The arms were supplied by Britain and handed over by Ambassador Gerald Graham to Libya's Premier, Mustafa Halim. A supply of United States arms was scheduled to arrive here soon.

HAMILTON, Ohio, Feb. 1-- The engagement of Miss Constance Bird Wilson to Mark Crane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Crane of Glencoe, Ill., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll L. Wilson.
When new ideas in pleasure boating are getting try-outs, the Shakeshafts can be certain to do some pioneering. Their boat service station at Mamaroneck is one of the busiest on Long Island Sound.
DUESSELDORF, Germany, Feb. 1--Ruhr leaders painted a black picture of the financial condition of West Germany's industry and business today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Warren E. Baker, general counsel of the Federal Communications Commission, underwent vigorous questioning today on whether the agency "discriminates" against newspapers seeking radio and television licenses.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 1--A service at St. Andrew's Anglican Cathedral in Sydney today marked the opening meeting of the world executive of the World Council of Churches.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 (AP)--The Rev. David S. MacInnes, executive of the Presbyterian Synod of New York, was elected president today of the State Council of Churches. The Syracuse church leader was chosen at the closing session of a three-day meeting of the Protestant organization. He succeeds the Rev. James A. G. Moore of Rochester.

The dispute between the Department of Marine and Aviation and the Port Authority over the heliport to be constructed at West Thirtieth Street and the Hudson River will be aired soon before the Board of Estimate.
A former deputy collector of internal revenue, who the Government said received $12,600 through filing false applications for tax refunds, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Moving discreetly across the background of any international conference attended by Britain are the quietly dressed, gently spoken officials of the Foreign Office.
PARIS, Feb. 1--The finance ministers of seventeen European nations will discuss the problem of reconciling two rival economic doctrines here Feb. 28.
Directors of Eastman Chemical Products, Inc., a subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company, have announced the election of William S. Vaughan as president and a director.

Highhanded practices on the part of the Soviet Government, which holds that it is a law unto itself in the interest of the Communist world revolution, have involved it in trouble with two more countries.

MIAMI, Feb. 1--Daniel G. Arnstein, who operates a fleet of cabs in New York, has in his racing stable a colt named Eiffel Blue. If they backed the Arnstein horse at Hialeah today, some extra-chipper Arnstein cabbies are on the streets tonight.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 (UP)--The Boston Bruins' right-winger, Jerry Toppazini, suffered a compound fracture of his right finger yesterday, but Coach Milt Schmidt of the National Hockey League club said today: "He'll play tomorrow night against Chicago." A shot by Doug Mohns broke Toppazzini's hand during a practice.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Joan Barbara Kelly to John J. Quinn Jr. Miss Kelly is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kelly of the Bronx. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Quinn, also of the Bronx. The prospective bride is a graduate of Aquinas Hall. Mr. Quinn, a senior at Fordham College, was graduated from Fordham Preparatory School.
PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Feb. 1 (UP)--A jet bomber division, capable of striking at an enemy anywhere in the world, was activated at the Air Force Base here today.
FOR his first show in sev eral years, Nat Werner has brought together more than forty pieces of sculpture at the A.C.A. Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 1 (Reuters)--Vice Admiral A. de Boaey, Commander in Chief of the Royal Netherlands Navy, will fly to Washington Feb. 13 for a two-week inspection trip of United States naval installations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The House of Representatives, by 358 to 3, approved today a $1,400,000,000 naval shipbuilding program that included construction of the first nuclear-driven surface vessel. The craft would be a missile-launching cruiser.

Albert W. Schroeder has been elected president of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway Company. He succeeds John W. Devins, who will retire on March 1. It was also announced that shareholders will be asked to increase the board of directors to twelve so Mr. Devins may continue as a member. W.P. Coliton replaces Mr. Schroeder as vice president of operations.

New York's department stores continued last month to ride the crest of heavy consumer demand. Excellent response to January clearances gave the nine major stores an average sales increase of 3.5 per cent over January of last year.

A "flood" of pledge cards-- "beyond our wildest hopes"--has been pouring in on the union that hopes to oust the independent International Longshoremen's Association from the New York waterfront.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Navy today sparked a $100,000,000 tanker construction project by private interests.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--Most departments of the National Council of Churches that are now in the organization's Midwest office in the Pullman Building here will be moved to New York City in the last week of April. The Rev. Dr. Harry H. Kalas, Chicago office director, announced the move today.

CAIRO, Jan. 31--Egypt's hardening opposition to the Baghdad Pact was seen here as serving notice on the West that any attempt to strengthen or extend that alliance would only sow more a Arab disunity.

I made my plans to appear at the convention on July 14 to accept the nomination in person.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 1--A variety show, "Frantic Follies of 1956," will be presented Saturday and Sunday by the Eastern Military Academy here.

PARIS, Feb. 1--Guy Mollet, newly installed Premier of France, laid plans today to go soon to Algeria to study the rebellion there. He has called the Algerian revolt the nation's primary problem.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 1-- William H. Nunn of 21 Greenview Way, an assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died-yesterday in Montclair Community Hospital after a brief illness. He was 55 years old.

Futures prices moved irregularly yesterday in generally dull and featureless markets here. Coffee, cocoa, hides, wool and copper rose; cottonseed oil, soybean oil and onions declined, and rubber, potatoes, sugar and tin closed mixed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- Defense Secretary Charles E. Wilson said today an industry official used a "despicable smear technique" in suggesting that personal interest caused Assistant Secretary Thomas P. Pike to oppose a West Texas-California pipeline.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 1 (AP)-- The Continental Oil Company today announced a -cent increase in tank-wagon prices of its regular and premium gasoline in Texas. Harry J. Kennedy, vice president in charge...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--A daughter was born yesterday in Georgetown Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Henry Dorsey Jr. of Westmoreland Hills, Md. Mrs. Dorsey is the former Mrs. Elizabeth Bradley Beukema, daughter of General and Mrs. Omar N. Bradley of Los Angeles. Mr. Dorsey is the son of Rear Admiral Benjamin H. Dorsey, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Dorsey of Washington. The child has been named Melanie Graham.
MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The Soviet Government announced tonight it would pay 70 per cent-more for vegetables in an effort to overcome the "extremely insufficient" production.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--The National Confectioners Association of the United States and the Associated Retail Confectioners of the United States today approved a full-scale public relations program for the confectionery industry.

BOONTON, N.J., Feb. 1-- Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Cobb have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Lou Cobb, to William John Schwarting. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Schwarting of Rockville Centre, L.I. A spring wedding is planned.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 1--Mr. and Mrs. James W. Wooster Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ezit Anne Wooster, to William K. Newcomb of Menlo Park, Calif.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 1 (AP)--Vice Admir al Alfred M. Pride took command today of the Pacific Fleet Air Force from Vice Admiral Harold M. Martin, who is retiring from the Navy. Admiral Pride, 58 years old, recently commanded the Seventh Flett in the Formosa area.
The Metropolitan Opera presented "Lucia di Lammermoor" last night, with Roberta Peter singing the title role for the first time at the Metropolitan.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1-- Juscelino Kubitschek today lifted press censorship in one of his first acts as President of Brazil.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 1--Dr. Walter C. Coffey, President Emeritus of the University of Minnesota, died yesterday in Orlando, Fla., on the eve of his eightieth birthday.
The Red Cross here collected 11,636 pints of blood last month, as compared with 9,576 in December, 1955.
Hayes Alan Jenkins spent considerable time in the shadow of Dick Button, the former world and Olympic champion, before attaining his goal as men's Olympic figure skating champion.

The Cancer Philanthropic League, Inc., an organization of volunteers that provides home care for the victims of cancer, will hold a benefit luncheon and fashion show on Saturday. The event will take place in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane.
A record toss in the shot-put and an individual double triumph highlighted the freshman field events of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Track and Field Association yesterday.
Mrs. Barbara Hartle, a former leading Communist party organizer in the Pacific Northwest, was released yesterday from the Women's Federal Penitentiary at Alderson, W. Va.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- A key House Democrat predicted today the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee would recommend $10 to $12 billion in new highway "use" taxes over the next fifteen years to pay for the road construction program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The President and Mrs. Eisenhower will leave tomorrow for a long, quiet week-end at their Gettysburg home.
The American Association of Advertising Agencies consented yesterday in Federal Court not to make any effort to fix commissions received by agencies for placing newspaper and magazine advertising.
ALBANY, Feb. 1--The Thru way took in more toll revenue last year than officials expected, but the share paid by truck traffic was well below advance estimates.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 1--To Tenley Albright figure skating has always been intensely personal. Since she was 10 years old, skating has been her life.
Tuesday's rally in rail, metal and oil stocks continued yesterday, but the railroads ran out of steam about noon and the oils and metals also weakened in late dealings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP)-- Forty high school seniors from twenty states were named today as finalists in the annual science talent search conducted by the Science Clubs of America.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 (AP)--Japan's Chamber of Commerce said today any United States import restrictions on Japanese cotton goods would "immensely affect Japan" and urged the United States to "avoid such an unhappy eventuality."
Fighting or playing hockey made little difference to the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. Engaging the Toronto Maple Leafs...

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (UP) --Sam Tufano's Mill Neck, the 9-to-5 favorite, gained a photofinish triumph today in the feature at the Fair Grounds. Nother Speech finished second, a length and a quarter in front of Tonight. Mill Neck ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:47 1-5.
St. John's will play its 1,000th basketball game tonight, meeting Cincinnati in the middle contest of a college tripleheader at Madison Square Garden.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 1--A four-man mission will leave Saturday to visit trust territories in the Pacific administered by the United States, Australia and New Zealand. The group will report on conditions in the area to the eighteenth session of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, opening here in June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- The United States Chamber of Commerce feels "good" but not "exuberant" about the business outlook for 1956. In a quarterly report, the chamber said production of many products, such as autos and homes, reached such peaks in 1955 they "must be expected to taper off" this year. It said farm income "which declined steadily last year probably will suffer a fur ther moderate drop."
ATLANTA, Feb. 1--The Georgia Legislature today passed a newspaper libel bill and it was branded as an attempt by the Administration of Gov. Marvin Griffin to intimidate the press.
HONG KONG, Feb. 1--The Chinese Communists said tonight their anti-aircraft shot down two Nationalist F-84 Thunderjets Sunday over Tungshan, sixty miles southwest of Quemoy.

A large uncut diamond, de scribed by experts as the finest and purest ever to be dug in Africa, was delivered to its American buyer yesterday morning, airmailed from London. It was one of 50,000 diamonds bought by Harry Winston, Inc., the largest purchase the concern has ever made. It was valued at $8,400,000.

Make no mistake about it--the days are truly getting longer. Starting at the time of the last-minute Christ- ... mas shopping rush, each one of them has seen the sun come up a little earlier, go down a little later.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 2--The West German Government and Parliament strongly condemned East German judicial authorities today for having sentenced to death two persons convicted of having incited East Germans to flee the German Democratic Republic.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 2--A long time ago a little American girl conquered polio. This afternoon, ten, years later, she fought off the agony of a throbbing ankle to win another test--the women's figure skating championship of the seventh Winter Olympic Games.

The so-called Point Four Program of technical assistance to underdeveloped areas evolved from the fourth point enunciated by Mr. Truman in his Inaugural Address giving his aims for world recovery. In calling it "not an anti-Communist measure," he wrote:

It looks as if Kim Stanley will get the principal feminine role in the Arthur Laurents play "A Clearing in the Woods." Negotiations are under way, but contracts haven't been signed. A spokesman for the author admitted yesterday that Miss Stanley was the leading candidate for the assignment.
The Red Cross will collect blood today at the American Express Company, 65 Broadway, and the America Fore Insurance Group, 80 Maiden Lane.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Wesley (Buzz) Clark, the seventeenth choice of the Baltimore Colts in the National Football League draft, signed today. Clark was a middle guard and offensive tackle at Mississippi Southern.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 2 (AP)--A daughter was born yesterday to Jane Powell, film actress and singer. Miss Powell is the wife of Pat Nerney, automobile dealer. The child, named Lindsey Averill Nerney, was born in St. John's Hospital.
Two gypsy scofflaws, George Lee and George Adams, received lenient treatment yesterday from Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh for their cooperation in getting other gypsies to pay fines ...
ALBANY, Feb. 2--The State Commissioner of Investigation cited today wholesale registration of the dead and summer residents in Putnam County as a reason for a tighter check on rural voting.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. 2-- The National Blank Book Company had record sales of $11,436,490 in the year that ended Nov. 30, Richard P. Towne, president, announced yesterday. This was 15.8 per cent above the previous record high of $9,873,409 in 1954. Net income for the year just ended was $580,980 or $6.45 per share, compared with the previous year's $452,811, or $5.03.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 2 --John Guedel has presented to the National Broadcasting Company his next project, "What Is Love?"

A store building under construction at 236th Street and Johnson Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been purchased by Harry J. Appel, builder. The seller was the Guide Realty Company, headed by ...
Stanley Hummel, a veteran of the local concert scene, gave a piano recital last night in Town Hall. His playing followed the pattern he has set in previous years.
Directors of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday voted a dividend of 50 cents payable on March 10 on the new stock resulting from the recent three-for-one split.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Max O'Rell Truitt, son-in-law of United States Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat of Kentucky, died early today at Emergency Hospital. Mr. Truitt, an attorney, was 52 years old.
CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 2 (AP)--Following is a list of champions crowned in the seventh Winter Olympics:
The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that its net income from operations last year rose to $13,040,690 from, $9,384,986 in the preceding year.
Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., is diversifying by the acquisition of Vitality Mills, Inc., Chicago producer of dog food and other animal and poultry feeds.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Judge Vincent A. Carroll reduced today to eleven to twenty-two months the sentences of Milton and Rosalie Schwartz for their part in the abortion death of Mrs. Doris Jean Ostreicher.
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 2 (AP)-- The Milwaukee Braves today signed Joseph Zdanis, 18, an outfielder-shortstop from Paterson, N.J., to a Wellsville (N.Y.) contract in the Class D Pony League.
The St. Regis Paper Company is planning to add protective food wrapping and packaging paper to its diversified line of papers through a securities transaction with the Rhinelander Paper Company.
NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 2--The volume of commercial ship traffic and coal dumping at Hampton Roads ports during January established records, according to the Hampton Roads Maritime Association.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2 (AP)-- The Cleveland Indians said today that Sam Mele, an outfielder who is a free agent, and Duane Pillette, a right-handed pitcher belonging to Buffalo of the International League, would report to the Indians' spring training camp at Tucson, Ariz., on a trial basis.

If City Magistrate Walter J. Bayer --who is comparatively new at the business--will permit us to intervene as a friend of the court, we advise him not to waste too much sympathy on motorists haled before him by the police for traffic violations.
Stockholders of the MissouriKansas-Texas Railroad at a special meeting in St. Louis yesterday approved a plan which would permit the road to proceed with a voluntary recapitalization program.

A program of dramatic readings from Dostoevski, Chekhov and Saroyan will be given tonight at the Cooper Union Forum, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street, at 8:30. Ruth Ford, Mae Cooper, Henry Sharp, Will Kuluva, Deirdre Owens, Alfred Ryder, Svea Grunfeld and Willie Simpson will participate.
George P. Monaghan, New York State's Commissioner of Harness Racing, wants a set of track officials comparable to "major league umpires."
LONDON, Feb. 2--British Government circles indicated cautious satisfaction today with the results of the Eden-Eisenhower talks.
General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen served notice on the city yesterday that it must pay in full the salary increases budgeted for most of the court's employer in 1956-57.
Chief of Detectives James B. Leggett started an investigation yesterday into the shooting Tuesday involving Billy Daniels, night club singer, because the report reached his office five hours late.

The appointment of Spencer F. Williams as president of Mortgage Representatives, Inc., Mortgagee Representatives, Inc., was announced yesterday. The new mortgage banking concern has opened offices ...
The gust of wind heading for New York yesterday was not wholly the result of an atmospheric disturbance. The baseball men are coming to town for their final session of the offseason.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- Strong resistance is being marshaled in the Senate to the Eisenhower Administration's arrangement with the British to soften restrictions on trade with Communist China.
Gene Austin, one of the leading crooners in the Nineteen Twenties, will appear on the "Shower of Stars" television program on Feb. 16 to sing "My Blue Heaven."
Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, will make his only New York appearance this season at the second and final Pension Fund Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony ...
Al (Dusty) DeStefano, head basketball and baseball coach at St. John's University since 1952, resigned yesterday, effective at the end of the next college baseball season.

The Indianapolis, Ind., Sanitary District will accept bids until Feb. 21 on $17,970,000 of first and second issue bonds of 1956, it was announced yesterday. The bonds which are dated Feb. 1, will mature from 1958 to 1987.

ALBUQUERQUE, Feb. 2 (AP) --Thirty-four pupils, teachers and parents were marooned last night in an elementary school by the worst blizzard in years. All were safe today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- A famous letter Franklin D. Roosevelt wrote ten days after the 1941 Pearl Harbor attack to "the President of the United States in 1956" has been delivered to President Eisenhower.
MONTREAL, Feb. 2--David Rittenhouse, a retired steel executive and one of the pioneer telegraphers of the continent, died here yesterday at the age of 92.

The key question for the years ahead will be the sincerity of the Soviet Union's approach in its dealings with the West, in the opinion of Joseph E. Johnson, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
Tri-Continental Corporation's net assets reached $278,027,599, a new high, at the year-end, Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president, reported yesterday in a preliminary annual report.

H.V. Kaltenborn has asserted that former President Harry S. Truman was right in saying that he and other news analysts were wrong in their 1948 election-night interpretations of the political trend. But, Mr. Kaltenborn added, he was not quite so wrong as Mr. Truman made out.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2-- Leaders of unions with 25,000,000 workers in North, South and Central America rejected today a fresh Communist effort to form a united labor front in this hemisphere.
Allan Sproul was reappointed president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for a fiveyear term yesterday by the directors of the bank.
ALBANY, Feb. 2--The Harriman Administration's plan for compensating innocent victims of uninsured drivers was submitted formally today to the Legislature.
TRENTON, Feb. 2--Leading from the start, the Rider College basketball team overwhelmed City College of New York, 96--66, tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2--The General Motors Corporation, which has a long record of firsts, took another in 1955. It became the first company in American history to earn more than a billion dollars in a year.
