ALTHOUGH a third of life is spent in sleep, a persistent decorating problem in many homes is how to conceal the furniture on which this blissful state is obtained. In the past, beds have been hidden in closets or masqueraded as chests. The twentieth-century contribution has been the sofa-bed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, advised farmers today to dig in to protect not only their families but their livestock in case of nuclear attack.

GOVERNOR HARRIMAN'S budget, announced Wednesday, contains welcome and practical provisions for the start of educational television in this state. The plan must be carried further, however, if New York City is to benefit.
Four firemen, including the deputy Fire Chief of Brooklyn and Queens, were injured and a fifth suffered a heart attack and later died as a result of a Queens fire yesterday.
The Waterfront Commission's hearing into a baggage "shakedown" on a North River pier, which resumes this morning, may be marked by "fireworks" growing out of a charge of tampering with witnesses.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 3--Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin called on President Eisenhower yesterday to reconsider his rejection of the twenty-year friendship pact proposed by the Soviet Union last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb 2 (UP) --Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, has decided that from now on he alone will sign letters that require his signature.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP) --The Government wants no more $1,000,000 tax deficiencies like that of Joe Louis, former boxing champion. It is taking steps to see they do not happen again.

MELROSE, Mass., Feb. 2-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. H. Lloyd Thornton of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Thornton, to Martin A. Rankow. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Rankow of New York.
Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to lend his good offices to a union campaign for recognition as bargaining agent for taxicab drivers.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 2--Members of the Austrian winter Olympic team lingered over their breakfasts at the Hotel Croce Bianca this morning. Among them sat Toni Sailer, the 20-year-old skiing sensation who already has won two gold medals. Sailer is heavily favored to win a third one tomorrow in the downhill event.
PAHAQUARRY TOWNSHIP, N.J., Feb. 2--The School Board in this largely wooded township anticipates spending $2,380 on education in the next fiscal year, --all for one pupil.
A Bronx County Court jury returned last night a death verdict against a building superintendent accused of knifing a 17-year-old youth in an argument.

Something over 5,000 miles from here, a great newspaper prints this morning an editorial that begins: "After more than five years of forced silence we return to take our place in journalism and renew our ...
The marriage of Miss Margaret Andrews to Theodore Ehrenkranz took place yesterday afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Riverdale the Bronx. The Rev. Gerald Berry performed the ceremony.

The Society of Automotive Engineers has leased 18,000 square feet of space for headquarters in the thirty-story office building going up at 485 Lexington Avenue, the east blockfront between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Beginning tomorrow, Mexican air mail for Europe will be flown over the Arctic route. Compania Mexicana de Aviacion announced today that mail will be flown to California and thence to Europe by Scandinavian Airlines.

Wellington Fund'S net assets at the year-end rose to a new high of $496,612,707, equal to $26.61 a share, according to the annual report released yesterday. This compared with the previous high of $401,740,447, of $24.60 a share, set in 1954.
Senior Rabbi Julius Mark of Temple Emanu-El will leave today on a mission to the Pacific, where he will place a Torah scroll in a chapel to be dedicated on Guam.

Futures trading continued dull yesterday in most New York commodity markets. Prices movements were irregular with cocoa, coffee, rubber and potatoes higher; sugar, wool, hides, copper and zinc lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil and onions mixed.
The purchase of substantially all the properties of the Upham Gas Company, Mineral Wells, Tex., for $5,000,000 was announced yesterday by Robert J. Bradley of Dallas, Tex.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Jerome S. Glazer of New Orleans on Jan. 25 in Tours Infirmary in New Orleans. Mrs. Glazer is the former Miss Barbara Shapiro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Shapiro of 470 West End Avenue. The child will be named Bradford Allen.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Small price recessions early in the Board of Trade session today brought active buying, with a stronger trend later in the day.

Sears, Roebuck Co., big merchandising organization, selling by mail and through a nationwide chain of about 700 retail stores, will spend $55,000,000 to $60,000,000 for expansion and improvement this year.
MOSCOW, Feb. 12--The Soviet press charged today that propaganda balloons released by the United States sponsored Crusade for Freedom imperiled air communications between Berlin and the West.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--A new set of figures published in an official Government document shows proved oil reserves in the Middle East to be more than double previous estimates.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 2 (AP)-- Lionel Hebert posted a 3-underpar 68 today to take the firstround lead in the $15,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.
THEODORE APSTEIN'S "The Innkeepers," which opened at the John Golden last evening, is a mild play on a fiery subject.
TORONTO, Feb. 2 (Canadian) Press)--Little Long Lac Gold Mines, Ltd., has acquired control of Lake Shore Mines, Ltd., at Kirkland Lake, Ont., Lake Shore president J.C. Adamson has announced.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks increased $40,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The task of holing through the last 350 feet of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was halted yesterday by a dispute between the contractors and sandhogs.

POTSDAM, N.Y., Feb. 2-- The Clarkson Tech hockey team scored its twelfth straight victory tonight by downing Middlebury, 6--2. Eddie Rowe, the highest scorer in Eastern college hockey, was top man with two goals and one assist for the Golden Knights.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 2-- Dale Hall, a halfback with Army's national champions in 1944, was named as an assistant on Head Coach Earl H. (Red) Blaik's football staff today.

William J. Schaefer Jr., president of Schaefer, Inc., Stamford, Conn., has been elected president of the National Institute of Rug Cleaners. The institute has 590 members in the United States and Canada.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2--The United States asked today for a quick meeting of the Security Council to approve the Sudan's request for United Nations membership.

Miss Ann Judith Riker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Judson Riker of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Sumner Gordon Baum were married yesterday evening in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador by the Rev. Dr. Jacob ...

The Brtish Petroleum Company announced yesterday plans for a $55,000,000 expansion of its Kent oil refinery on the Isle of Grain, England. The new facilities, which will not go into operation for more than a year, will raise the plant's capacity from 90,000 to 140,000 barrels a day.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 2 --A son was born to Lieut. William Cory Woodhull 2d of the Army and Mrs. Woodhull last Saturday in the Morristown Memorial Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Willie Mosconi, Haddon Heights, N.J., defeated Jimmy Caras, Upper Darby, Pa., twice today, 150--110 and 150--53, in a pocket-billiard match billed for the world championship. This gives Mosconi 1,200 points to Caras' 751 in their 1,800-point contest.
One hundred and twenty-eight persons, including many children, were routed from their home shortly after 1 A.M. today by a four-alarm fire in an adjoining building.
The next Waterfront Commission order cutting casuals from the port's work force may lower it to a critical level below which cargo-handling efficiency might be menaced.

ALBANY, Feb. 2--A new high school course in physics has been prepared by the State Education Department and will go into use next September. The course places "substantial emphasis" on electronics and nuclear energy.

CAIRO, Feb. 2--In the view of the Arabs there is nothing new in the proposals for Middle East peace made by President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Eden, a high official of the Arab League said tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2 (UP) --Dr. Paul Dudley White, President Eisenhower's heart specialist, sailed today on an expedition to record the heartbeat of a giant whale. He hopes his studies will help him learn more about the human heart.
IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 2--The marriage of Mrs. Margaret Allen Stearns to Peter Yates Francisco of New York took place here yesterday afternoon in St. Barnabas Protestant Episcopal Church.

Edward E. Conroy, who was in charge of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation during World War II, died Wednesday in his home at 256 Burns Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 60 years old.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2--Atomic radiation has been used successfully to sterilize human bone for transplantation, the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons was told today.

MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (AP)--A twelve-man jury today convicted Mrs. Lillian Pursey, a former baroness who is now the wife of a Member of Britain's Parliament, of illegal possession of narcotics. She was sentenced to serve a six months in jail.

Special to The New York Times. BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 2 --Superior Court Judge James C. Shannon told the police today that his wallet, containing $41, had been taken from his coat, which was hanging in his chambers while he was presiding in court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UP)-- American corporations paid out more in dividends last year than ever before in history, the Department of Commerce reported today.

McMINNVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 2 (AP)--A college student from New York was brought out of Higgenbotham Cave early today by a rescue squad after lying on his back in a pit of the giant cavern for eight hours.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- The Washington Senators today purchased Vernon Morgan, a former schoolboy star at Emporia, Va., from the Chicago Cubs. Morgan, a left-handed hitting infielder, batted .301 last season at Des Moines in the Western League. He saw limited service with the Cubs and Los Angeles of the Pacific Coast League.

The Lewis Conger Building, 1152-56 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), at Forty-fifth Street, has been sold by Herbert Jacques Morris of the Clinton W. Blume Company, realty brokers, to New England Industries, Inc. The buyer was represented by Harold Greenstein, as consultant.

Bank clearings of the twentysix leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday mounted to $21,070,605,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented a decline of 1.4 per cent from last year's $22,043,570,000 and 4.9 per cent below the previous week's $22,164,072,000.

WHEN a contemporary piece draws bravos from the subscribers of the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall, you may be sure that it is something special. Samuel Barber's "Medea's Meditation and Dance of Vengeance" was the composittion that stirred the Philharmonic audience last night, and it builds with unusual intensity.

TRENTON, Feb. 2--State Senator Kenneth C. Hand, Republican of Union County, was named to the State Superior Court bench today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner. It was the fourth appointment to this tribunal made by Mr. Meyner, a Democrat, in as many days.

Two new series of free classes on home care of the sick will be started next week by the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross at 1 Red Cross Place. The daytime classes will be held Tuesdays and Thursdays from ...
Prices of cotton futures advanced 3 to 20 points (15 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The volume of business was moderate.
The use of safety belts for firemen was praised yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. as "the most comprehensive safety step ever taken by the department."

SINGAPORE, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Chairman E.G. Holiday of the Singapore Chamber of Commerce Rubber Association today denied accusation by the United States Rubber Manufacturers' Association that certain Singapore rubber grades did not measure up to international standards.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)-- Judge Harold R. Medina said today that if the Second United States Circuit Court of Appeals, of which he is a member, did not get new judges soon "some of us are going to be knocked out."
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 3-- When Japan's Occupation Constitution is rewritten the Emperor may be designated as "Head of the State." But he will continue to be without power in the Government.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 2 (UP) --The Philadelphia Warriors rallied in the closing seconds tonight to nip the New York Knickerbockers, 88--87, in a National Basketball Association game at War Memorial Auditorium.

ARLINGTON, Va., Feb. 2-- A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Allen Bourg on Jan. 26 at Doctors Hospital in Washington. Mrs. Bourg is the former Miss Nancy Day Boland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Boland of Middletown, N.J. The child has been named James Allen.
DENVER, Feb. 2 (AP)--Uranium held the stage center today has the national Western Mining Conference opened three days of meetings, Miners are hopeful ...
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics eased to 89.4 on Feb. 1 from 89.5 on Jan. 31. The figure for Feb. 2, 1955, was 92.

STROMBOLI, Italy, Feb. 2 (Reuters)--Lava cascaded to the sea from Stromboli's three craters tonight as the island volcano burst into fresh activity, with heavy subterranean rumblings and brilliant flashes.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The Atlantic Terminal Command at the Brooklyn Army Terminal will be moved to an internal city, as the Army announced last Sept. 28, but no decision on the place has yet been made.
BOSTON, Feb. 2 (UP)--The Chicago Black Hawks kept the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League cellar tonight, gaining a 2-2 tie despite a seriously injured goalie.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 2--A conference in Canberra today between shipowners and the Australian Council of Trade Un ions and the Waterside Workers Federation failed to settle the eleven-day-old waterside strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb.2--Wendell B. Barnes, head of the Small Business Administration, today ordered the conversion of all disaster loans made by that agency, from 6 per cent to a 3 per cent annual interest rate.

The Alumnae Association of Ladycliff College, Highland Falls, N.Y., will hold a cocktail dance tomorrow from 4 to 7 P.M. in the Florentine Room of Schrafft's Restaurant, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street. Funds realized will be given to the college's new chapel.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 2--Vocational training equipment valued at $1,820 will be sent to eight agricultural and engineering high schools in South Korea, as a result of contributions received recently from schools and organizations in the United States and Cuba.
Mr. and Mrs. Victor Borge are the parents of a daughter, born yesterday, at the Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. The child has been named Frederikke. It is the couple's second child.
BOSTON, Feb. 2--Some of the $1,219,000 Brink's loot has been recovered.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, who directed the development of the atomic bomb, said yesterday that physics was now in search of a new order in the universe.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 2 (Reuters)--Marshal Ivan Konev, Soviet commander-inchief of East Europe's unified military command, left here by air today for Moscow after an eight-day stay in Czechoslovakia.

The use of atomic radiation for sterilizing food is a long way from "just around the corner," John M. Fox, president of the Minute Maid Corporation, said yesterday. He spoke at the closing day's sessions of the National Frozen Foods Convention ...

Cooperative apartments in 1056 Fifth Avenue have been sold by Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers, to Dr. Genia Sakin, Milton Belgard and Leonard Friedberg. Sidney Mattison bought an apartment in 1035 Fifth Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 2-- A vehicular blind alley formed by a four-lane divided highway to the heart of this North Shore city was proposed today by the State Department of Public Works.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)-- Malaya, the British Commonwealth's rich rubber and tin territory, took a big step nearer independence within the Commonwealth here today.
KADUNA, Nigeria, Feb. 2-- Turbaned Moslems, pagan warriors, masked dancers, women singers and a jester paraded before Queen Elizabeth II today in a scene of medieval splendor.

A three-story office building at 365 New Lots Avenue in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Williamsburgh Savings Bank. The property is in the rear of the bank's branch on Pennsylvania Avenue. Purchase was made from William Surgan, who was represented by Julius Trachman, attorney.
Food items below are recommended as good buys of the coming week-end in stores in the metropolitan area. Prices are reported by the New York City Department of Markets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--A Labor publication predicted today that "in the months immediately ahead, most unions very likely will negotiate gains at least comparable to those widely achieved in 1955."
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 2 (UP)--Dave Melton, a righthanded outfielder with San Francisco of the Pacific Coast League in 1955, signed his Kansas City Athletics' contract today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2-- The general economy is running well ahead of forecasts for the early part of this year and will continue to climb well into the summer, Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, declared today.

The campaign was built on one issue--the interests of the people, as represented by the Democrats, against the special interests, as represented by the Republicans and the record of the Eightieth Congress. I staked the race for the Presidency on that one issue.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 5-- Dag Hammarskjold said today that he saw no objection to regional military alliances if these were formed for self-defense and for nothing else.
The nation's eighty-one medical schools will share $2,657,434 raised in 1955 by the National Fund for Medical Education.

Gifford Reynolds Beal, a painter, why only last year was called a "perennially young veteran" in the field of art, died at his home yesterday at the age of 77. He lived at 27 West Sixtyseventh Street.

The New York Rangers tied the score three times last night to earn a 3-3 deadlock with the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden. The National Hockey League game was played before a sell-out crowd of 15,925 fans, including about 700 standees.

A new program of religion and psychiatry will be instituted this summer at Union Theological Seminary. It will be made possible by a grant of $200,000 from the Old Dominion Foundation for an initial period of five years.

A syndicate of investors organized by Louis P. Sill, vice president of Herbert Charles Co., realty brokers, has purchased three five-story commercial and apartment buildings at 51, 53 and 55 East Fifty-fifth Street, near Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Buy American Act--that perennial breeder of ill-will between foreign bidders and the United States--seems to have lost most of its sting so far as international relations are concerned.

MAYBE parents think they have money troubles as the April 15 tax deadline looms up on the calendar. For real financial anguish, though, few problems beat the plight of the high school sophomore.

AS actors the baseball writers are always topical but never tropica--meaning that there not so hot. For the thirty third time they assailed the Muses in their annual show at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. And when these disguised press-box tenants wear the sock and buskin, the sock is always emphasized in quite heavy-handed fashion.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 5-- Reports that the United States and Britain are considering the possibility of armed intervention to keep or restore peace in the Middle East have aroused angry comment here.

MIAMI, Feb. 5--Robert Ussery rode at the Hialeah race track last winter, but he didn't attract much attention. It's a different story this February. The rider of Switch On, the winner of yesterday's $66,500 McLennan Handicap, is one of the top men in the jockey standing.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Feb. 5 (UP)--Anne Quast and Ruth Jessen, teen-agers from the State of Washington, won the women's international four-ball golf tournament today.
CAIRO, Feb. 3--"For thousands of years the Great Pyramids of Egypt were the foremost engineering marvels of the world. They insured a life after death to the Pharaohs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Senate hopes to dispose of the natural gas bill this week in spite of the uproar surrounding an alleged attempt to buy a Senator's vote for the measure.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 5--The sun set on the seventh Winter Olympics tonight. To uproarious applause, the flagbearers of the thirty-two competing nations marched into the crowded ice stadium for the closing ceremony.
Three United States theologians have raised the "caution" flag against what they regard as overly hasty interpretations of the Dead Sea scrolls.
ZURICH, Feb. 5--Three out of the five great Swiss commercial banks published their balance sheets for 1955 last week.
The morale of teachers, supervisors and principals in the New York City school system appears to be at a new low.
Harry S. Truman declared yesterday that the Republicans party must have been "pretty badly hurt" by his charge that Vice President Richard M. Nixon had called him a traitor.
MIAMI, Feb. 5--Forty thousand Miamians and visitors had an advance look yesterday at the new $10,000,000 Jordan MarshMiami store which will be opened formally at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning.

The mystery of how Jackie Gross eye was badly cut at the Rikers Island jail was solved quickly by a Bronx assistant district attorney after it had baffled the Department of Correction since last Tuesday.
Mrs. Harry Hays Morgan, mother of the well-known Morgan twins, Gloria Mercedes and Thelma, died Saturday in her home at 14 East Sixtieth Street.

BEFORE World War II there were probably few Americans who knew or thought much about Korea other than it was a strange land in far-off Asia. Except for a small sprinkling of missionaries, Americans had had little occasion to know the "land of the morning calm" until our occupation forces landed there in the late summer of 1945.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--Several important Republican legislators are planning a drive this week to get more state money for suburban schools than the Heald Commission has recommended.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- Senator A. Willis Robertson urged Congress today to nullify the Supreme Court's "disruptive" school integration ruling by allowing states to operate segregated classrooms.
ALTHOUGH there were no world premieres on the program of the Knickerbocker Chamber Players at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, the concert had a decidedly contemporary color.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 5--The Security Council will meet tomorrow to consider the Sudan's application for membership, United Nations sources foresee favorable action.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5-- Heavier punishment, more enforcement officers and better Federal-State coordination were among steps recommended today to combat the narcotic evil.

Jerry Ford, the athletic director at the University of Pennsylvania, has been named to head the Ivy League administrative committee. It's created a pleasant stir in boarding school circles because Ford is one of their own. He used to be the St. George's football coach.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 5--Dutch foreign trade last year set a record high. Exports were 10,163,000,000 guilders, against 9,172,000,000 in 1954. Imports totaled 12,189,000,000, against 10,860,000,000. [The guilder is traded at about 3.8 to the dollar.]
As an Olympic-year harbinger of things to come, the Millrose games spectacularly projected new faces and different events into the track and field spotlight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Federal Government made available to the states in 1955 a record amount of surplus Federal property for educational and public health purposes.

The Radio Corporation of America is geared to roll a color-TV set a minute off assembly lines in Bloomington, Ind., and Indianapolis. A tour of the Bloomington plant last week and reports by R.C.A. executives left no doubt that the television industry kingpin is ready to swing into mass production of color sets at a moment's notice.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--A system to forecast the extent and the pattern of radioactive fall-out in an atomic attack has been expanded to the entire country.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 5-- Israel's plea for increased economic aid brought today American pledges to buy $11,154,150 of its bonds this year.

THE Ford Foundation's "Omnibus" achieved genu ine distinction over Channel 2 yesterday afternoon. The first of its series of three documentary dramatizations of the Constitution was imaginative television of high usefulness and compelling interest.
PARIS, Feb. 5--France's foreign trade balance improved considerably in 1955, with Germany remaining her most important commercial partner.

Miss Elinor Ruth Rohrlich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Rohrlich of 22 East Eighty-eighth Street, was married here yesterday to Bevin David Koeppel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Koeppel of Kings Point, L. I.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 5-- Wolf Ladejinsky, land reform export of a United States mission in South Vietnam, said today that he had committed a wrong in making an investment in a glass factory in Taiwan (Formosa).
MAX POLIKOFF is a concert violinist who is enthusiastic about contemporary music. He has played a good deal of it at his recitals and he has lent his skill to such ...
The Republic of Ireland, in which there is probably less private American industrial investment than in any other freeworld country, is moving vigorously to remedy the deficiency.

PARIS, Feb. 5--Deliberate ideological conversion is not a new phenomenon in Asia. As long ago as 1570 a shrewd Chinese statesman named Wan-chun-hu memorialized the Ming Emperor suggesting the Buddhist religion be spread among the menacing Mongolians to the north.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating said yesterday he would introduce soon a bill to liberalize the McCarren-Walter Immigration Act.

WOLFEBORO, N.H., Feb. 5-- William Roy Barnhill, executive secretary of the Lakes Region Association, died today in Huggins Hospital here. He was 71 years old and had been a resident of Alton, near Wolfeboro, for ten years.
The seeds of a new Third Avenue vastly different from the old are sprouting from the rubble and mudholes left by the wreckers of the elevated railroad.
Jussi Bjoerling will return to the Metropolitan Opera Feb. 17 for his first appearance since the 1953-54 season. He will appear in Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera," singing the role of Riccardo.
AMERICA'S security and the security of the free world depend to a large degree on our leadership in the field of nuclear energy.
A three-year pre-law course designed to give members of the bar a "common core of knowledge" was advocated yesterday by Dean William C. Warren of the Columbia University Schobl of Law.

OTTAWA, Feb. 5--While Prime Minister Eden rested today and prepared his address to a joint session of the Canadian Parliament tomorrow, there was a good deal of discussion about what had happened during his Washington visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--If observers of the Senate should be asked to survey the chamber and select the Senator least likely to create a controversy, Francis Case of South Dakota would very probably be the choice.

ATHENS, Feb. 5--A leftward trend in Greek opinion as a result of the unsettled Cyprus issue appears growing as Greece enters a crucial phase of the electoral contest. The election of a new Parliament comes two weeks from today.
John R. Crawford of Wynnewood, Pa., one of the nation's leading contract bridge stars, won the twenty-sixth annual Life Masters individual championship early today.
After two months as executive director of the Waterfront Commission, Michael J. Murphy thinks many of the agency's regulations are "too stringent."
The establishment of the World Jewish Migration Council to handle world-wide Jewish migration and resettlement programs was announced yesterday.

AUCKLAND, Feb. 5 (Reuters) --New Zealand newspapers are being printed for the first time on home-grown, home-produced newsprint. The country formerly was dependent on North American and British supplies.

Longshoremen under Harry Bridges in the San Francisco area earned an average of $110 weekly last year, according to statistics made public here yesterday.
FRESNO, Calif., Feb. 5--The California, Democratic Council convention gave an overwhelming endorsement today to Rich ard Richards for the United States Senatorial race.
Arab boycotts of Jewish concerns in this country were denounced and pleas were made for defensive arms for Israel at several Jewish meetings here yesterday.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 5--Leo Astrom, the ski-minded baker who turns out pastry for the Bear Mountain Inn's kitchen, continued to dominate the local jumping scene when he made a sweep of the three trophies at stake today.

Last Tuesday Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, acting at the request of Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson, assembled in the auditorium of the Sherman Hotel in Chicago a number of people representing the Federation's National Swine Industry Committee.

A total of thirteen associate professors at City College have been advanced to the rank of professor, it was announced yesterday. They are part of a group of forty-nine members of the college's faculty and staff who have received promotions.

New York City's Board of Education has been criticized in the past for not making a more aggressive fight for better salaries for public school teachers. Last June we commented that it was regrettable that Charles H. Silver, president of the board, had not rallied public opinion more forcibly during the city's budget-making process.
A new program plan now under discussion may open the way for Jackie Gleason's "The Honeymooners" and "Stage Show" to exchange time periods.
The Seafarers International Union is actively opposing a number of recent recommendations on labor-management relations made by the House Merchant Marine Committee.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 6--The Australian Council of Trades Unions was expected to call off the nation-wide dock strike after a meeting of its inter-state executive in Melbourne tomorrow.
LONDON, Jan. 28--British horse-racing is going through its annual winter soul-searching. Bookmakers, the handiest targets for reformers, call it the "silly season," but they take it seriously.

RIGHT now, when every sportswear and dress designer is attempting to create a "hot" number for summer selling, Virgil Stark, engineer and president of the North American Utility and Construction Corporation, has introduced a "cool" one--a refrigerated jacket.
Out-of-town buyers were enticed yesterday by a wide variety of merchandise exhibited at several trade shows here.
The seven-story building at 119-23 MacDougal Street, containing sip stores and twentyfour apartments has been sold by Stanley W. Kempner Son, Inc., to Loomis J. Grossman, real estate operator.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 6 (AP)-- The Nehru Government's sudden move toward nationalization of the life insurance industry has upset the Indian business community.
TRENTON, Feb. 6--Gov. Robert B. Meyner submitted to the Legislature today a record budget for the fiscal year 1956-57.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Members of Congress who wonder how much money has been used to influence their votes on the controversial natural gas bill will find no answer in the official reports of lobby spending.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 6-- Greek Cypriote school children continued to bedevil British soldiers today. They touched off a series of riots in Famagusta, the leading port of Cyprus.

The net income of American and Foreign Power, Inc., excluding subsidiaries, was about $9,910,000, or $1.37 a share, last year, Henry B. Sargent, president, told stockholders by letter yesterday. This compared with 1954 net of $1,11 a share and represented a gain of about $1,900,000.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 6-- French Premier Guy Mollet announced tonight he had accepted the resignation of Gen. Georges Catroux as a member of his Cabinet and as Minister Residing in Algeria.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6-- Heatly Courtonne Dulles, chairman of the investment banking firm of Janney, Dulles Co., died today at his home in Villanova. He was 88 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The task of presenting history with a fair balance of all the available facts, uncolored by the personal bias of the historian, is one of the most difficult labors of the pen and a severe test of the human conscience.

CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy, Feb. 6--(UP)--Nikolai Romanov, the Soviet Sports Minister, boasted today that Russia's top ranking in the Winter Olympics was "what we came for" and forecast the same thing would occur at the Melbourne summer games.
A shipload of goodwill from New England sailed for Trinidad, B.W.I., yesterday aboard the Ocean Monarch.
ON Saturday, June 24, 1950, I was in Independence, Mo., to spend the week with my family and to attend to some personal family business.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (UP)-- A coroner's jury ruled today that the wreck of a two-card Santa Fe Diesel commuter train Jan. 22 with the loss of thirty lives was an unavoidable accident without criminal negligence on the part of the train crew.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 6--The merged labor movement will decide in the next week whether to hold a special convention this year to endorse a Presidential candidate.

LONDON, Feb. 6--Occupation rights to a narrow strip of Essex marshlands have been won by British atomic planners at the expense of the United States Air Force and British ordnance. Conservationists who had opposed the atomic planners' entry may find that they have won a victory after all.

Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., one of the country's leading companies of amateur performers of Gilbert and Sullivan, will give "The Gondoliers" on April 4, 5, 6 and 7 at the Hunter College Playhouse, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.
ALBANY, Feb. 6--Republican legislators agreed at a party conference tonight on two choices for three impending vacancies on the Board of Regents.
A mother filed a $500,000 claim against the city yesterday for the alleged "forcible" injection of her 7-year-old son with Salk anti-polio vaccine.

Individual issues rose anal fell yesterday, some by considerable amounts, but the stock market as a whole was without direction. At the close, a few more issues were lower than higher and The New York Times combined average had fallen 0.51 point to 318.50.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Attorneys for Paul Robeson, the singer, urged the United States Court of Appeals today to rule State Department passport regulations unconstitutional.
A special six-man committee yesterday voted to recommend changes in the rules regarding the selection of new members to baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 (AP)-- Temple overcame a stubborn Duquesne team, 63--48, tonight to ring up its fifteenth victory against one defeat. The Dukes trailed, 26--23, at the half in losing their first game at the Gardens this season.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 6-- The Soviet Ambassador to the United States was quoted here tonight as having said the So viet Union favored "a peaceful settlement of the Arab-Israeli problem."

MIAMI, Feb. 6--The D. and H. Stable's Needles and Mrs. Anson A. Bigelow's Nail, the top-ranking 2-year-olds of 1955, flew silk for the first time this year in Hialeah's seventh race today. They took a beating.

The New York Knickerbockers will try to snap a three-game losing streak tonight when they meet the Boston Celtics in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 14 points (10 to 70 cents a bale) today.

Stockholders of Consolidated Freightways, Inc., yesterday approved a two-for-one split of the common stock and the redemption of all the outstanding preferred stock. Both measures are effective March 15. The date of record for the split is March 1.

LONDON, Feb. 6--Britain has agreed to an accelerated timetable for Malayan independence within the British Commonwealth. The decision came at a conference with Malayan representatives that ended here today.

Members of the Welfare and Health Council of New York voted yesterday to replace the thirty-one-year-old organization with a limited membership corporation, the Greater New York Community Council, Inc.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 6--A flood-control program for Westchester was submitted to the county Board of Supervisors today by its legislative committee.
OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (UP)--Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent announced in Parliament today that the Government had lifted its embargo on arms exports to the Middle East.

Pepsi-Cola Company's newfound bounce is not confined to the bottle. In the last five year sales have effervesced up to a 112 per cent increase, white net, profits have risen from $1,271,919 to a heady $9,600,000. Earnings per share have climbed from 28 cents in 1950 to an estimated $1.60 last year.
LONDON, Feb. 6--Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, steadfastly refused today to comment on the attack on the party leadership made by Aneurin Bevan Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP)-- Trustees of the Robert A. Taft Memorial Foundation formally approved today the design of a bell tower to honor the Republican Senator from Ohio.

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 6--Mr. Neff, 47 years old, before the Case incident, was not widely known outside of Lexington, where he practices law. A native of Lexington, he served three and a half years in the Air Force in World War II.
The Child Study Association of America, Inc., whose goal is a wholesome family life through a program of parent education, has planned a theatre party for the evening of March 19.
The city of Waterbury, Conn., is planning to borrow $4,650,000 in the public market on Feb. 15 to finance school, public works and water system improvements.
A vote in the United Nations Security Council yesterday made it reasonably certain that the next new U.N. member--the seventyseventh--will be the newly fledged Republic of the Sudan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 --The National Labor Relations Board has voted unanimously to dismiss the petition of the Commercial Film Producers Association to bar on an industry-wide basis its member companies.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Edmund F. Mansure, General Services Administrator.
Mrs. Lorelle Hearst, former wife of William Randolph Hearst Jr., publisher, reinstituted before the Waterfront Cbmmission yesterday charges of an attempted shakedown by a waterfront baggage porter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)-- The official opening of the 1956 major league baseball season today was moved up one day, leading to speculation that President Eisenhower planned a trip out of town on Tuesday, April 17.

Joseph M. Rumshinsky, leading composer for the Yiddish stage in America, died yesterday at Kew Gardens General Hospital in Queens after a gall bladder operation. He was 74 years old. He resided at 85-02 139th Street, Kew Gardens.

The New York money market continues to be tight. A rate of 2 per cent still holds for transactions in Federal funds, that is, balances held in the Federal Reserve System for the reserve accounts of member commercial banks.
RICHARD LINDNER is not a surrealist, or what is called a magic realist, yet there are shades of both schools in his work at the Betty Parsons Gallery, 15 East Fiftyseventh Street.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6--The International Union of Electrical Workers accepted today a new Federal plan for settling the 113-day Westinghouse Electric Corporation strike. The company agreed to the proposal last night.
A new name has been proposed for Third Avenue to complete the change in identity predicted as a result of the removal of the elevated railroad.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 6--The West German Government said today that it would refuse further cash contributions to the support of Allied armed forces stationed in West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Secretary of State Dulles said today that arms alone could not guarantee the security of Israel or preserve peace in the Middle East.

Dr. Georg Oenslager of Akron, Ohio, a noted research chemist who formerly was employed by the B.F. Goodrich Company, died of a heart attack Sunday aboard the Italian liner Conte Biancamano. He was 82 years old.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 6 (UP) --A plane caught in a sand storm crashed today near Habbaniyah, killing the pilot and two American passengers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The White House today designated Feb. 14 as the date for consultations on President Eisenhower's next full-scale medical examination.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6 --Loew's, Inc., plans to enlarge its theatre holdings overseas, Arthur Loew, president, said today. At the same time, he predicted that it soon might be possible for the company to double the amount of its annual motion-picture earnings in the foreign market.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6-- Democratic House leaders agreed today to try again to put much of the cost of the long-term $36,500,000,000 highway building program upon the principal users of the roads.

Charles Barker Petrie of 270 West Eleventh Street, editor of the life insurance department of The Weekly Underwriter, an international insurance publication, died of a heart attack on Sunday at a doctor's office. His ale was 55.

Trust assets held bye the nation's banks, now an estimated $50,000,000,000, will grow to $200,000,000,000, or even $300,000,000,000, in "our lifetime," it was predicted yesterday.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 6--Mrs. Martha Shaw Youngs of 219 Audley Street, a teacher and principal in the New York school system for forty years, died Saturday at the Garden Terrace Nursing Home, Chatham. She was 86 years old. Mrs. Youngs was the widow of Frederick Danforth Youngs.
Sales and operating revenues of the Atlantic Refining Company and consolidated subsidiaries last year rose to $513,035,000 from $489,747,000, but earnings declined $1,887,000.
William S. White, a member of the Washington bureau of The New York Times and author of "The Taft Story," is at work on a book about the Senate.

Just about-fifty years ago a 17year-old Polish boy played his first piano recital in the United States. Tonight Artur Rubinstein plays the first of a series of five concerts, to be given within only two weeks, in which he will present seventeen major concertos by eleven great composers.

Fifty scholars and relatives of Aaron Burr met last night in the historic Fraunces Tavern and tossed off toasts to the proposition that Burr was a better man then he is generally thought to have been.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Tuesday, Feb. 7--The University of Alabama's first Negro student was ordered excluded until further notice late last night for the "safety" of herself and other students and faculty members.
Perry Mason, the fictional lawyer created by Erle Stanley Gardner, will be the subject of a new one-hour film program next fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The Senate, casting aside suggestions that it was voting under a cloud of suspicion, passed the natural gas bill tonight, 53 to 38.
Better management of advertising is essential to assure that sales and advertising pull their weight in expanding business. Above all else, an advertising manager must be a "sound business man.'
ALBANY, Feb. 6--Republican legislators tonight voiced "shock and disgust" at Governor Harriman's reference to them as a "do-nothing, good-for-nothing" body.

Two roundhouse rights to the body and one to the head brought a fifth-round knockout for Miguel Berrios, Puerto Rican featherweight, over Bobby Courchesne of Holyoke, Mass., at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The bout was scheduled for ten rounds.
Joseph C.J. Strahan of 929 Park Avenue, a retired hosiery manufacturer, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

The Soviet Government has protested to the United States, Turkey and West Germany against the release from the outside world of both official meteorological and unofficial "freedom campaign" balloons which penetrate its own airspace and that of its satellite colonies.

Assemblyman John A. Britting and his wife Edna refused on constitutional grounds yesterday to answer questions relating to an investigation of land deals in Suffolk County. They appeared before J. Irwin Shapiro, State Investigation Commissioner, at Mr. Shapiro's office, 270-Broadway.
On-the-spot arrests for culpably negligent motorists involved in serious accidents were ordered yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Ken nedy.
Thirteen new members have joined the National Institute of Arts and Letters. Malcolm Cowley, institute president, announced their election yesterday.

FEBRUARY, it has been said, is the month of birthdays, an apt time to talk of birthday cakes. Tradition, which is ancient since the Roman Emperor Hadrian served birthday cakes, insists such loaves be lit with candles.

A clergyman accepted yesterday the post of rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights. But whether he will ever be installed or preach from the pulpit now occupied by the Rev. William Howard Melish was still a question.

Gasoline stocks increased 3,709,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 182,656,000 barrels, compared with 178,947,000 a week earlier and 171,331,000 a year ago.

Food processors and distributors were held not responsible yesterday for the price spread between what the farmer gets and what the consumer pays for food. Instead, said Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, higher wages, taxes and transportation costs were the chief culprits for the increased gap.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--An authoritative warning that Republican majorities in the Legislature will not approve any gasoline tax increase was issued tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The book value of manufacturing and trade inventories at the end of December was estimated at $80,000,000,000. This was an increase of $5,000,000,000 compared with the end of 1954, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce said today.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 8 --University of Alabama students joined today in deploring the violence that had driven out the university's first Negro student.
HARTFORD, Feb. 8--Connecticut's Deputy Commissioner of Motor Vehicles resigned today.
The Court of Special Sessions ruled yesterday that unless willfulness was proved, a defendant could not be criminally convicted for failure to file a state income tax return.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Government reported a seasonal drop in the value of construction activity last month but said the total of $2,850,000,000 still was higher than any previous January on record. It was 1 per cent higher in value than the previous record established in January last year.

The objective of "60 million jobs" was regarded as a visionary goal when it was in the slogan stage about a decade ago. This is hardly surprising when one recalls the circumstances that largely conditioned men's thinking in those days.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8 --Paramount has agreed to give Yul Brynner a chance to direct as well as star in a picture. No story has been decided upon.
The Queens District Attorney's office is investigating suspected ticket scalping practices at this city's two maior airports

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 8-- The trustees of Dartmouth College have authorized plans for a social and creative arts center for students. It will be named for Ernest Martin Hopkins, president emeritus of Dartmouth.
A bronze lion, traditional symbol of Columbia College, was awarded last night to Frank S. Hogan, District Attorney of New York County.
The Port of New York in 1955 racked up its best six-month record in three years for general cargo in foreign trade.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--A Republican by-election victory in Queens gave Senator Walter J. Mahoney hope today that Republicans would have a two-thirds majority in the new State Senate to be elected in the fall.
The Sigma Phi Society, one of the oldest college fraternities, cleared the way yesterday for the initiation of two Negro honor students at Williams College.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 8 --What prompted a soft spoken, former high school English teacher, already a graduate of a four-year college, to become the first Negro to attend classes as a student at the previously allwhite University of Alabama?
BOTH European and American painters participate in this week's group exhibitions. The show at the New Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue. justly entitled "Historic Modern Art, is outstanding.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 8 --Capt. Fred Muller, U.S.N.R., retired, an early leader in radio and electronics, died here Monday of a heart attack. His age was 65. Before his retirement from the Navy five years ago he had resided in Ramsey, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The National Council of AmericanSoviet Friendship was ordered today to register with the Attorney General as a Communistfront organization.
The New York Rangers scored in the waning minutes of the last period to tie the Boston Bruins, 3--3, in their National Hockey League match at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--A former Soviet Union secret agent who fled to the West told Senate investigators today that Russia had agents working out of the Soviet Embassy here and the Soviet delegation to the United Nations in New York.

MADRID, Feb. 8--University students fought today with fists and sticks against members of the Falange party, some whom were armed with blackjacks and brass knuckles. Several youths were injured slightly. It was expected that the university would be closed tomorrow and classes not be resumed probably until Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Well, sir, it was as plain to everybody else around here as it should have been to young Tom Hennings of Missouri that old Mr. George of Georgia wasn't going to be shoved out of...

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 8 (Reuters)--Elementary school children joined today in violent demonstrations calling for the union of Cyprus and Greece. They damaged school buildings, destroyed British flags, smashed portraits of the Royal family and hoisted Greek flags.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP)--Jane Nelson, the runner-up in the 1955 national amateur, and most of the other favorites advanced through the first round of the women's Palm Beach golf tournament today.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, Feb. 8--Thousands of Moroccans poured into downtown Casablanca from the city's native quarters today to cheer Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef. He is here for a three-day official visit.

A BRITISH poet rhapsodized "mighty roast beef" and spoke of "how it ennobled our hearts and enriched our blood. Three centuries later on another continent; roast beef extends the same hospitable invitation to appetites.
CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Robert Morss Lovett, stormy figure in education and government for nearly sixty years, died today in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 85 years old on Christmas Day.

Book reviewers came under the scrutiny of seven authors yesterday, not all of it unfavorable. The out-of-town reviewers who made up the audience took the turn-about with good grace, especially since they were admitted to be "enormously vital to the author."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The United States halted today the launching of weather balloons from West Germany and Turkey because of a Soviet complaint.

Eyebrows were raised in Wall Street yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange issued its latest "insiders list." It showed that Alexander Rittmaster, a director of Montgomery Ward Co., notified the Exchange on Jan. 31 that he had sold 8,100 Ward shares as long ago as Sept. 19, 1955.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 8 --Organized employers and workers agreed today on a 4 per cent increase in industrial wages and in salaries of white collar workers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Substantial, important increases in rainfall have resulted from cloud "seeding," the President's advisory committee on weather control reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Ralph (Tiger) Jones, 157 pounds, Yonkers, took everything Tony Baldoni had to offer tonight and then rallied to knock out the youngster from Wilkes-Barre, Pa., at 2:30 of the sixth round.

No one interested in the welfare of New York City's public school children can escape a feeling of concern over the unrest among teachers because of their unsatisfactory salaries. The situation has recently been described at length in our news columns. Teacher morale is said to be at a new low. A boycott of extracurricular activities continues and is about to be intensified.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 8-- Many of the changes in Vietnam during the last year can be traced on Saigon's hot and sunlit streets.
The Standard Oil Company of California will spend more than $350,000,000 for building and exploration this year, R.G. Follis, chairman, announced yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia Feb. 8 (Reuters)--The Federal Cabinet today charted emergency measures in the event that 24,000 striking Australian longshoremen fail to end their crippling seventeen-day walkout by Tuesday as expected.
Owen Tolbert-Hewitt, an actor who was appearing in the Broadway comedy "No Time for Sergeants," died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 58 years old. He had entered the hospital a week ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--President Eisenhower said tonight that restoration of rigid farm price supports would "defeat the main object" of creating a soil bank to cut crop surpluses.
ALBANY, Feb. 8--The Republican chairman of a special legislative committee predicted today that the Holz plan for indemnifying victims of uninsured autos would never receive legislative approval.
Furman's basketball team, featuring the high-scoring Darrell Floyd, will oppose New York University in the second game of a college triple-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The announcement that Leon Barzin will be the artistic director of the Symphony Foundation of America focuses anew on the contribution of this group of music makers.

LONDON, Feb. 8--The United States, Britain and France were reported today to be preparing to ask Chancellor Konrad Adenauer directly for continuation of West German payments toward the three powers forces in Germany after May 5.

Bud Phillips, the ski-school head at Mad River, Glen in Waitsfield, Vt., is a versatile chap. He runs a charter boat business, shoots golf in the low seventies and can even teach rock climbing if the necessity arises.
The Reeves Instrument Corporation, subsidiary of the Dynamics Corporation of America, has taken over a $5,000,000 plant and added facilities at Roosevelt Field, Mineola, L.I.
Maury McDermott, a 27-yearold left-handed pitcher, yesterday became a Yankee through a seven-player deal between the American League champions and the Washington Senators.
The forty-sixth anniversary of the founding of the Boy Scouts of America was marked here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Marriner S. Eccles, former Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, offered a package of suggestions today on monetary and credit techniques, but generally backed the past and current policy of the present board.

The political news from Peru has been disturbing and disappointing in recent weeks. Everyone who has the interests of democracy in Latin America at heart has been hoping that President Odria will seize the great opportunity that faces him to hold free and democratic elections for President in June.
JERUSALEM, Feb. 8--Israel is tensely awaiting the United States' decision concerning her request that she be allowed to purchase fighter aircraft.
UNION CITY, N.J., Feb. 8-- The former executive director of this city's housing authority was arrested here today by Federal agents.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 8 (AP)--The Dairymen's League Cooperative Association Inc. today announced the purchase of Cloverdale Farms Co., Inc. and six affiliates.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--The Assembly Committee on Ethics will investigate the conduct of Assemblyman John A. Britting. Mr. Britting, a Lindenhurst, L.I., Republican, refused to answer questions about allegedly fraudulent land deals.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 8--President Eisenhower today called for sweeping changes in the immigration laws.
IT seems like old times to have Edward G. Robinson back.

The sixteen-story office building at 45 West Forty-fifth Street has been sold by the Ainsley Realty Company to Henry Goelet, real estate investor and builder. The new owner plans to install air conditioning and otherwise to modernize the structure.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 8 (UP)--The New York Knickerbockers scored their second straight victory tonight by defeating the Rochester Royals, 102--97, in a National Basketball Association game.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--A special Senate committee gained a clear field today for its investigation to determine whether an improper attempt had been made to influence a Senator's vote on the natural gas bill.

Elmer Rice's "The Adding Machine" will be revived at the Phoenix Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. The play is considered by theatre students to be an outstanding example of the form known in the theatre of the early Twenties as "expressionism."
The American Foundation for Allergic Diseases announced yesterday plans to raise $1,100,000 to support basic scientific research on allergic diseases.
AMRITSAR, India, Feb. 8-- The Government of the State of Bombay still is engaged in trying to minimize the extent of the riots that crippled the city last month.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 8-- The chief administrator of United Nations Relief to Arab refugees from Palestine declared here today that his 'agency would continue to do its utmost to aid those exiles, but he stressed the relative scantiness of its resources.

BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 8 (UP)--The United States Olympic hockey team, paced by a four-goal effort by Dick Meredith, scored a 12-5 victory over a squad of Swiss Olympians and Canadian professionals tonight before 6,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- Top officials of a scientific group studying civil defense said today that the present national effort was a failure.

Robert E. Condon, city Director of Civil Defense, reported yesterday that New York's Civil Defense system was being changed to meet the challenge of the nuclear and missile era. New consideration will be given to participation in disaster relief.

Departmental charges were filed yesterday by the Board of Higher Education against Philip P. Steitz, suspended assistant business manager at Hunter College, who has been accused by the police of stealing $48,000 from a college fund over the last five years.

LONDON, Feb. 8--The stock markets opened weakly today and prices fell. At the lower prices, buyers showed signs of returning, but only the South African gold mining stocks, Which had dropped sharply, recovered their early losses.
Bolivian Ambassador victor Andrade appealed yesterday for a better understanding by American business of improved private investment opportunities in his country, especially in the petroleum field.

LONDON, Feb. 8 (UP)--Fears of an American boycott of British rings were ended today by the world light heavyweight champion, Archie Moore, after the British Boxing Board of Controls had scheduled a "full hearing" for Feb. 22 into last night's stormy decision against Kid Gavilan of Cuba.

COMMISSIONED to write a piece for the Boston Sym phony Orchestra's current seventy-fifth season, Aaron Copland turned to a work he had written for the orchestra's fiftieth anniversary. "Symphonic Ode," in a revision made twenty-five years after its original composition, had its New York premiere last night at a Boston Symphony concert conducted by Charles Munch at Carnegie Hall.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 11 to 23 points (55 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday.

The twenty-eighth commencement exercises of Queens College were held last night on the Flushing campus. Degrees were conferred on 163 women and ninety men.

DUKE SNIDER is normally a serious man. His sense of humor is on the droll side. But the Duke of Flatbush arrived at the baseball writers' dinner the other night with a new baseball cap, one he had designed and made to order. It was a cap with two peaks, one fore and the other aft.
THE blue marlin are providing activity and excite ment for the anglers now gathered at Bimini in the Bahamas. Although the fish are not giants, they are quite plentiful.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8-- The Federal Maritime Administration moved today to open the Great Lakes to American ships carrying international cargo between this country and Western Europe.
Committee members working for the success of a benefit performance of "Pipe Dream" were entertained at a tea given yesterday afternoon by Mrs. George Richards at her home, 1088 Park Avenue.

Bankers believe they can get more customers for their trust services through solicitation of the "mass market" and through stepped-up competition with individuals, such as lawyers, who also offer such services.

Three hundred motorists will receive "valentines" in the mail from the Police Department in the next few days. They will be notified that the summonses they received last Monday for moving violations are to be returnable next Tuesday, St. Valentine's Day, instead of Monday.

ABOARD U.S.S. EASTWIND, in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica Thursday, Feb. 9--The Navy plane missing since last Friday with seven men aboard was found early today in the area of the Alexandra Mountains on Edward VII Peninsula, northeast of Little America V.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--Grain trading during much of today's session on the Board of Trade was extremely dull. Prices sagged a little early in all pits, but declines were mostly small. Commission absorption caused partial recoveries.

MIAMI, Feb. 8--The $20,425 Florida Breeders Stakes, for 2-year-olds foaled in the state, was the chief divertissement at the Hialeah horse park today. It was won with ease by the 3-to-5 favorite, King Hairan, who now has a three-for-three record in Hialeah contests.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UP)-- The Senate voted late today to extend the Federal sugar program six years and give domestic producers a 55 per cent share of the future growth of the United States market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today announced allocation of $38,932,065 for improvement of 319 airports during the rest of the fiscal year ending June 30. Puerto Rico's economy has more than trebled since 1940, according to an official survey released yesterday by the New York office of the island Commonwealth's Economic Development Administration.

Commodity futures prices were irregularly lower yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Potatoes registered the largest volume of the year and the domestic sugar contract had its second most active day. Most other markets were dull.

The Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third largest automotive producer, achieved the highest dollar and unit sales in its history last year, and the third largest earnings.
Electric Bond and Share Company's 1955 net income, before a prior year's tax credit of $376,125, was $6,854,470, or $1.31 a share.

For the second straight week, ski resort operators in the Berkshires of Massachusetts yesterday found themselves preparing for a busy week-end. Although mild temperatures were forecast, it was generally believed that the mountains had enough cover to insure good sport.

A stranger strolling through the canyons of Manhattan's financial district at mid-morning on any workday might well think a mass exodus was under way. He would encounter hordes of workers streaming from office buildings.

Oils led the stock market yesterday down to the lowest levels since Jan. 27 in the sharpest one-day dip since mid-November.

America's preparations for the Olympic Games do not lie altogether in muscle and striving on the country's playing fields. Some of them are being carried on right across the Hudson River at Hoboken in the sphere of hydrodynamic research.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa yesterday received the tools he said he needed to add about $10,000,000 to the annual revenue from the city sales tax.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- The nation's major railroads had an estimated net income of $917,000,000 last year, the Association of American Railroads said today. $240,000,000 over the 1954 level.
PARIS, Feb. 9--France's new Republican Front Government has stumbled badly at its first step.
ALBANY, Feb. 9--A bill proposing a $250,000,000 bond issue for expansion of the State University was introduced in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Feb.9--President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles have assured the European Coal and Steel Community that the United States will support the projected European atomic energy authority.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9--March and May wheat were strong today on the Board of Trade.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--A bipartisan bill to add twenty-six justices to the State Supreme Court made its long-awaited appearance in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The former troopship La Guardia was sold today to a new American steamship company for $3,850,438.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Representative Chauncey W. Reed, Republican of Illinois, died to day at Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 65 years old.

PARIS, Feb. 9--The French Foreign Minister, Christian Pineau, said today that France could accept the return of the Saar to German sovereignty only on condition that there be safeguards for French economic interests in the Saar.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP)--Blustery snowstorms and bitter cold swept today across a 2,500-mile front from Norway's North Cape to Turkey. The toll of death traced to the cold rose to 208.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Justice Department will file an amended complaint tomorrow in a four-year-old civil suit against four large oil companies.

LONDON, Feb. 10--Hollywood was accused today in the House of Commons of having pushed the British film industry into a small corner of its own home market. Americans were accused of "nationalistic" bias against British films in the United States market.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 10 --The Mills Building at Main Street and Ocean Avenue, was destroyed early today by a fire that caused damage unofficially estimated at more than $2,000,000. The brick-andframe structure is a landmark in the heart of this village's business district.

LONDON, Feb. 10--A further fall today in Government issues --to which the decline in sterling contributed--carried the war loan to a new low level. A fall of fifteen shillings ($2.10) carried the loan to 72 17s 6d (204.40) for the 100 ($280) issue.
SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 10 (UP) --Jim Hearn, a pitcher for the New York Giants, fired a par 72 today to gain the first-round lead in the annual Early Wynn baseball players golf tournament.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 10-- The police and bad weather broke up a demonstration by European Algerians here today as Robert Lacoste arrived and took up his post as French Cabinet Minister Residing in Algeria. DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP)--Control of the Motor Products Corporation, whose management was preserved by a drive of its 4,000 union employes' two years ago, was in new hands today.

M. F. Estates, Inc., has purchased the fifty-nine-family apartment house at 2785 University Avenue, the Bronx. The seller was a client of Leepson Rubman, attorneys. The sale was subject to mortgages totaling $305,000, according to Ehrlich, Corso, Feldman Co., brokers.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 10--A rift has developed between Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano and Finance Minister Fritz Schaeffer over Herr Schaeffer's refusal to continue West Germany's cash contributions to the support of Allied troops after May 5.
Brooklyn College's basketball team scored its second victory of the season over City College tonight, routing the Beavers, 92--70, at City's Wingate Gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10-- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, asserted today he was a little more confident about his forecast that President Eisenhower would seek a second term "if he feels able." .

Isaac Logart, a welterweight boxer from Camaguey, Cuba, gained the decision over Ramon Fuentes of Los Angeles in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The conflict was a close one and the victory went to the Cuban by a split vote.
VALLETTA, Malta, Feb. 10-- The struggle for the hearts and minds of the people of Malta between Prime Minister and Archbishop reached a climax today, the eve of a two-day referendum.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10--March wheat edged up to another seasonal high today, and old crop futures showed a firm undertone.
TOKYO, Feb. 10--The new Japanese Ambassador to Washington, Masayuki Tani, reiterated today the need for closer Japanese-United States relations to ward off steady Communist expansion in the Far East.
HONG KONG, Feb. 10--A new thirty-letter Latin alphabet was announced today by the Peiping Government for "discussion and trial" in its campaign to modernize China's ancient "picture language."

The Queens County Bar Association has purchased a site for its new headquarters in Jamaica, Queens. The vacant plot, about 60 by 97 feet at the southeast corner of Ninetieth Road and 148th Street, was purchased from Esther Gross and Dorothy Siegelbaum.
WASHINGTON, Feb.10--Senator Estes Kefauver declined today to say outright whether he favored a proposed ban on Federal aid to public schools that remained segregated.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Excbange moved irregularly yesterday to close 11 points (55 cents a bale) up to 12 points (60 cents a bale) off.

MIAMI, Feb. 10--Delta, flying the orange silks of Arthur B. Hancock's Claiborne Farm, won the filly-and-mare feature at the Hialeah cavalry post today. She was the $4.90-for-$2 favorite. Steve Brooks rode her.
ANKARA, Turkey, Feb. 9-- Recent suggestions for improvement of Turkish-Soviet relations, as reported in Pravda, have not impressed Government leaders here.

But if you ask him for a walking record--any type of walking record--you will get a puzzled glance.

PARIS, Feb. 10--The British idea of a union of Western Europe and the British Commonwealth has been received with skepticism by advocates of European integration here. The idea was reported in a London dispatch published in The New York Times Wednesday.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 11 (UP)-- The kindly, spinster bookkeeper of a savings firm, dipping into the till over the years to make donations to charity, friends and relatives, may have made off with $2,800,000--more than double the Brink's robbery loot --auditors said today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)-- The Treasury said today that sales of "E" and "H" savings bonds, those most commonly purchased by the public, amounted to $572,490,000 in January. Redemptions amounted to some $450,000,000, leaving sales excess of $122,000,000 for the month, the announcement said.
