THE New York Chamber Ensemble, a group of mu sicians from the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, gave its second concert of the season Saturday evening at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.
Need help in preparing your Federal income tax return? Here is a three-step procedure suggested by the local district directors of the Internal Revenue Service:
ALBANY, Feb. 12--The cost to government of pensions, welfare and institutional care for New York State's aged has increased almost five times in the last decade.
The House Merchant Marine Committee, Herbert C. Bonner, chairman, has done a fine job in its investigation of labor-management problems both on the ships and on shore.
ALBANY, Feb. 12--Robert Moses said today he would try to build the Niagara power project with or without Congress' permission.

Governor Harriman entered the battle over civil rights yesterday with one of the strongest stands on desegregation so far. He demanded "vigorous" Federal action against those who kept a Negro woman student out of the University of Alabama.

It was quiet downstairs in Madison Square Garden yesterday, but it won't be quiet starting this morning. The eightieth Westminster Kennel Club show will begin then and the basement benching area will be shattered by the sound of 2,560 dogs. The event will continue through tomorrow.

LONDON, Feb. 12--British socialism celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the parliamentary Labor party today on a familiar note. Led by Aneurin Bevan, the left wing tore into the moderate leaders while spokesmen for the latter replied with restraint.

Radio station WNYC began its seventeenth annual American Music Festival yesterday afternoon. The first of the 130 programs it will broadcast during the next ten days was a concert by an orchestra consisting mostly of strings.

William Haber and Harold M. Levinson have written a most disturbing book. Although they applaud the adoption of technological advances by the construction industry, they leave the reader with no possible doubt that its productivity is falling steadily farther behind that of industry as a whole.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 12 --The Hollywood A.F.L. Film Council called today for a "nation-wide consumer boycott campaign" against the motion picture "Daniel Boone."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 12-- Finance Minister Fritz Schaeffer has won the informal consent of most of his Cabinet colleagues for discontinuance of cash contributions to the support of the Allied armed forces in West Germany.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Feb. 12-- The marriage of Miss Patricia Ruth Edelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney P. Fdelman, to Second Lieut. Alan Jay Schwartz, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Schwartz of Woodmere, took place this evening.

Universities and colleges that practice segregation were branded "propaganda institutions" by the Rev. Joe Earl Elmore at a chapel meeting here yesterday. He spoke as assistant minister after the main service at the Methodist church of St. Paul

The Senate Committee on Agriculture has elected by a vote of 8 to 7 to ignore the President's plea for retention of the flexible supports provided for in the Agricultural Act of 1954. High rigid supports, as we have frequently pointed out here, are strictly a throwback to the war period.

LONDON, Feb. 12--Harold Macmillan in his first official speech as Chancellor of the Exchequer provided a brilliant diagnosis of the disease afflicting Great Britain's economy, but he refrained from prescribing any immediate cure.
Hyperbolically speaking, a couple of television personalities may have, done more for the American merchant marine in the last year than the industry's entire promotional budget.

Raymond R. MacLean, Suffolk County Purchasing Agent since August, 1954 told state investigators that he looked upon his post as "something of an extra job." It is one of five public posts he holds in the county.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 12--The Connecticut and New Jersey ski-jumping titleholders tied for top honors today as the United States Eastern Ski Association conducted its annual junior championship here for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10--Following are the votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week that ended Feb. 10:

WASHINGTON Feb. 12--The British are likely to decide soon whether to enter into direct negotiations with Saudi Arabia about Buraimi, according to diplomatic reports. It appears certain that Britain will not again resort to arbitration.
THE Violin, Viola and Violoncello Teachers Guild, Inc., presented a program of contemporary music at Carl Fischer Hall yesterday afternoon.
SO-CALLED atonal music still has the power to goad a fairly sophisticated audience to righteous indignation and withering sarcasm. At least,

Track and field fans who like their competition spiced with controversy went away happy from last Saturday's New York Athletic Club games. For the railbirds who insist on records, there also was satisfaction. Five assorted marks were broken or tied.

THE charges of misfeasance in Suffolk County made yesterday by J. Irwin Shapiro were not the first accusations of official wrongdoing made by the former Domestic Relations justice since he took the office on Jan. 1, 1955, by appointment of Governor Harriman.
J.P. Stine has been named East Coast zone manager for the Thor Power Tool Company, Aurora, Ill. He will have offices in Newark, N.J.

WILHELM BACKHAUS will be 72 years old next month, but he played five Beethoven piano sonatas at Hunter College Saturday night as if he were 35. Technically, he had the ease and security of a young daredevil of the keyboard.
The Early Admissions Program, which produces teen-age college graduates, has been adjudged a success at Columbia College.

A new Lincoln book that develops a fresh theme is "Lincoln and the Tools of War," by Robert V. Bruce. Basing it on the Civil War records at the National Archives and on Lincoln's own papers, the author describes Lincoln's interest in the Ordnance Bureau and the improvement of war equipment.
Prices of cotton in the domestic market last Week continued to move into higher ground for the third successive week.
LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP)-- Western Europe reported a death toll of 292 today as the worst cold wave of the century entered its third week.
Net income of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) increased last year to $23,008,000 from $18,527,085 earned in 1954, according to the preliminary annual report released today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)-- Prolonged delays and bureaucratic quibbling threaten to stall completely the military housing program voted by Congress last year, a House subcommittee reported today.
GLENSIDE, Pa., Feb. 12--Dr. Mary Kendrick Benedict, educator and physician, died here Friday at the home of a sister, Miss Florence L. Benedict. Her age was 81.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Feb. 12--A resurgence of terrorist action here has followed the flight of Salah ben Youssef, dissident nationalist leader, to Tripoli to escape police action against himself and his followers.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Feb. 12-- Mr. and Mrs. Fernand Auberjonois have announced the engagement of Mrs. Auberjonois' daughter, Miss Marie-Laure Frank, to John 'Michael Degener. He is the son of Mrs. Porges Degener of New York and George L. Degener of Millerton.

New Yorkers who are indignant at racial discrimination in the South may wisely take note of a report on racial relations here, made public over the week-end by the Protestant Council of the City of New York.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 12-- Suffolk County is engaged in a struggle over the merits of a Republican-sponsored bill to modernize the county's form of government.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 12 (UP) --John B. Hollister, foreign aid director, reported today that the Soviet bloc increased purchases of "hard goods" by $25,000,000 the first six months after Western trade controls were relaxed in 1954.
Ramon Monzant, a righthander, and Joe Margoneri, a southpaw pitcher, are the latest signers of contracts with the Giants.

ALBANY, Feb. 12--A $5,000,000 program of state loans to rehabilitate tenements will be laid before the Legislature tomorrow night. The particular aim is to encourage immediate action toward eliminating of substandard living conditions in some areas of New York City.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 12-- Adlai E. Stevenson called today for removal of the desegregation issue from the Presidential campaign.
THIS Leap Year of 1956 is scarcely beyond knee britches, yet it is already decrepit from the fun-poking it invariably receives as the "open season" for female courting.
Major league baseball officials and the National Broadcasting Company are nearing an agreement to cooperate in televising a "Cavalcade of Baseball" early in April.
CECIL BEATON, England's No. 1 photographer of beautiful women, thinks "American gels" and fashion designers will go all out soon for the stately lady look of pre-World War I.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 12 --Forty dinghies, the largest Frostbite fleet ever to race at Larchmont Yacht Club, turned out today. One boat was disabled before the first start but thirty-nine crews enjoyed the finest competition of the season.
Rates on a number of commodities in the steamship charter market dropped slightly last week.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 12--Yugoslav sources maintained today that President Tito's Government was resisting many blandishments from the Soviet Union. They added, however, that the pressure was mounting and that the Yugoslav regime was not always in a position to say "no."
OSLO, Norway, Feb. 12 (AP)-- Russia picked up today where it left off in the Winter Olympics by taking the first three places in the world speed-skating championships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--The chairman of the Senate Elections subcommittee pledged today anexpanded investigation of campaign contributions. He said his group would start the inquiry "immediately" after a special committee had finished its task.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 12 --This was Race Relations Sunday at many of the churches throughout the country.
The year of the monkey, a year that augurs well for mankind, got off to a fine and clamorous start in Chinatown yesterday.
Ethel Linder Refiner, who will produce the musical version of Voltaire's "Candide" on Broadway this fall, is trying to sign Alfred Drake for the starring role of Dr. Pangloss.
This is the week on the calendar that has become more or less dedicated by this column to a discussion of some of the previous twelve months' outstanding developments in gold.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 12 (AP)--Gov. George M. Leader said today that he had appointed a two-man fact-finding board to study the strike at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Officials of the United States Information Agency concede privately that their job has not been made any easier by the incident of the "weather" balloons.
NEW HARTFORD, Conn., Feb.12--Miss Loranda Stephanie Spalding of 245 East Fortyninth Street, New York, was married here this afternoon to Efrem Zimbalist Jr. of 1155 Park Avenue, New York.
Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, warned yesterday that the new Soviet policy of lifting the Iron Curtain sufficiently to woo young, uncommitted nations endangered the free world.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12 (AP) --Battelle Memorial Institute today announced completion of the first "critical assembly" laboratory in this country for private research on atomic power plants. Atomic-powered aircraft engines will be studied in the program.
LONDON, Feb, 12--The unexpected use of the presence of Donald Maclean and Guy Burgess in Moscow by the Soviet Government may be rooted in internal and external conditions, it was suggested tonight.
Fourteen colleges and universities in eleven states will be represented at a five-day seminar on school law that begins today at Teachers College, Columbia University.
Mayor Wagner urged the United States today to take immediate steps to safeguard peace in the Middle East.
FOR almost ten years daily journals have had official Word, always later revoked, that the Prairie State training ship for the New York Naval Militia, was to be scrapped for her metals.
The Prison Association of New York advised the Legislature yesterday to disregard any attempts by "vested interests" to curtail existing correctional industries.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, First Department, declared yesterday that a proposal to provide twenty six more Supreme Court justices in the state would not solve the problems of court congestion.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today released testimony in which Robert R. Bowie denied he ever had advocated admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
First steps have been taken toward a merger of the Central Trades and Labor Council and the New York City C.I.O. Council, representing a total of more than 1,000,000 New York trade union members.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb, 12 --Color will be the keynote of Milton Berle's telecast on the National Broadcasting Company network on Feb. 21. The comedian will do the first color telecast to originate in Las Vegas, Nevada.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 12-- A bearded, turbaned old doctor of Koranic law invited visiting reporters to come to the Kasbah today so he could add his word to the debate on the future of Algeria.

Mrs. Demarest Wright of Revonah Woods, Stamford, Conn., and Dr. Irving Sherwood Wright of New York and Point O'Woods, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alison Sherwood Wright, to Dr. Donald John Cameron. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Cameron of Scarsdale, N.Y.
ATHENS, Feb. 12--Candidates entered today the final week of a hard-fought struggle for renewal of Greece's onechamber Parliament of 300 seats.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12-- There has been a change in thinking at the Federal Reserve about the near-term business outlook. Officials now see almost no likelihood of an early resumption of inflationary, pressure, and they are conscious of a number of signs of slackening in business activity.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 12--The merged United States labor movement proposed today that the Germans be allowed to make a direct choice between unification plans sponsored by the Western powers and by the Soviet Union.

Moscow's National Hotel, across the street from the Kremlin, is a natural locale for a tale of mystery or intrigue. A faded relic of a past era, its heavy furniture, high-ceilinged rooms, rickety elevators and primitive bathroom facilities remind the visiting foreigners it houses that much of the old Russia persists in the new.

MAX POLIKOFF, the impresario-violinist, had a large and enthusiastic audience for the second program of his series. "Music in Our Time: 19001956." It was presented yesterday afternoon at the Ninetysecond Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

Following are comments made yesterday by Governor Harriman and Adlai E. Stevenson on segregation. Governor Harriman discussed the issue on "Let's Find Out" over WCBS Radio. Mr. Stevenson issued his statement in Portland, Ore.

Plans for building a fifteenstory apartment house with stores on the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Eightyfourth Street have been announced as a result of the sale of the property by Frederick Brown to a client of Herbert S. Leman, attorney.
Changes in the top command of Slick Airways, Inc., were announced yesterday by the air freight carrier's headquarters in Burbank, Calif. They are to be effective March 1.

LEXINGTON, Va., Feb. 12-- The George C. Marshall Research Foundation announced today the receipt of a gift of $150,000 from John D. Rockefeller Jr. The contribution will be used to establish a permanent record of General Marshall's public and private papers.
New York State Attorney General Jacob K. Javits proposed yesterday a new agency to improve the business and industrial welfare of the state.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 12--The increase in the Dutch bank rate by one-half of 1 per cent to 3 per cent was a complete surprise to the market last Monday, although it generally was held that in view of the keen demand for money the prevailing rate was too low.

PARIS, Feb. 12--Leaders of six European nations have agreed to seek a nuclear pool for themselves going 'far beyond that proposed for them and eleven other nations in the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. But they believe the two projects need not clash.

Six years ago yesterday Champion Bang Away of Sirrah Crest began his move to the top in the dog world when he took the Futurity, winners dog and eventually best of breed blues at the American Boxer Club's annual specialty show here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) --Senator J.W. Fulbright called today for an investigation of "probable conflicts of interest" on the part of two former officials of the Securities and Ex change Commission.
What is better than one insert advertisement? Two insert advertisements. At least that is the feeling of National Telefilm Associates, Inc., distributor of television feature films.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12-- Average resale prices of mortgages insured by the Federal Housing Administration rose in December for the first time since September, 1954, the agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12-- President Eisenhower will take leave of his Cabinet and his physicians this week and retreat to Georgia to rest and decide his political future.

MAXWELL A. KRIENDLER, burly, plain-spoken executive of Iron Gates Products, Inc., recently returned from a trip to the Soviet Union. Americans, who are now permitted to visit that country, will find little encouragement to do so in what he has to say, Mr. Kriendler, who be
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 12 (AP) --The 1955 victor, Fay Crocker, defeated Patty Berg by a stroke today in the Miami Beach women's open golf tournament.
Austria's national soccer team from Vienna scored seven goals in the first half yesterday as it routed the American League AllStars, 7 to 1, at Zerega Oval, the Bronx.
Abraham Lincoln's deep concern for other people was hailed yesterday from the pulpits of Congregational, Presbyterian and Protestant Episcopal churches in this city.

When the new artificial rink at the Loomis School in Windsor, Conn., is dedicated next Saturday, the Rev. Carl E. Munger and George Warren will have just cause to feel a chapter in their lives has been concluded.

THE month of November, 1950, saw us occupied in three moves, so far as Korea was concerned. One was to reassure our Allies in Europe, especially the British and the French, that we had no intention of widening the conflict or of abandoning our commitments in Europe for new entanglements in Asia.
WASHINGTON, Feb.12--Ezra Taft Benson said today that "all indications point" to a Presidential veto of a farm bill in the form approved by the Senate Agriculture Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12--Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Chief of Staff of the Army, conceded today that the Army believed its "optimum" strength would be twenty-seven or twenty divisions, instead of the nineteen allowed by the budget. It was the first time he had made such a statement in public.
Money for mortgage financing has started to flow more freely recently.
The city began yesterday its two-day observance of the 147th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birthday with a recital of the Gettysburg address at a veterans' ceremony.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 12--Dr. Walter Timme of Cold Spring, N. Y., a neurologist who practiced in New York City for many years, died here today. He would have been 82 years old on Feb. 24.
CAIRO, Feb. 12--Assurances of Western aid for Egypt's High Dam project have created new hopes for a kind of goodwill and stability that might lead eventually to peace in the Middle East.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 12--Dartmouth's Big Green, a powerhouse in Eastern collegiate ski circles, rounded out another successful week-end today with an impressive team triumph in the Williams Winter Carnival.

MIAMI, Feb. 12--Nashua, the $1,251,200 race horse, and James E. Fitzsimmons, Nashua's trainer, are getting a lot of fan mail. Much of it is addressed to "Nashua, Hialeah Race Track, Hialeah, Fla.," and the bulk of it is from young admirers.

Skating and hitting with joyful willingness, the New York Rangers registered a 2-to-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. The National Hockey League game, probably the most thrilling of the current campaign at home, was witnessed by a capacity crowd of 15,925.
The St. Olaf Lutheran Choir, under the direction of Olaf C. Christiansen, sang a choral program of unusual excellence at Town Hall Saturday evening.

The Twentieth Congress of the Soviet Union's Communist party is meeting in Moscow--the first Congress since Stalin's death. In theory this Congress is the highest policy making body of the party, but the provincial and minority party congresses held earlier have shown that this fiction will remain a fiction.

A four-story building at 1580 Edison Avenue, the Bronx, containing a store and twentyseven apartments, has been sold by the Harcres Realty Corporation to Isaac J. Pomerantz. The property occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet near Roebling Avenue.
TO savor a pancake, doughnut or fritter today is to link yourself up with a tradition of length, breadth and interest.

Although political motivations and political consequences cannot be discounted, the inquiries by the State Commissioner of Investigation, striking here and there and most recently at the purchasing practices in Suffolk County, will inevitably encourage and hasten governmental reforms long overdue.
Columbia's bid for the Ivy League basketball championship was dealt a severe blow yesterday when Chet Forte, the Lions' leading scorer, was declared ineligible for the remainder of the season.

IN McMURDO SOUND, Antartica, Feb. 13--For the past six weeks or so Commander Standish Backus Jr., of Santa Barbara, Calif., has been cutting the Antarctic down to the size of his 6-by-6-inch sketch pad.

Little happened on the New cork Stock Exchange yesterday, as investors throughout the country continued to think of the day as a holiday. Volume sank to 1,420,000 shares, the smallest since last Aug. 20, compared with 1,770,000 on Friday.

All local futures markets except the New York Produce Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange were closed yesterday in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. Cottonseed oil futures were active and higher; soybean oil was quiet but rose, and wool was dull and mixed.

Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, will be the spealter at the dinner of the Peter Minuit Post of the American Legion at the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, on Thursday evening. He will talk on "The Realties of New York Realty."

THE first among the United Nations to join us for action in Korea were the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth countries. They did this in spite of the fact that Communist activity in Malaya put a heavy drain on British manpower. The British, however, had shown much concern over the danger that the conflict might enlarge and draw in the Soviet Union.
Rough tactics cost Ray Drake a victory last night. His tenround bout with Hardy Smallwood of Brooklyn was called a draw after Referee Ray Miller took the fifth and ninth rounds from Drake.
The Institute of International Education has received a grant of $1,500,000 from the Carnegie Corporation.

The unnamed company that on Jan. 27 offered to buy 150,000 shares of Boston Woven Hose and Rubber Company common at $18.50 a share has received deposits of more than that number and no more stock will be accepted.
ALBANY, Feb., 13-Mayor Wagner asked the Legislature tonight to increase the salaries of the members of the New York City Board of Water Supply from $15,000 to $20,000 a year.
It was bound to happen sooner for later. The aviation industry has come up with an inflatable rubber airplane that can fit in the trunk of an automobile.
LONDON, Feb. 13-Britain is expected to demand soon from Archbishop Makarios a positive and unequivocal denunciation of violence on Cyprus.
Carl Sandburg endorsed here last night Adlai E. Stevenson's plea for moderation in efforts to integrate the races in Southern public schools.

Lincoln's Birthday observance yesterday brought heavy crowds of mothers and school-free children to New York department and specialty stores. Retailers figured their sales about 20 per cent higher than their volume on a normal Monday in February.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-An exhibit showing the benefits of "people's capitalism" for competion overseas with international communism won the hearty approval of President Eisenhower today.

MIAMI, Feb. 13 (AP)--Remand, idle since Dec. 22, won the first division of the $10,000 Emancipator Purse before 22,689 at Hialeah Park today. The gelding defeated Shimke, the odds-on choice, by two lengths.

The other day a group of travel experts here held a roundtable discussion about American tourists and residents abroad, a serious matter indeed, since there are about a million of each nowadays (apart from the armed forces) and the quantities are increasing.

Maurice Podolorr, the president of the National Basketball Association, said yesterday that he was "certain" that the professional league would extend to the Pacific Coast "within the next ten years."

In an extension of their holdings in the Washington SquareGreenwich Village area, Stanley W. Kempner Son, Inc., real estate investors, have purchased the seven-story building containing four stores and twenty-four apartments at 232-40 Sullivan
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The United States and West Germany signed today an atoms-for-peace agreement designed to give the new German nation the benefits of many beneficial uses of atomic energy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-The United States Court of Appeals took under advisement today a plea by twenty-one New York business concerns against the proposed Washington Square Southeast redevelopment project.
Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly said last night hat President Eisenhower's final decision on a second term would be determined by his "overriding sense of responsibility to the nation."

Jamaica's all-winning record in its division of the Public School basketball league has a brain trust behind it. The starting team finished mid-year exams with a scholastic average of 88.6 per cent. Behind the players is a corps of managers whose "first string" has an average a shade over 90.
ALBANY, Feb. 13-Two Harriman administration bills to broaden the states unemployment insurance program were introduced in the Legislature tonight.
Six hundred branch bank managers scattered throughout the five boroughs were asked yesterday to serve as the city's unofficial trouble shooters.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (AP)--An attorney for the Penn-Texas Corporation, asking a court ban on the proposed stock exchange by Fairbanks, Morse Co. and the Canadian Locomotive Company, Ltd., said today the proposal was "a scheme to neutralize the votes of the smaller stockholders."
LONDON, Feb. 13--Britain's battle against inflation suffered a disappointing setback last month when the deficit in her trade with the rest of the world increased.

CAIRO, Feb. 13--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser has pressed Jordan to join Egypt in a bilateral defense pact. The Egyptian leader's proposal plainly was intended as a new measure to keep Jordan out of the Western-sponsored Baghdad Pact.
Adventurous and patient people will have an opportunity again this year of trying their luck in the Seamen's Church Institute's annual bottle-message sweepstake.
The Ford Motor Company will close ten of its fifteen car assembly plants and shut down one line at an eleventh for one and two-day periods this week, it was announced yesterday.

Despite the complaining of oldtimers, the teaching profession has its lures for beginning teachers.
Following is the text of the address by Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night before the National Republican Club, as recorded by The New York Times:
An Argentine economic mission has come to the United States seeking credits and offering investment possibilities. There is every reason to be generous and encouraging with this delegation.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, plagued by commuters and floods, has some new problems--financial ones.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 13 (UP)--The Auburn Tigers, the runners-up for the Southeastern Conference football title in 1955, were placed on indefinite probation today for paying twin athletes $500 to enroll. Auburn can't go to a bowl next season even if it regains good standing.
TOKYO, Feb. 12-A low-cost plan for using United States dollars to help Asians to help themselves is suggested by a friendly Japanese critic of the assistance program in the Far East.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 13-- Adlai E. Stevenson tumbled thirty-five feet in a somersaulting snow vehicle during a blizzard on the slopes of Mount Hood today.

Louis Bromfield, author-farmer, advocated yesterday stationing an American battleship in Israeli waters as part of a bold United States policy against Soviet maneuvers in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--The United States will not be bluffed or deterred from its search for stability and peace in the Middle East. This was the immediate reaction of officials today to the Soviet warning against free-world intervention to prevent war in the troubled area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--A railroad spokesman said today the American farmers were facing no greater problems than the railroads and that agricultural products should not be exempt from a proposed 7 per cent increase in freight rates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP)-- A conference of state taxpayer groups considered today a program calling for less Federal spending, balanced budgets and a reduction in the public debt.
ROME, Feb. 13--The first of forty United States Air Force Flying Boxcars landed in Italy today with food, clothing and blankets for snowbound villages in the south and central regions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP) --A House Banking subcommittee today called top Government and private housing officials for questioning Thursday and Friday on a "shortage of funds for G.I. and Federal Housing Administration loans."
A new operation that greatly increases laboratory animals' resistance to heart attacks was described here yesterday.

Prime Minister Nehru has again denounced his country's Communists as "reactionaries" who have "locked up their minds" with old and outdated theories based on the "class struggle." He accuses them of talking peace but plotting violence.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Feb. 14-- The world's top Communists met in the Kremlin today for the twentieth Congress of the Soviet Communist party. It is their first full-scale session since the death of Stalin.

Tonight's Broadway premiere is "Someone Waiting," starring Leo G. Carroll and Jessie Royce Landis. At 8 o'clock the Emlyn Williams thriller will begin to unwind at the John Golden Theatre, where two preceding entries left in a hurry.

MONTREAL, Feb. 13 (AP)--, The Montreal Star announced today it would not avail itself of recent Quebec legislation permitting newspapers in the province to obtain newsprint from a Government-administered pool at a frozen price.
AT this time a year ago George Halas wss sad-eyed and despondent when he discussed his forthcoming retirement as coach of the Chicago Bears. The very mention of it made him unhappy.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-- President Eisenhower will receive from his physicians tomorrow afternoon the longawaited definitive medical report that may help him decide whether to seek re-election.
MOSCOW, Feb. 13--The Soviet Union announced tonight it would consider the sending of British and United States troops to the Middle East a threat to peace and an object of "legitimate concern."
Riders on the New York Central System were asked yesterday to "be patient" while the railroad was putting in a program for greater efficiency.
Changes in the Lincoln Square redevelopment are being considered to include the Juilliard School of Music and a drama training school.
LONDON, Feb. 13--Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd accused Soviet leaders today of having hidden their knowledge of the whereabouts of Donald Maclean and Guy Burgess, former British diplomats.
A basic real estate tax rate of $4.06 for each $100 of assessed valuation was predicted yesterday for 1956-57 by Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13-- Dr. Emmett Reid Dunn, David Scull Professor of Biology at Haverford College, died today in Bryn Mawr Hospital at the age of 61.

The Republican Administration of Suffolk County demanded official notification last night of charges that county funds had been squandered through "reckless disregard" for purchasing methods prescribed by law.

The theme of the Prison Association's annual report to the New York Legislature, presented yesterday, calls for constant repetition. It is the need to put the findings of past surveys to work--the job of "implementation."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13-The solemn debate over the Supreme Court's desegregation decision is providing some striking evidence about the leading candidates for the Presidency.

Advertising executives have long been regarded as the aches and pains champions of industry --with assorted ailments such as ulcers, heart conditions and High blood pressure. But a study by Printers' Ink magazine reports that they are no worse off than other executives.
John J. Mann, the only person to serve as chairman of the American Stock Exchange for five terms, yesterday upset the plans of the Exchange's nominating committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13--A Special Senate committee cleared the way today for the opening of a Federal grand jury inquiry into the $2,500 campaign contribution to Senator Francis Case, Republican of South Dakota.

THE season's third concert of the Musicians Guild, which took place in Town Hall last night, added to the already high achievements of the group. Like most concerts of the Musicians Guild, it offered an interesting, varied program performed by artists of high distinction.
The New York Yankees added two young pitchers to their roster yesterday when signed contracts were received from Jim DePalo and Jim, O'Reilly.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Feb. 14 (AP)--Indonesia cut her last political ties with the Netherlands today. The Government said cancellation of all financial, economic and cultural treaties between the two nations would follow soon.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that Ford stock would be admitted to dealings on March 7.

After the Wednesday flurry, traders yesterday resumed their anxious waiting for the President to make up his mind about a second term. Stock prices drifted a little lower. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange sank from 3,000,000 shares to 1,750,000. Almost every group closed mixed.

THE "architecturally featureless" room found today in many modern apartment projects has inspired Frank Parker, interior decorator for B. Altman's "Young Homemaker" model rooms. In newly arranged rooms are found some of his solutions to avoid banal decorating in these box-like rooms.
A financial goal line that Robert R. Young set out to reach only two years ago has almost been crossed.

An increase of 4,962,000 barrels to a record high in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. They set a new peak of 187,618,000 barrels, compared with 182,656,000 a week earlier and 174,203,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Government's top housing official rejected today various suggestions for a more active Government program to add to the supply of mortgage money.

FREDERICK, Md., Feb. 16 (AP) --Brig. Gen. Francis H. Oxx, U.S.A., retired, former Allied Deputy High Commissioner in Austria, died at his home here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 57.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16--The Parmelee Transportation Company filed suit today for triple damages of $19,200,000 for losing the business of transferring through passengers and baggage between Chicago's eight railroad stations.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP) --Robin Roberts of the Philadelphia Phillies signed a contract today reportedly for a salary that would place him among the highest paid pitchers in baseball history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) --Herbert Hoover Jr., Under Secretary of State, warned today that Russia's rise posed an "unparalleled threat" to the United States. He said new weapons exposed this continent to direct "devastating attack."

The furor stirred up by the announcement made by Senator Francis Case of South Dakota that an oil and gas company had offered him a campaign contribution of $2,500 came at a bad time for some politicians but at a good time for the general public in this Presidential year.
LONDON, Feb. 16--The Government increased the bank rate today from 4 to 5 Per cent. The move is part of the Government's effort to keep the pound sterling strong.

Frank H. Wilson, the actor who created here in 1927 the little role in the play "Porgy," died yesterday in Queens General Hospital, Jamaica, after a short illness. His age was 70. He lived at 32-24 104th Street, Corona, Queens.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--A bill to require all securities salesmen, brokers and dealers to register with the Attorney General every two years was introduced in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Secretary of Agriculture was denounced again at the Capitol today. He was denounced for the same reason he was the last time: telling truths that are unpopular with many legislators, particularly those who have large farm and organized labor groups in their constituencies.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 16--The Army garrison at Iquitos in eastern Peru, the country's principal Amazon River port, revolted today.
Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, said yesterday that the effect on the nation's economy of cutbacks in defense spending had been more than made up for by private business and industry.
HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 16-- The new president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad gave renewed assurances here today that the road would soon be back on the track again.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--William H. Morgan, a political protege of James A. Farley, was appointed a member of the State Civil Service Commission today by Governor Harriman.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Friday, Feb. 17--The White House announced early today a suspension of arms shipments from the United States to the Middle East.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--The president of the State Civil Service Commission disclaimed today all responsibility for the high percentage of temporary employes on Nassau County payrolls.

Western Union Telegraph Company and American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres Inc., anounced jointly yesterday signing of contracts for each to acquire a 22 per cent interest in Technical Operations, Inc., an Arlington, Mass., manufacturing, research and development company.

LONDON, Feb. 16--The century-long struggle for the abolition of the death penalty in Britain was won tonight. The House of Commons voted in favor of the introduction of legislation abolishing or suspending capital punishment.
TRENTON, Feb. 16--The four-state agency recently formed to recommend a development program for the Delaware River Watershed will hold its first meeting tomorrow.

Heavy short covering, new buying and stop-loss purchasing sent coffee futures soaring to new seasonal highs yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Several of the "M" positions rose the 2-cents-apound daily limit. Trade hedge selling and profit taking supplied the contracts. The volume was the third largest of the year.

A burglary suspect was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court because a woman smelled cigar smoke coming from her apartment. As the story was unfolded in court, Mary Beres ford, 28 years old, of 61 East Sixty-sixth Street, left her home at 7 P.M. Wednesday to shop. She returned about an hour later with a bag of groceries.
The United States economy was portrayed last night by a high Commerce Department official as a successful model, parts of which other nations could profitably adapt to their own needs.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--Governor Harriman urged today that the state contribute to the cost of hospital and medical insurance for its employes.
A CONSIDERABLE change in manner has come over the painting by Cornelis Ruhtenberg, whose recent work is on view at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 16 --An Executive Order providing for the training of a ready reserve of business and labor executives for Government service in an emergency was signed today by President Eisenhower.

The Government filed an amended complaint yesterday against two large oil companies and four subsidiaries. It contends that they overcharged the Economic Cooperation Administration for European oil shipments under the Marshall Plan.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 16-- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today charged deliberate abuse of "decent standards of fairness" in the state investigation of the county's affairs.

Mr. and Mrs. M. Wesley Edson of 216 East Thirty-sixth Street and Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Gay Edson, to Stephen Harris Giger, son of Mrs. Harris Giger of St. Louis and the late Mr. Giger.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--The Republican majorities in the Legislature proposed today that the rate buy an extra 12,000,000 quarts of milk in the coming far for children of families on chief.

MOSCOW, Feb. 16--The Twentieth Communist party Congress, the first since Stalin's death, was told today that the "cult of personality" had wrought considerable harm to both the party and the Soviet Union.
ROME, Feb. 16--Senator Ezio Vanoni, Minister of the Treasury and interim Minister of the Budget, died in the Senate building this afternoon.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--The Court of Appeals ruled today that a state law preventing the sale of condensed or evaporated skimmed milk in retail stores was unconstitutional.
Margaret Truman will relinquish her radio job on the National Broadcasting Company network to fill television commitments.
NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 16-- The Shah of Iran and his Empress arrived today in New Delhi. In the world of diplomacy this has become the thing to do.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 16-- A thin, birdlike man, Fi nance Minister Fritz Schaeffer, occupies the center of the West German political scene. He exercises more effective power than the country's Cabinet as a whole. Only Chancellor Konrad Adenauer can overrule him.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots yesterday notified eleven railroads operating floating equipment in the port that it would call its captains and deckhands out on strike at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 16--A British Treasury official arrived here today to discuss Finance Minister Fritz Schaeffer's refusal to continue cash contributions to the support of Atlantic act armed forces in West Germany after May 5.
Cotton futures moved 1 point lower to 11 points higher yesterday. The volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was small.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy was accused yesterday of being on the "verge of tyranny" for refusing to turn over wiretapping data to a legislative committee.
The last steel column in Manhattan of the elevated railroad that had shut out the sunlight over Third Avenue for threequarters of a century was uprooted yesterday.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted yesterday that Jews the world over would assist financially in the development of the Middle East if Israel and the Arab states were at peace.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP)-- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that Federal District Judge Bailey Aldrich of Boston had refused for a time last summer to sign a non-Communist affidavit and finally had signed it "only after severe pressure."

MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (Reuters) --A retired Columbia University professor has been attacked for having written a book described as being "full of lies, slanders and wild inventions," the Moscow radio reported today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- About 12,300 young men have volunteered to date for the sixmonth training program of the armed services.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has placed into production its new plant for manufacture of isocyanates, chemicals which du Pont chemists say will expand the use of plastic foam products. The chemical is a derivative of isocyanic acid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) --Ten executives of a company that makes jet fighter planes for the Air Force drew $399,000 in bonuses last year in addition to $594,250 in salaries, House investigators disclosed today.
A member of Congress denied yesterday that he had called for a meeting between unions affiliated with the merged labor movement and two independent longshore unions.
City College's basketball team threatened to upset Fordham at the Rose Hill gymnasium last night, but the Rams pulled the game out, 63--60, with a secondhalf rally.

Early next month Southern Vietnam will hold its first popular election on a nation-wide scale. The voters will choose an Assembly whose function will be to approve and adopt a constitution for the young republic. To this Assembly, in turn, the Government of President Diem will presumably be responsible.

Service charges on special checking accounts at leading New York City banks appear to be slated for an increase from 25 to 50 cents a month. sixth largest commercial bank in the city, has announced such a rise, effective on April 1.
Despite snags in initial organization, the first major military execcises of the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) are off to a good start.

VISITORS to the annual New York Sports, Travel and Vacation Show, which starts today at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx, will see two infant bears in the exhibit of the State Conservation Department. They are symbols of the harm done and the nuisance caused by picking up baby animals in the woods.
MADRID, Feb. 16--The political tension caused by street fighting in Madrid last week between university students and Falangists appeared today to be relaxing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--The Government lost in the Federal Court of Appeals today its fight to establish the renegotiability of wartime Red Sea charters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- Fathers and men 26 years of age and older will be virtually exempted from the draft by a revision of Selective Service regulations ordered by President Eisenhower.
The Commercial Credit Company in 1955 had the highest earnings in its forty-four-year history, E.C. Wareheim, board chairman, announced in issuing the annual report for publication today.

Hot Rod Hundley lived up to his All-America billing as, almost single-handedly, he led West Virginia University to an 82--75 basketball victory over St. John's University of Brooklyn at Madison Square Garden last night.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony's pro gram last night at Carnegie Hall encompassed two soloists, a new, rather circusy Shostakovich overture and a celebration of the seventy-fifth birthday of Ernest Bloch.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (U.P.) --House of Representative investigators seized the private papers of a construction corporation executive today. They acted to prevent what they called a Justice Department "cover-up" of a controversial expansion project at a Government-owned nickel plant.
STOCKHOLM, Feb. 16 (AP)--A four-goal splurge in the last period gave the United States Olympic hockey team a 6-3 victory tonight over Sweden's National sextet.
ALBANY, Feb. 16--Governor Harriman proposed today construction of a "closed" state institution for 600 mentally retarded delinquents and semidelinquent patients.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--A Defense Department expert said today that Administration agreement to ease trade controls against Russia had greatly assisted modernization of the Soviet war machine.

MIAMI, Feb. 16--The friskiest bit of race-running at the Hialeah horse park today was done by the Starmount Stable's Nantallah. He won the sixfurlong sixth in 1:10. That's only three-fifths of a second away from the track record.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- Three witnesses before the House Committee on Un-American Activities invoked the Fifth Amendment 175 times today in a twohour span.
The flood of reports of record 1955 earnings, now reaching a crest, makes cheerful reading for management and investors alike. But as a guide to the future--let the reader beware.

Mrs. Laura Kilpatrick Morgan bequeathed her residuary estate in trust to her two great-grandsons, Leopold and Christopher Vanderbilt Stokowski. They will receive the principal when they become 21 years old.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 16-- Following is the text of a letter to Governor Harriman by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors concerning the state investigation now in progress in the county:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UP) --Spokesmen for newspapers, broadcasters and advertising agencies charged today that a proposal to ban interstate liquor advertising would discriminate against their businesses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16--A Defense Department expert said today that Administration agreement to ease trade controls against Russia had greatly assisted modernization of the Soviet war machine.

IT was a telephone call that started the mental wheels spinning and it was a television program, viewed by accident, that completed the association of ideas. Or perhaps it would be more proper to say that the beginnings really belong to a swimming meet between Yale and Army at West Point. At any rate, here's the way it went.

IN the mood for a change of pace this week-end, the lady in the kitchen decides on veal Maybe not the bargain that beef and pork are, veal nevertheless is much cheaper than last February. Prices on the luxurious cutlets, now in the neighborhood of $1.30 a pound, have averaged as much as 20 cents a pound less than a year ago.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 16-- The two parties that control a majority in the North RhineWestphalian State Parliament offered a motion today to oust the state government, dominated by Dr. Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democrats.

THERE isn't any question about it. Lew X. Lansworth's first novel, "Over the River Charlie,"* is odd to the point of willful eccentricity. Now that I have finished it, maybe I ought to lie down for a while--to catch my breath and to give myself time to rid myself of the disquieting illusion that I have been reading a novel written in collaboration...

The Falange party in Spain is very much in the news these days and is obviously passing through one of the many crises in its not too savory history. However, the chances are all in favor of it weathering this storm.
Calendar congestion in the Federal Court of the Southern District has been reduced by about 40 per cent, Paul W. Williams, its prosecutor said yesterday.

A 40-cent fare to the Rockaways was announced yesterday by the Transit Authority. The facility across Jamaica Bay was rehabilitated after a fire destroyed the trestle of the Long Island Rail Road and the line was taken over by the city. Service will begin June 28.
Victoria de los Angeles brought more than her beautiful voice to the part of Marguerite is Gounod's "Faust" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 16-- Informed Israeli Government sources said tonight that Premier David Ben-Gurion's promise of holding off construction on the Jordan Valley project was conditioned on the prompt arrival of Eric Johnston.
The Roekefeller Foundation is supporting attempts to penetrate the mysteries of the universe and the minds of American voters.

In its report to the Legislature the Temporary Commission on the Courts, of which Harrison Tweed is chairman, has given a spectacular demonstration of the need for drastic reform in the administration of justice in New York.
The first phase of the Shell Oil Company's institutional safety advertising campaign came to a temporary close yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16--Wheat futures were strong today on the Board of Trade. There was considerable short covering in the deferred futures, and a continued good demand for the March and May contracts. The near delivery again set a new high for the season.
The Douglas Aircraft Company announced yesterday it had redesigned its DC-8 jet transport to make it larger than originally planned.
At a dinner here tonight Republicans and Democrats alike are honoring a legislative leader who is held in unique affection and respect on the Albany scene.

A MAN stared at the steeple of St. Paul's Chapel down town at noon the other day and was astonished to see that it said 4 o'clock. A second glance told him that the steeple timepiece had human hands instead of the regular dial sweeps and that a man's head was poked through the dial pivot space.

Last year more Americans preferred beagles than any other kind of pure-bred dog. That's been true since 1953, when the merry little hound took first place in the popularity parade from the cocker spaniel.
John Archer, who retired in 1951 as head of the printing and binding office of the New York Public Library, died yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh. His age was 69.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16-- The Government today called both sides to Washington Monday for an "all-out effort" to settle the strike at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

Along with his order requiring integration of the schools of New Orleans "with all deliberate speed," a United States District Judge has written an opinion to stir the heart of every citizen concerned with the great and difficult question now rocking the Deep South. These are his words:
LONDON, Feb. 17--The British Government announced today that it would spend the equivalent of $4,336,360,000 on defense in the fiscal year starting April 1.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Feb. 17 --A rebel-yelling crowd of more than 1,000 persons roared defiance of racial integration tonight as they organized the West Alabama Citizens Council.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 17--Marshal Tito and his colleagues are convinced more than ever that the new leaders of the Soviet Union have adopted a promising approach to international and domestic affairs.

State Housing Commissioner Joseph M. McMurray suggested yesterday that low rent public housing in the Rockaways might be jeopardized if the Transit Authority instituted a 40-cent fare to the peninsula.

The Anaconda Company raised its price of refined copper 3 cents a pound yesterday, to 46 cents. This is the higher copper price quoted by a major primary producer since the closing months of the Civil War in 1865.

A good many of our blue-chip stocks fetch much higher market prices in relation to earnings than those of corresponding enterprises in England and Holland, International Investors, Inc. has disclosed.

Mrs. Helen Whitney Bourne Choate, daughter of Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson of Lands End, Locust Valley, L. I., and North Conway, N. H., was married on Feb. 4 to Roy F. Atwood of New York. Members of the immediate families attended the ceremony in the Congregational Church of North Conway.
TRENTON, Feb. 17--Leslie Brown refused today to accede to a demand by Gov. Robert B. Meyner that he resign as chairman of the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission.
It is February and it is raining. It is cold, and one sees by the thermometer that only a degree or two ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 17 (AP) --Albert Karl (Kip) Selbach, who had been a major league baseball player for fourteen years, died today at St. Anthony Hospital at the age of 83. He was also captain of the AllAmerica bowling team in 1902 and owned two bowling alleys.
The National Supply Company, manufacturer of oil and gas field equipment, last year had the highest sales and the second largest earnings in its history, according to figures issued yesterday.
IT is to the credit of Ferenc Molnar's talent that his play "Liliom" should still be able to stand on its own two feet almost a half-century after he wrote it.

The backlog of new corporate debt and preferred stock continues to mount beyond the halfbillion-dollar mark as the calen-- dar starts heading for spring. The pace of underwriting activity continues moderate, however.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 17 --President Eisenhower confessed today to being "a little frightened of myself" as he played nine holes of golf for the first time since his heart attack Sept. 24.
Old sprinters never really stop running. They just apply their speed and competitive spirit to other fields.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--The New York Telephone Company today won a chance to reargue its plea for an annual rate increase of $68,850,000 that had been rejected by the Public Service Commission.
In refurbished quarters on the old Manhattanville College campus, the Institute of Film Techniques at City College is focusing its cameras on Father Knickerbocker.

An excellent example of Soviet tactics in "negotiation" is offered in the current discussion in London of the basis for a Soviet-Japanese peace treaty. In the beginning, the Soviet Union laid down certain proposals that were obviously impossible of acceptance.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 18 --The Twentieth Congress of the Communist party has heard a direct attack on Stalin's most important economic work as well as his handling of foreign policy.
A group of suburban specialty shops is fighting discount-house competition in women's apparel and accessories by refusing to buy merchandise from manufacturers who sell the same items to discounters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--A Senate investigation of EastWest trade focused critically today on Harold E. Stassen, President Eisenhower's adviser on disarmament.
THE National Broadcasting Company's venture into daytime TV drama, "Matinee Theatre," carried off an amusing and very pleasant adaptation yesterday of James Thurber's "The Catbird Seat."

THE return of General MacArthur to the United States [in April, 1951] set off a wave of emotion and a great deal of oratory. I had expected this, and it did not upset me. In fact, I let it be known that I thought it only proper that the General should be invited to address the Congress and that his achievements as a great soldier should be acclaimed.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 17--Despite the calm reported in most of Peru today, the Government's repression of the political Opposition in Lima is tightening, with arrests mounting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- House Ways and Means Committee Democrats seeking aid from the Republicans in financing the new $35,000,000,000 highways program, were balked again today.
A Nationalist Chinese sea captain has enrolled in the School of Insurance at 225 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- Angry managers of the natural gas bill gave up the fight today in the face of a Presidential veto that obviously would be sustained.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 17--A Soviet spokesman said today that there was hope an East-West agreement might be reached on disarmament.
President Eisenhower's veto yesterday of the natural gas bill was based on the "highly questionable activities" of proponents of the measure that have achieved wide attention in the last two weeks.

Word comes from the United Nations Capitol on East Forty-second Street of a small, quietly simmering controversy that has in it the ingredients of some vast issues. The question is where and when the next session of the U. N. Assembly will be held.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--Dr. Peter Schlumbohm, New York inventor, is staging a one-man revolt against what he calls Detroit's dachshund designs in cars. He got a patent this week for a family car that, instead of being long, low and sleek, is short, high and roomy.

IF patience were all that was needed to settle the West inghouse strike, the walkout should have been over long ago. For that quality is one thing the two principal peacemakers in the dispute have plenty of.
MOSCOW, Feb. 14--Former Premier Georgi M. Malenkov told the Communist party Congress today that heavy industry was the basis of the entire Soviet economy.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 17-- Miss Jacqueline St. Clair Bennett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Garland Bennett Jr., will be married here tomorrow evening to Fred Lovejoy Mullikin Jr. of New York. The bridegroom-to-be is a son of Mrs. Frederick J. Vieth of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Mr. Mullikin of Jacksonville, Fla.
The seventeenth annual Colonial Ball, commemorating the birthday of George Washington, was held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mayor Wagner was guest of honor.
The indoor track season will reach its annual peak tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's sixty-eighth championship carnival at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts told the National Press Club today that he was not a candidate for either President or Vice President, on the Republican ticket this year.
Sales and earnings of the Weyerhaeuser Timber Company last year reached the highest levels in its history, according to the annual figures announced yesterday.
Gene Fullmer, a middleweight from West Jordan, Utah, and Gil Turner of Philadelphia engaged in a primitive punching contest at Madison Square Garden last night, with Fullmer gaining the decision.
A model "brotherhood town" is being built by a group of oldsters who believe that life is too precious to be cluttered with prejudice.
A biography of Sir Winston Churchill's early years is one of two books published today. Written by Leonard Wibberley for teenage readers.

SPORTS show highlights: This year's show certainly has more to offer than last year's event, which was the first under the management of the New York Expositions, Inc., and also the first at the Kingsbridge Armory.

Several factors--some technical, some not--thrust the stock market yesterday into the best one-day gain, as measured by The New York Times Index, since September, 1939. The value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange showed a net gain of $4,000,000,000.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 17 --Adlai E. Stevenson berated Vice President Richard M. Nixon tonight as a young man of "very easy verbal virtue" who had given early notice that the Republican "crusade" would go forward this year "on the lowest level."

Events today: Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera, 2; Concert Artists Guild, Steinway Hall, 3; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Alfredo Antonini and Herman Neuman, conductors, Dorothy Bullock, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 5.
The people of Africa are determined to be free and it is up to the western world to gain their confidence, Representative Frances P. Bolton of Ohio said here yesterday.
Republicans and Democrats came about as close to a millennial harmony here last night as perhaps they ever will.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 17 --Typewriters are clattering merrily at the Universal-International Studio. Employment of scenarists is at its highest point in the last two years, according to Ray Crossett, studio scenario and story editor, with thirty-six writers working on thirty-four feature films. Seven of the writers were hired this week.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Industry was called on today by a top management executive to help do something about the serious shortages of skilled labor, scienitsts, engineers and management talent.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 17 (AP)--Brooks Dodge of Gorham, N. H., won the men's slalom race in the international white ribbon ski tournament today and American girls gained three places among the first five in the women's slalom.
THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 17 --President Eisenhower today vetoed the natural gas bill and made a blistering attack upon "arrogant" actions by some industry lobbyists.
DETROIT, Feb. 17 (AP)--The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation today announced it would build its largest assembly plant twelve miles northwest of Youngstown, Ohio.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 17--The engagement of Miss Sandra Yvonne Metzner to Lieut. Steven M. Fulda, U.S.A.F., has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Russell W. Metzner. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Fulda of Dallas, Tex.
A new class of tramp tonnage, larger and faster than existing bulk cargo carriers, is about to make its appearance on the world-wide bulk dry-cargo scene.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- The Secretary of the American Dental Association asked Congress today to double the appropriation for dental research recommended by the Bureau of the Budget.
LONDON, Feb. 17--The stock markets here today seemed to find the combination of higher bank rate and the Chancellor's measures hard to digest. Prices moved erratically.
Gustave, Inc., manufacturer of novelty slippers, has leased about 10,000 square feet of space at 338 Lewis Street in Paterson, N.J.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Dr. Dis raeli W. Kobak, a leader in the field of physical medicine and rehabilitation, died today in Chicago Wesley Memorial Hospital. His age was 69. Death was attributed to leukemia.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17-- President Eisenhower's veto of the gas bill is his first fundamental break with the Democratic-Republican coalition that actually controls Congress most of the time.
Charles P. Grimes, attorney for Wes Santee, said yesterday he would demand a Congressional investigation of the Amateur Athletic Union and the United States Olympic Association.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 17-- West German farmers, caught like their United States counterparts in a serious price squeeze, are in line for large-scale relief under a Government aid program now being prepared.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17--Old crop wheat futures were strong again today after an irregular early trend, and soybean futures also pushed upward on general buying. Coarse grains were neglected by the bulls, but rye showed a little strength.
ALBANY, Feb. 17--Governor Harriman called today for creation of an experimental state clinic in New York City to find a lasting cure for addiction to narcotics.

MIAMI, Feb. 17--The world's costliest horse is going to run his first 1956 race tomorrow. The 1,200-pound Nashua, bought for the $1,000-a-pound price of $1,251,200 last December, heads a nine-horse line-up in Hialeah's $100,000 added Widener Handicap.
The Shubert theatre empire will be broken up under the terms of a consent decree signed yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 17-- American educators were advised today to take a moderate, middle-of-the-road policy on critical school issues.

United States consumption of newsprint in January ran at a new record level nearly 5 per cent greater than in 1955, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. It estimated the total for the month, covering all uses of newsprint, at 529,288 tons.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Feb. 17-- The Algerian policy defined by Premier Guy Mollet in the French National Assembly yesterday got a chilly reception here today.

LONDON, Feb. 17--The Government's all-out war against inflation entered a new and sterner phase today. The Government announced that it was cutting bread and milk subsidies, tightening restrictions on installment buying and slashing its own spending.
Victory over the common cold within five years was predicted here yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP) --Swaps returned to competition today and scored an impressive victory in the $15,000 Los Angeles County Fair Handicap at Santa Anita Park. He beat Bobby Brocato by one and threequarter lengths. Arrogate was third.

MANY women, even those who have made peace with housework tasks to the point of enjoying them, can be afflicted with the "February doldrums." This, then, is a time to re-evaluate the housework, an assessment from which they can profit from for a long time to come.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP)-- New peace talks in the long Westinghouse strike were assured today when the striking union accepted a Government bid for the meetings here.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday reserved decision in the matter of Stephen (Tex) Sullivan, boxing promoter of the London Sporting Club.
Leonard Sillman and John Roberts have settled most of the important production details for their forthcoming revue, "New Faces of 1956."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 17-- The Armenian Orthodox community of Syria and Lebanon is increasingly split by East-West rivalry in the forthcoming election of a new Patriarch of Cilicia.
The coal-producing Philadelphia and Reading Corporation, which last year went into the underwear business, yesterday further diversified its operations by acquiring a boot maker.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17--Senator Walter F. George called today for a Congressional investigation of the tank transaction with Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UP) --One of the Mayors attending a White House conference got into a dispute with the Civil Defense chief, Val Peterson, today. Another accused Administration officials of making "campaign speeches."

Niagara University's sophomore-studded team yesterday accepted an invitation to play in the National Invitation Basketball Tournament at Madison Square Garden starting on March 17.

Stocks went through a confusing session yesterday, trading 2,530,000 shares--against 2,840,000 on Friday--and following a roller-coaster pattern. There was strength at the start, a dip starting in the second hour, a rally late in the noon hour and a selloff near the close.

Columbia swept three events and took eight of thirteen first places to defeat Rutgers in a dual track and field meet, 73--35, at South Field yesterday.

Adlai E. Stevenson acknowledged yesterday that there had been poor coordination between his headquarters and Washington in his 1952 campaign for the Presidency.

IN his campaign for the Presidency [in 1952], Stevenson lived up to his reputation as a man of eloquence. His elo quence was real because his words gave definition and meaning to the major issues of our time.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--Trading fell off today on the Board of Trade following yesterday's big upturns in wheat, soybeans and rye. But buying support again was in evidence in those commodities after moderate recessions, and a sharp rally in corn surprised the trade.

POCATELLO, Idaho, Feb. 21 (AP)--Idaho State College won its fourth straight Rocky Mountain Conference basketball championship tonight by defeating Colorado College, 77--52.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Feb. 21--Mr. and Mrs. Guy H. Whittall have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Pengelley Whittall, to David Nelson Hoadley, son of Mrs. Nelson T. Hoadley and the late Mr. Hoadley. The wedding will take place in May.
As life is prolonged by medical science, increased antibiotics use may be expected because old people are more susceptible to infections, Dr. Perrin H. Long said last night.
Adolph Schurmacher was reelected president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York yesterday by the board of directors.
CHICAGO, Feb. 21 (AP)--A Federal judge today told Fairbanks, Morse Co. to go ahead with preparations for an exchange of stock with Canadian Locomotive Company.

The first of the big Diamond Jubilee tournaments of the United States Lawn Tennis Association starts today.
The Pennsylvania Railroad's stainless steel, lightweight, lowslung Aerotrain will begin regular service Sunday after having received shop treatment for noise, vibration and side-sway.

A new one-story building at 60-05 Flushing Avenue in Maspeth, Queens, has been leased by the Supreme Donut Corporation. The structure will be occupied as offices and for the production and distribution of doughnuts and other bakery products. The lease was negotiated through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.
Paperboard production in the week ended last Saturday was 11.2 per cent above that of the like week last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 21 (UP)--The Government announced today it had agreed to withdraw the remaining French forces from South Vietnam.
Reversing the normal procedure of anniversaries, the New York County Medical Society announced yesterday it would observe its sesquicentennial by looking forward instead of back over its history.

A Mi-Careme (middle of Russian Lent) supper dance will be given on March 16 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by members of the Association of Former Imperial Russian Cavalry and Horse Artillery. Russian Easter this year will fall on May 6.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 (UP)--The Senate unanimously passed today a bill to place volunteer firemen killed or injured in line of duty under protection of the workmen's compensation law.

Huntington eliminated the Cornell Reds with a 13-8 victory in a Sherman Memorial Cup five-goal polo match at the Squadron A Armory last night.
PARIS, Feb. 21--A warning against the danger of inflation in the coming months characterized the seventh annual report, issued today, of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

In a thrilling contest requiring two overtime periods, the Syracuse Nationals handed a 108-107 setback to the New York Knickerbockers in the Eastern Division race of the National Basketball Association at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the New York Telephone Company to issue 1,100,000 shares of common stock and $55,000,000 of refund ing mortgage bonds in order to raise $165,000,000 for expansion costs.

LONDON, Feb. 21--The stock markets continued to rally today under the lead of Government loans. Sentiment was helped by Chancellor Harold Macmillan's statement that the new deflationary measures were adequate for the present.

A 74-year-old attendant was seriously injured yesterday when a homemade bomb exploded in the men's lavatory at Pennsylvania Station.

BOMBAY, India, Feb. 21-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru witnessed a two-hour naval air demonstration today from the flight deck of the British aircraft carrier Albion. The vessel, accompanied by the carrier Centaur, is on a six-day goodwill visit to India.
VIENNA, Feb. 21--The Austrian Government decided today to join the Council of Europe. By doing so she will demonstrate that she is ideologically bound to the West.

Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Ambassador to Italy, returned home yesterday to prepare for the forthcoming visit of Italy's President, Giovanni Gronchi.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UP) --Representative James T. Patterson, Republican of Connecticut, said today the Internal Revenue Service had agreed to give special treatment to returns from New England taxpayers claiming refunds for flood damage.

ATHENS, Feb. 21--Disgruntled Opposition leaders and independent Deputies decided today to contest the validity of last Sunday's election. The Government party under Premier Constantin Karamanlis said it had won by a narrow margin.

ALTHOUGH Strindberg's "Miss Julie" is 86 years old, it is remarkably modern in spirit and craftsmanship. And the intelligent performance that was put on at the Phoenix last evening quite rightly treats Strindberg as contemporary.

BERLIN, Feb. 21--The greatest proof of the fallacy of Marxism is, curiously enough, the existence of the Soviet Union. For Karl Marx foresaw the triumph of his theory first in highly industrial countries like Germany or England.

A new hard-box cigarette packing machine, said to be the first American development of its kind, was introduced yesterday by the American Machine and Foundry Company at its plant at Second Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 21 --An earthquake lasting twelve seconds and centering around Eskisehir shook northwest Turkey last night. Two men and two women were killed when part of the old Byzantine wall surrounding the city collapsed, burying two houses.

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 21--Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Golding have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Jayne Golding, to Harold Duane St. John Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. St. John, formerly of Short Hills. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers announced yesterday that Dr. Fulton Cutting had been made a fellow of the institute.

The United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I., will graduate fifty-nine deck and engineer officers on Friday. The class is one of the smallest since the school was established just before World War II.

With no special news developments to account for it, the stock market put, on a great show of strength yesterday after its oneday holiday. Disputes over tariff policy-- one of the more esoteric national pastimes--will enter a new round in Washington this week. There will be some new scenery and minor plot switches, but the essential conflict will continue on classical lines.

ROWAYTON, Conn., Feb. 25 --Announcement of the engagement of Miss Joan Mary Halloran to Edward Parsons Corning Jr. has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Halloran, formerly of Stamford. Mr. Corning is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Corning of Stamford.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 --The Princeton hockey team scored two goals in two minutes in the second period and went on to defeat Yale, 4--0, tonight.
Color is the big news in kitchens. Beautiful pastels that, until recently, were available only on special order, are now being produced by every leading manufacturer of appliances.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 25--John Landy, holder of the world mile record of 3:58, set an Australian three-mile mark of 13 minutes 27.4 seconds today during what he described as a monotonous run against weak opposition.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 25 (UP) --About 61,000 persons were without gas service today after a three-alarm, $500,000 fire knocked out fourteen generators at the Portland Gas Coke Company plant at Linnton. The company said that service could not be restored until next Friday at the earliest.

There is much fundamental background to indicate some of the economic forces that should continue to have a beneficial effect on real estate, according to Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc.

IN "The Great Plains in Transition" Carl F. Kraenzel, Professor of Rural Sociology at Montana State College, has primarily written a sociological treatise.

THE Australians differ from other people in their con cern with the past only in that they have less national history to explore than most and have done less detailed exploration than their fellows in older nations. Nevertheless, a great change has come over Australian professional historical writing.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 25 (AP)-- For the first time in the fifteenyear history of the Bowling Hall of Fame, no one qualified for admission, a tabulation of electors' votes showed today. Andy Varipapa of Hempstead, L.I., received thirty-seven votes, but needed forty-two or 75 per cent of the fifty-six ballots cast.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 25--Czechoslovakia protested "vehemently" to the United States today against the sending of balloons over the country.

MIAMI, Feb. 25--The D. and H. Stable's Needles did some cash-collecting at the rate of a little more than $1,000 a second at the Hialeah horse park today. He won $111,600 of the $148,800 purse in the Flamingo Stakes for 3-year-olds, and he did it in a rather brisk 1:49 2/5.
BOSTON. HINDEMITH'S opera "Ma this der Maler" finally has had its American premiere at Boston Uni versity.
