PANAMA, Feb. 25 (UP)--The Panama Government announced today it had received from the United States the first payment of a $1,930,000 annuity for use of the Panama Canal Zone. The annuity was raised from $430,000 in a new treaty between the two countries that became effective Aug. 25.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25--The United Nations Children's Fund said today that 32,500,000 mothers and children benefited last year from its nutrition and disease control campaigns. This was an increase of 15 per cent over 1954, according to Executive Director Maurice Pate.

Stockholders of the Buckeye Incubator Company, manufacturer of equipment for the poultry and tobacco industries, yesterday increased the authorized common stock from 600,000 to 1,500,000 shares.
The day when people will wear clothing made of paper may not be too far off.
COLDWATER, Mich., Feb. 27 (AP)--Frank Kaprel, football coach at Coldwater High School, said today he had accepted a position as assistant line coach and chief scout at Dartmouth College.
TRENTON, Feb. 27 (AP)--Ike Williams, former world lightweight boxing champion, received today a six month suspended sentence for punching and kicking his estranged wife in an argument last month.

Peter J. Connolly, referee to the Appeals Council of the Regional Office of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare at 42 Broadway, died of a heart attack on Friday in the Broad Street Station of the B.M.T. subway.
The clerk's office of Manhattan Traffic Court will be opened tonight and tomorrow between 5 and 8 o'clock to handle an anticipated rush of scofflaws seeking to pay their fines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- When the President gets around to saying "yes," "no" or "maybe"--the popular guess here is that he will say "maybe" on Wednesday morning--he also will be confronted by a number of additional questions.

MOSCOW, Feb. 27--Communist leaders here are paying close attention to conflicting assessments in the United States of Soviet policy.
ROME, Feb. 27--The Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano published the text today of a pastoral letter of the Polish episcopacy.
HAVANA, Feb. 27--Cuba appealed today to the Inter-American Peace Committee the Organization of American States to intervene in her dispute with the Dominican Republic.
AN eloquent performance of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House included among its assets a new Beckmesser sung by the baritone Ralph Herbert.

Coach Tom Blackburn of the University of Dayton yesterday named two of his players, 7-foot Bill Uhl and 6-6 Jim Paxson, to play for the East in the College All-Star basketball game at Madison Square Garden on March 31.
ELKRIDGE, Md., Feb. 27 (AP) Shirley Leppo, a poliomyelitis victim who had been in an iron lung since she was 8 years old, died today on her twenty-third birthday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 27-- Ceylon is acting to check the steady decline in numbers of her elephants. A hundred years ago they numbered 30,000; today the elephant population is estimated at 1,000.
SIGOURNEY, Iowa, Feb. 27-- Senator Estes Kefauver came to the farm belt tonight to urge "bold action" in a "real emergency on the farms."
Boeing Airplane Company will spend an estimated $73,500,000, in the next three years for additions to its plant and equipment, John O. Yeasting, vice president of finance, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) --The Navy disclosed plans today to build the first nuclearpowered submarine capable of firing guided missiles.
SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 27 (AP)--Lew Hoad, Australia's top amateur tennis player, left Sydney with his wife, Jennifer, by air tonight for an overseas tour.
CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 27-- More than fifty persons were arrested today, the fourth day of a passive civil disobedience campaign launched by Communists and other Leftist organizations.

Two United States touring tennis players, Hugh Stewart of San Marino, Calif., and Tony Vincent of New York, have been temporarily "grounded" in Europe on orders from the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
LEIPZIG, Germany, Feb. 27-- East Germany has come a long way since the uprising of June 17, 1953.

Mrs. George E. Brewer Jr., chairman of the board of trustees of the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, announced yesterday the election of Robert H. Mulreany as a trustee.

Pan American World Airway yesterday urged the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve it application to fly directly between New York and Nassau the Bahamas.

Some softness, notably in steels, rails, tobaccos and coppers, was sandwiched between two periods of strength in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The close found the market almost unchanged. Rails were a bit lower and industrials about where they had ended on Friday.
LOUISVILLE, Feb. 27 (UP) --Kentucky crushed Georgia, 143 to 66, tonight in basketball.

A joint legislative committee's exposure of abuses of charitable fundraising by unscrupulous promoters led to the passage at Albany in 1954 and 1955 of some mild regulatory laws that have not yet achieved their purpose.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--An entirely new approach to Federal medical research was recommended today as the result of a special study.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 (AP)--The remaining half interest in Hafiz II, a 4-year-old son of Nearco who won the Queen Elizabeth II and Champion Stakes in England last year, was bought by Larry MacPhail, Maryland sportsman.

A Push-O-Button spice rack with a Salem Maple Finish that may hang on the wall or set on the table is available at Abraham Straus after March 1 for $4.95. It seeks to keep spices orderly and dust free.

The revolt in Peru is over, without bloodshed and without any evidence that the few military officers who struck in Iquitos, far from the capital of Lima, had either popular support or even the backing of many fellow-officers.

Fourteen thousand shares of trades that never happened were reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. They showed prices rising steadily, New York Central from 44 to 44 3/8 to 44 5/8; Philco from 32 5/8 to 32 7/8 to 33.

The Academy Chamber Players have canceled their concert, which was scheduled for next Thursday evening at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at Ninety-second Street.

Miguel Berrios rallied in the last four rounds to gain a split ten-round decision over Bobby Bell last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, Berrios, from New York, weighed 127 pounds to 128 for his Youngstown (Ohio) opponent.

Purchases of life insurance in January reached an all-time high of $3,742,000,000, a gain of 21 per cent over the like 1955 month, Life Insurance Agency Management Association reported yesterday. The figure in 1955 was $3,104,000,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 27--Sentiment is grooving among the leaders of the Legislature to push through a bill creating a number of new seats on the State Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Supreme Court ruled today that a "no strike" clause in a collective bargaining contract did not bar a work stoppage against unfair labor practices of employers.
Two city officials yesterday disputed the interpretation of a plan to remove a group of twenty-four "nudist" and "girlie" magazines from city newsstands.

Three new films, two of them British imports, open at firstrun theatres today.
DENVER, Feb. 27--In a unanimous decision the Colorado Supreme Court ruled today that judges of lower courts should decide whether to permit newspaper, radio or television coverage of trials.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Republicans no longer are braced against the crushing blow to their hopes that would be delivered by the President if he declined again to be a candidate.

ATHENS, Feb. 27--Premier Constantin Karamanlis formally subbitted his resignation to King Paul today and recommended that he succeed himself in a new Government. The King agreed. Premier Karamanlis asserted he had won a "clear majority."

The Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and the Penn Fruit Company have leased space for supermarkets in the Springfield Shopping Center to be erected at State and Sproul Roads in Springfield, Pa., by the Sproul Corporation.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 27--Mr. and Mrs. Alvah Hall Warren Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leatrice Anne Warren, to Junius Simpson Dean Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dean of Montchanin, Del. The wedding will take place in the spring.
DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The University of Dayton today appointed Don Panciera, 28 years old, backfield coach for the football squad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- President Eisenhower announced today his intention of redesignating George C. McConnaughey as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Mr. McConnoughey will continue as chairman until his term as a member expires on June 30, 1957.
The music library of Olin Downes, late music critic of The New York Times, has been purchased for $10,500 from his estate by Florida State University.

Processing of office operations through electronic data machines "is necessary," but the move entails extensive preliminary planning, Alfred M. Wilson, executive vice president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company, cautioned yesterday.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a near doubling of January net income over the same period in 1955.
Stockholders of Bunker Hill Sullivan Mining and Concentrating Company will be asked at the annual meeting March 27 to shorten its name to the Bunker Hill Company.
Announcement of the engagement of Miss Helen Drew to Dr. Howard Isenberg has been made by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Louis Drew of the Bronx. The couple will be married in the spring.

Adlai E. Stevenson proposed last night that President Eisenhower summon a meeting of Southern Negro and white leaders in an effort to allay mounting racial tensions.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy expressed the hope yesterday that the use of additional policemen in the "traffic test tube" in midtown also would curb jay-walking.

A plan of the American National Theatre and Academy to raise $5,000,000 for the establishment of a forty-theatre circuit gained momentum yesterday.

A report from Dr. Evarts A. Graham, St. Louis surgeon and researcher, linking lung cancer with heavy cigarette smoking, will be "studied with great interest" by the tobacco industry, Timothy V. Hartnett said yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP) --The Philadelphia Eagles today signed John (Rocky) Ryan, a 6-foot 1-inch 200-pound end from Illinois, and John Erickson, a 6-foot, 3-inch 230-pound tackle from West Point, for the 1956 National Football League season.

DETROIT, Feb. 27 (AP)--The nation's auto makers made another moderate reduction in car assemblies last week as they continued efforts to reduce dealer inventories. States factory output last week came to 124,317 passenger cars.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The Administration unveiled a thirtypoint legislative program in the housing field today. The emphasis was on plans to spur housing for the aged.

Gilbert Green, 49-year-old convicted Communist leader, surrendered yesterday to begin a five-year prison term. He had been a fugitive for five years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-- President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy arrived in Washington today for a four-day visit devoted to developing closer ties between Italy and the United States.
The Gilbert and Sullivan Society of New York will hold its monthly meeting tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Claridge Hotel.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 -- Bill Rigney passed his first test as the manager of the Giants today as he guided his squad through its first formal day of spring training. He proved to the satisfaction of a critical press group that he had a sense of humor and that he could "take" a ribbing.

PARIS, Feb. 27--Two parallel European nuclear projects, both still in a tentative state, are expected to be under official negotiation after tomorrow's meeting of the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

Operating revenues of the New York Central Railroad rose last month by $6,416,830 to $64,982,347, but earnings dropped to $2,525,117, or 39 cents a share, from $3,082,934, or 48 cents a share, reported in January, 1955.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--The United Steelworkers has turned down a contributory unemployment pay plan offered by the International Nickel Company.

"Witness for the Prosecution" will give a special performance Sunday night for the benefit of the Actors Fund. On March 11, a special performance for the fund will be given by "The Lark."

LEOPOLD PRESAS is widely known as one of the major semi-abstract painters in his native Argentina. In his first exhibition in the United States--it is at Galeria Sudamericana, 866 Lexington Avenue--Presas shows oils and temperas that reflect a strong but individually applied interest in cubism.

NASSAU, Bahama Islands, Feb. 27--Sir Miles Thomas, board chairman of the British Overseas Airways Corporation, arrived here from Miami yesterday after visiting the Caribbean area served by the company's new Viscount airliners, Sir Miles will fly to New York tomorrow.

More than $12,000,000 of new securities of Kansas Gas and Electric Company will be offered to investors today by investment banking syndicates following sale to investment banking syndicates at public sealed bidding.
BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)--The Milwaukee Braves tonight announced signing Billy Bruton, an outfielder, and Humberto Robinson, a pitcher.
A total of 501 pints of blood was collected Friday by the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 (AP)--The River Divide Farm's Decathlon, the second choice at $6.60 for $2, won the $10,000 Osceola Purse before 20,402 at Hialeah Park Today. It was the colt's fifth start of the winter and his fourth success.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) --The St. Regis Paper Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an offer to trade up to 540,000 shares of its common stock for the outstanding common of the Rhinelander Paper Company, of Wisconsin, on a share-for-share basis.

The manufacture of high pressure acetylene products on a full commercial scale for the first time in the United States got under way yesterday when production started at the new $6,000,000 plant of General Aniline and Film Corporation at Calvert City, Ky.

Johns-Manville Corporation will build a plant to manufacture asbestos-cement pipe products near Stockton, Calif., A.R. Fisher, president, announced yesterday.
Cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The close was 3 points off to 18 points up, with the distant months showing the most strength.
PARIS, Feb. 27--In his newly decorated white and be-mirrored salon, Givenchy shows a continuation of his soft, fluid line, with increased back emphasis.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 27 (AP)-- Dr. Robert M. Lindner, psychologist, psychoanalyst and author, died today at Johns Hopkins Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 41 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 27-- Brazilian troop commanders faced a tactical dilemma today in operations against the Air Force jungle rebellion.

Fort Worth, Texas borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday in the public market to finance street paving, fire protection and water supply and sewerage improvements.
The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company's 1955 sales of new life insurance broke all records in the company's 111 years of operations, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A quick test in the Senate of the Administration's farm policy was assured today.
An option for the purchase of thirty acres of the former estate of Robert F. Loree on Hanover Road in Florham Park, N.J. has been taken by the Automatic Switch Company of Orange, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)-- The Bureau of Mines reported today stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum totaled 256,645,000 barrels on Feb. 18, a net increase of 3,161,000 barrels for the week.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 27--Discount practices in the nation's book trade may be affected by the results of as antitrust hearing that opened today in Federal court. It has been pending since 1952.

Attorney General Jacob K. Jaavits will be the speaker at the luncheon meeting of the National Realty Club on Thursday noon at the Roosevelt Hotel. He will speak on "The Future of New York City."

Sheikh Muhammad Bahjat AlBitar, a religious leader and philosopher of the Islamic world, arrived here by plane yesterday from Damascus, Syria. He will participate in the first tour in the United States in the interest of Moslem-Christian understanding.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BOSTON, May 1 (UP)--Red Kelly and Marty Pavelich teamed tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2-0 victory over the Boston Bruins that enabled the Red Wings to regain second place in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 1--Six months will pass before the national conventions of the two major parties assemble, and eight months will elapse before the voters go to the polls to make a choice between the candidates of these conventions. But the issues of the campaign began to clarify with the announcement of ...

MORRISVILLE, Pa., March 1 --Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey was identified today as one of a group of lawyers who shared in the $450,000 of counsel fees paid out by the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission between 1948 and 1955.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey questioned today the propriety of Ezra Taft Benson's accepting the services of a public relations concern named as a coconspirator in a Federal antitrust suit.
Paul J. Neff and the Missouri Pacific are no strangers. He has headed the railroad for the last nine and a half years without a break--even though he was fired in 1951.
Skiing enthusiasts again were gleeful yesterday as reports from the northlands continued optimistic. The picture was brighter in the southern parts of the snow country than it was farther north.

Futures prices were generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Potato trading was active but most of the other items were quiet. Potatoes, coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, onions and zinc rose; cocoa and rubber de- ...

The theatre benefit committee of the Masters Nursery has taken over the orchestra of the ANTA Theatra for the April 10 evening performance of "Middle of the Night." Edward G. Robinson is the star of the play.
MANCHESTER, N.H., March 1--Senator Estes Kefauver returned today for a whirlwind tour of New Hampshire with the air of a man who knew he was being followed.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Consumer installment credit declined in January for the first time since January, 1955, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Members of the Woman's Auxiliary of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church are sponsors of the first joint concert of the St. Thomas Church Choral Society and the St. Thomas Church Boys Choir. The event will be held on the night of March 22 in ...

WASHINGTON, March 1-- United States officials looked forward today to a fresh opportunity of winning the hemispheric argument over the limits of a country's jurisdiction at sea in an inter-American conference at Ciudad Trujillo this month.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Democrats and Republicans of the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report backed President Eisenhower today on the basic analysis and major recommendations of his economic report.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- President Eisenhower and President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy declared today that much as they desired disarmament, "the present situation does not allow any relaxation of the Western defense efforts."

Arthur A. Elder of 40 West Sixty-seventh Street, director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Training Institute, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital of internal hemorrhages. His age was 56.

A second dock worker testified yesterday he had paid cash to a hiring boss to get a job on a Yonkers sugar pier. The testimony came as the Waterfront Commission continued its hearing into kickback charges against the hiring boss, Frank (Marchito) Acosta.
All mayor radio and television networks declined yesterday to grant to the Democratic National Committee free time equal to that granted to President Eisenhower Wednesday night.

BEDFORD CENTER, N.Y., March 1--Leaders in athleties, aw, public planning and governmental service were among 150 persons attending a funeral service here today for Gustavus T. Kirby, who died on Monday at his Bedford Hills home. A retired attorney, be long had been active in civic affairs and Olympic committees.

THE first premiere of the New York City Ballet's season at the City Center took place last night, in the form of "Allegro Brillante," choreographed by George Balanchine to the single finished movement of Tchaikovsky's third Piano Concerto. It was designed for Maria Tallchief and ...
ALBANY, March 1--A team of state examiners reported today that it had found Suffolk County's financial operations riddled with illegal practices and bad management.

One barrier to a merger of Fairbanks, Morse Co. and Canadian Locomotive Company was removed yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange approved the listing of 90,404 additional shares of the former company's common stock.

WAYNESBORO, Ga., March 1 (AP)--Police bullets ended the life of a Massachusetts killer-kidnapper today seconds after an 11-year-old boy hostage broke away from him in a running gun fight along a Georgia highway.

Today's new film is "The Killer Is Loose," United Artists' suspense drama starring Joseph Cotten, Rhonda Fleming and Wendell Corey, at the Palace. Harold Medford's screen play was based on a story by John and Ward Hawkins. Budd Boetticher directed and Robert L. Jacks produced for Crown Productions.

"THERE has been a revoluiton in the plastics industry in the last two years," says Hiram McCann, editor of Modern Plastics. He made this statement at a luncheon meeting of the Home Fashions League earlier this week.

THE Paulist Choristers of New York, conducted by Father Foley, gave a concert last night in Town Hall. The program consisted of music by Rachmaninoff, Gretchaninoff, Palestrina, Byrd, Handel, Vittorio, Ralph Lyman Baldwin and others.
New York hockey fans reacted enthusiastically to the news that the Rangers had clinched a berth in the Stanley Cup play-offs for the first time in six years.
The Central Presbyterian Church was the scene yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Barbara Gaylord Cook to George Purnell MacGregor.
St. Joseph, patron of the workers, worked overtime yesterday at helping to straighten out the tangled affairs of Dorothy Day and her "House of Hospitality" for the poor.

Some large-scale advertising of new food products is in the planning. Anderson, Clayton Co., looking ahead to expansion in the packaged foods field, said yesterday it would change the name of its Mrs. Tucker's Products division to the Anderson,
Republican politics at Albany is making it '"very difficult" for the city to repeal its $5 and $10 auto use tax, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
Two youths were stabbed last night in a fight that followed a raid by eight armed teen-agers in a Brooklyn school gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP)--The White House said today that it had received "many hundreds" of telegrams enthusiastically praising President Eisenhower's decision to seek a second term.

The election of Alexander L. Guterma as a director, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the F.L. Jacobs Company, following the resignation of Frank E. Howard from these posts, was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Riggs Jr., president.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- Two members of the House of Representatives obtained some free medical advice recently from Dr. Paul Dudley White, the President's heart consultant.
The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, first major railroad to go into reorganization under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act after it was passed in 1933, vesterday was the last one out.

AT this time each year the National Institute of Arts and Letters opens an exhibition in the galleries of its parent organization, the American Academy of Arts and Letters, in that remarkable quadrangle of buildings on Broadway ...

St. John's University pulled steadily away in the second half to score a 75-66 triumph over New York University in the second game at Madison Square Garden before 3,981 persons last night. This was the last college basketball program of the regular season.
HONIARA, Solomon Islands, March 1 (Reuters)--A dozen passengers from the missing launch Arakarimoa have been found after sixty-four days on the open sea, it was announced today.
Float dropped $453,000,000 on a daily average basis in the week ended on Wednesday, thus increasing pressure on member bank reserves, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Events today: PhilharmonicSymphony, Bruno Walter, conductor, Myra Hess, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Yerdi's "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Nadyne Brewer, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Frantz Casseus, guitarist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) --L.L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, suggested today that Congress allow the automobile industry itself to deal with "phantom freight" charges on automobiles.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Senator William F. Knowland of California warned President Eisenhower today that his re-election would be imperiled unless he gave heed to the wishes of the orthodox Republicans.

Retailers are spending more money on newspaper and direct-mail advertising than ever before, but they have "strangely failed" to use television, which lends itself to visual demonstration, it was reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 1--Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in 1955 had net profit of $157,117,28, a gain of 34 per cent from the $117,160,000 reported for 1954 and the highest in the company's history. Robert E. Wilson, chairman, and Frank O. Prior, president, made this report to stockholders today.

Wall Street was represented at the crossroads yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane opened a new investment information center on the main concourse of Grand
Columbia's fencing squad won the Ivy League championship last night, defeating Princeton, 14--13, at University Hall.

MOSCOW, March 1 (Reuters) --The name of the Commander in Chief of the Soviet Navy, Admiral of the Fleet Nikolai G. Kuznetsov, was missing today from a list of top military leaders who signed a tribute in newspapers here to a dead comrade.

SAYVILLE, L.I., March 1-- Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright was designated here today for a third term in Congress at a meeting of the executive committee of the Suffolk County Republican Committee. The nominating convention is to be held here next Thursday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 29-- Relations between South Vietnam and Cambodia have deteriorated to the point that Vietnam has now closed their common border.

The United States Government acknowledges receipt of the Soviet Government's further note of Feb. 18 objecting to the flight of meteorological balloons by the United States and proposing an exhibit of the material in the Soviet Government's possession.
WASHINGTON, March 1--New York State sought today to counter a move that threatened to deprice it of at least $500,000,000 in Federal highway aid.
The president of the taxi drivers' union here and a fellow organizer were arrested yesterday afternoon as violence developed in their campaign to organize cabbies.
WASHINGTON, March 1-- President Eisenhower will support Vice President Richard M. Nixon for renomination if Mx. Nixon wants it.
Miss Autherine J. Lucy left the inflamed atmosphere of Alabama yesterday and flew to New York.
A skyscraper with exterior walls of bronze and glass will be erected on Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, March 1--BorgWarner Corporation set new records last year in both sales and earnings, Roy C. Ingersoll, chairman and president, said today. He also announced that the company was engaged in extensive diversification and predicted 1956 would be one of its "very best years."
The Welfare and Health Council of New York City announced yesterday that it would oppose a state charities registration board.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)--Following is the vote by which the House passed and returned to the Senate today the Upper Colorado River bill:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1--Twentieth Century-Fox is going to have to share Marilyn Monroe with Warner Brothers.
ALBANY, March 1--A constitutional amendment to create a new State Department of Local Government uses proposed to the Legislature today.

The fruits of general national prosperity in 1955 were many, good and varied. In part, they took material shape as food, clothing, automobiles and the like. But in part, too, they took the shape of prudent provision for the future. How vast such measures were in the aggregate ...

Alexandria, La., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $8,300,000 in the public market to finance public utility installations. An issue of revenue bonds will be offered on March 29. Dated May 1, 1956, they will come due serially on May 1 from 1959 to 1986.

Unfavorable shopping weather on several important retail selling days held year-to-year volume gains of New York department stores to 5.5 per cent in the month just ended, despite the advantage of one extra business day.

Actors Equity is permitting Siobhan McKenna to depict the title role in George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan" at the Harvard University Drama Festival in the summer. In this instance, the union waived its rule that alien performers are required to wait six months between engagements.

WASHINGTON, March 1-- Secretary of State Dulles said today that United States membership in the International Organization for Trade Cooperation was essential to bolster free world economic unity against Communist "cold war" tactics.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that President Eisenhower would have to conduct "a vigorous campaign" if he was to win re-election.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York started its campaign in the Bronx last night with contributions of $280,000.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., March 1--Gustave Stubbs Lobrano, managing editor of The New Yorker magazine, died today at his home, 325 Bedford Road. He had undergone a gall bladder operation on Dec. 29 at the New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 53 years old.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 1 --The State of Louisiana struck at the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today with a law suit seeking to oust the group from this state. The action is based on a 1924 law that was aimed at the Ku Klux Klan.

WAISTLINES may wander from season to season, hems may move up or down, but some styles remain favorites through the years. These simple, almost timeless clothes predominate in the spring collections shown this week at Abraham Straus and Russeks.

THE battle of the sexes usually is a flourishing one--even where teen-agers are concerned. The ammuntiion used in such youthful skirmishes is the lively subject of a new booklet whose aim, it is explained, is to ease the situation.

The highest incidence of vehicular accidents in January occurred between 6 and 8 P.M. on Mondays, a Police Department survey disclosed yesterday. In the thirty-one-day period fifty-one persons were killed and 2,304 persons injured in 871 automobile mishaps in the city.

Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches in the metropolitan area will join forces tomorrow in an ecumenical service of worship at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) --The Department of Commerce said today a preliminary estimate indicates exports during January amounted to $1,278,000,000
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP)--Senator Harley M. Kilgore, West Virginia Democrat, was buried with full military honors today in Arlington National Cemetery.
LONDON, March 2 (AP)--The Rev. Dr. Reginald John Campbell, who was regarded as one of Britain's greatest preachers, died yesterday in his East Sussex home. He was 89 years old.

George W. Hudtwalker Sr., of 69-11 Forest Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, described by Brooklyn Dodger baseball officials as probably the team's No. 1 fan, died yesterday in Wyckoff Heights Hospital after an illness of three months. His age was 75.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 2-- Adlai E. Stevenson admonished the North today to put its own house in order before "we cast a stone at Alabama" on desegregation:

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The Senate's limited investigation of the oil lobby failed again today to crack the mystery of John M. Neff's adventures in Iowa. But another chapter to the story was promised Monday.
GUELMA, Algeria, Feb. 22-- What is the prospect of ending the fifteen-month-old Algerian nationalist rebellion this year?
A full-size model of the Susan Constant, the flagship of the fleet that carried the first permanent English settlers to America in 1607, is under construction in a West Norfolk, Va., shipyard.
RUMSON, N.J., March 2-- Miss Alicia Todd Van Iderstine was married to John Rankin Howie here tonight in the chantry of St. George's-by-the-River Protestant Episcopal Church.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- Mark Zborowski, an admitted secret police agent of the Soviet Union in Europe in the Nineteen Thirties, swore today he had been threatened with death for refusing to continue as a spy in the United States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2--"One Way Ticket to Hell," a feature-length documentary-type movie about young dope addicts, has won first prize for 1954-55 in the Screen Producers Guild Intercollegiate Awards competition. The film was produced as a thesis by a student at the University of California at Los Angeles.
It may well be hard in London and Amman for some to realize that the strong web of interests shared by Britain and Jordan is dissolving.
Tight-lipped and shaky, Miss Autherine J. Lucy told a news conference here yesterday that she intended to return to Birmingham, Ala., "within the next week."
PRINCETON, N.J., March 2 --Clergymen of town and gown joined this afternoon in a service of intercession for Negro ministers leading the bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala.
ROME, March 2--Pope Pius XII received today a large cake adorned with eighty candles on his eightieth birthday. It also was the seventeenth anniversary of his elevation to the pontificate.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., March 2--An armed thug stole more than $188,000 in bills of $1 to $100 denominations today from the County Trust Company's drive-in branch at 211 Irving Avenue.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2--When, a little over a year ago, the Yankees bagged Bob Turley in a record eighteenplayer deal with the Baltimore Orioles experts were asking: Does the acquisition of Bullet Bob mean a pennant for the Yankees?
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 --The dispute between James C. Petrillo and some members of local 47 of his American Federation of Musicians broadened today.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 2 (AP)--Jimmy Demaret of Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., gained a tie for the lead with George Bayer of Cincinnati today at the midpoint in the $12,500 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

CHICAGO, March 2--An antitrust indictment was returned by a Federal grand jury today against the J.P. Seeburg Corporation of Chicago, described as the country's largest manufacturer of coin operated phonographs.
On any clear evening when the wind is gentle and not huffing and puffing through the trees now supple with sap, one may discover on a walk through park or rural roadway--spring.
The 1935 Viking Fund medals and cash awards were presented last night to three scholars--two American and one British--for their scientific achievements.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- The United States withheld again today the yes-or-no answer Israel has been seeking in her request for arms assistance.
Mel Barnwell of Boys High cut two-tenths of a second off a 21-year-old 220-yard dash record last night at the fifty-second annual Public Schools Athletic League indoor track championships.
Three waterway organizations have protested the rush-hour "closed periods" proposed for the Whitestone Parkway and Northern Boulevard Bridges over Flushing Creek in Queens.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- Administration spokesmen completed pleas to the House Ways and Means Committee today on behalf of a bill that would make the United States a member of the proposed Organization for Trade Cooperation.

Oils, rails and coppers yesterday once more led the stock market to higher ground. The rails made a new high for 1956 in advance of the award of a general rate increase. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 2,860,000 shares from 2,410,000 on Thursday.
As publicity-shy as British, policy in the Middle East, the small, courageous man known as Glubb Pasha--Lord Glubb--is almost as legendary in the Arab world as T.E. Lawrence.
AMMAN, Jordan, March 2-- Jordan today ousted the British commander of her Arab Legion, Lieut. Gen. John Bagot Glubb.
A retired Air Force general has been hired by Pan American World Airways to advise it on changing from piston to jet operations.
There is no likelihood of a serious slump in homebuilding, according to Earl B. Schwulst, president of the Bowery Savings Bank.

EAST LANSING, Mich., March 2 (AP)--Greg Bell, a 25-year-old Indiana sophomore, shattered the Big Ten broad-jump record tonight with a leap of 24 feet 11 5/8 inches in the preliminary of the conference indoor track and field championshins.

MIAMI, March 2 (UP)--The Darby Dan Farm's Clear Dawn a 33-1 shot with the closing-day crowd of 19,357, beat the Calu met Farm's Miss Arlette by a nose today in the $40,100 Black Helen Handicap for fillies and mares at Hialeah.
Once again the nation's railroads have gone to Washington with great expectations only to come away with a feeling of frustration.

Miss Katherine M. Breen, a life member of the Telephone Pioneers of America, died yesterday at her home, 11 Bay View Place, Tompkinsville, S.I. She retired several years ago after many years of service with the New York Telephone Company.
Sales and earnings of the Lone Star Cement Corporation last year exceeded the record highs attained in 1954.

HOT porridge, which inevitably started a day for earlier Americans, is as outmoded now as the wood-burning range and the one-horse shay. But cereals like hominy, buckwheat and corn meal still may appear deliciously, if somewhat differently, at breakfast.

The United States Government reports that at the very time the Soviets launched their campaign against a "violation of their air space" by American weather balloons the Soviets themselves were sending up similar balloons into the air space of other nations.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin M. Ashcraft 3d of Chicago and Washington have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Avis Ann Ashcraft, to Ensign John Vliet Nungesser, U.S.N.R. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold V. Nungesser of Short Hills, N.J.
LONDON, March 2--The British Government expressed today "deep shock" over the dismissal of Lieut. Gen. John Bagot Glubb as commander of the Arab Legion.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- Secretary of State Dulles set out today on a three-week visit to Asia in which he hopes to get a clearer perspective of the new Soviet campaign of enticement.

It is gratifying to know that President Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is investigating the Teamsters' pact with the International Longshoremen's Association to cooperate in organization activities, negotiations and strikes and that he will take whatever action is warranted ...
Directors of the Borg-Warner Corporation have raised the quarterly common dividend to 60 cents, payable on May 1, from 50 cents paid previously.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 2 (AP)--Fred Merkle, former major league baseball player who was best remembered for a "boner" that cost the New York Giants the pennant in 1908, died today. He was 67 years old.
As the second step in its new effort to acquaint parents with what is happening in the city schools, the Board of Education is turning a spotlight on its spelling program.
WASHINGTON, March 2--The Administration announced today that Indonesia had agreed to buy $91,800,000 worth of surplus farm products.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- President Eisenhower has prepared another letter to Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier, calling for Russian cooperation in new East-West disarmament efforts.

On Wednesday the New York Stock Exchange ticker ran for a time nineteen minutes behind the floor. That means that investors, speculators and drugstore economists who were clustered about the 2,428 tickers in this country, Canada and Cuba were getting news nineteen minutes late.
A philosophical bank robber with a penchant for the hour of 2:30 P.M. was seized in the Bronx yesterday, apparently just before he was to try to repeat a crime of four months earlier.

Dr. Urho Kekkonen was inaugurated as Finland's eighth President this week almost simultaneously with the beginning of an economic catastrophe in that country, the beginning of a struggle between organized workers and organized farmers.

The threat of congestion in the new capital market this spring is heightened by a further substantial build-up in the backlog of new corporate financing registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
BIRMINGHAM, March 2--Four men accused of participating in the mob action at the University of Alabama against Autherine J. Lucy filed suit today for $4,000,000 damages.
BRESLAU, Poland, March 2-- Every one of the new Poland's tortuous problems is reflected here in microcosm. Therefore it symbolizes the agonizing demographic war between Slav and Teuton.
HANOVER, N.H., March 2-- The Eisenhower Administration was accused tonight of "propaganda, procrastination and postponement" in its failure to live up to election promises.

FRANCONIA, N.H., March 2 --The son of a Colorado mining camp superintendent and the daughter of a New Hampshire potato farmer enabled the West and East to share downhill honors at the national junior skiing championships today.

A 28-year-old man who gave his occupation as "investor and collector of mortgages" was arrested yesterday on charges of illegal business practices in Queens County. These were said to have netted him more than $100,000 in the last eighteen month. He is Leonard H. Schlosser of 303 Oxford Bouleyard, Garden City, L.I.
"Appointment With Adventure" has received a new shortterm lease on life.

A twelve-story and penthouse building containing offices and light manufacturing space and occupying a plot 68 by 100 feet at 145 West Forty-fifth Street has been purchased by a syndicate of investors headed by J.P. and Manville Abramson.

CAIRO, March 2--Jordan's ouster of Lieut. Gen. John Bagot Glubb as army commander was viewed in Cairo as a far-reaching victory for Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and a blow to Britain and the West in the Middle East.

"THE SHADOW OF MY HAND," by Holger Chaill, is a majestically sweeping novel of life and love and death on the Dakota prairie. You may discount my admiration for it because I lived happily near that hard and admirable country for several years.
MOSCOW, March 2--A United States corporation was granted tonight the right to manufacture a turbodrill developed by the Soviet petroleum industry for digging wells through hard rock.
ZURICH, Switzerland, March 2--Western parliamentary socialism began pondering here today communism's recent proposal of remarriage.
BOSTON, March 2 (AP)--Fort Wayne's Western Division leaders, paced by Mel Hutchins, came from behind in the second half tonight to score a 104-97 victory over the New York Knickerbockers.

The Appellate Division, which has disciplinary powers over Municipal Court justices, and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York will investigate Municipal Court Justice Carson DeWitt Baker's traffic ticket indiscretions.

PARIS, March 2--France virtually ended today her 44-year-old protectorate over Morocco. A joint declaration issued in the name of the French Government and of Sultan Mohammed ben Youssef of Morocco declared that the protectorate treaty of 1912 "no longer corresponds henceforth to the necessities of Text of French-Moroccan joint statement is on Page 3. modern life, and can no longer govern French-Moroccan relations."
FIVE of the one-man shows of the week are diverse paintings by artists of France, Spain and the United States.
Eight hundred members of Actors Equity Association yesterday recommended that the union's governing body, the council, take the lead to effect a merger of all performer unions on a federated basis.
THE Interior Department has just issued its annual report telling American hunters and anglers now many they are, where they are and how much they spent last year for the right to hunt and fish.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 2 --The proposal of the Second Hoover Commission that Congress set up a clearly defined non-career, political executive group in the Federal Government was assailed here today as "unrealistic."
Along about 10 o'clock tonight, a clerk-of-course will scurry around among the athletes on the Madison Square Garden floor crying "All out for the Columbian Mile."
The Government of the French Republic and His Majesty Mohammed V, Sultan of Morocco, state their desire to give its full effect to the declaration of La Celle SaintCloud of Nov. 6, 1955.
MEDIA, Pa., March 2 (AP)-- Twenty-six officials and members of Local 107, United Electrical Workers, independent, today were taken to Broadmeadows prison for an indefinite term on contempt charges.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- Thadeusz Kassern, a former Polish Consul who attempted suicide last year in despair over his unsuccessful efforts to become an American citizen, won an important concession from the Immigration and Naturalization Service today.

MADISON, Wis., March 2 (AP) --Wisconsin's top Constitutional officers headed a delegation today that formally filed President Eisenhower's name in the Presidential preference primary April 3. They also completed the line-up for a test-by-vote of Republican policy.
WASHINGTON, March 2--The Senate elected Senator James O. Eastland, a far-right-wing Mississippi Democrat and a bitter pro-segregationist, as chairman of its powerful Judiciary Committee today.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 --The Little Colonel may have lost his shortstop's commission today.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- George L. Marcus, a Brooklyn Musician, believes he has solved the bass viol problem. This week he patented a way of putting the big instrument on wheels.
ALBANY, March 2--Attorney General Jacob K. Javits is inquiring into what happens to the money paid for unredeemed gasoline discount coupons sold by the Automobile Club of New York.
Like many a visitor with time to kill, President Giovanni Gronchi of Italy did some sightseeing last night among the city's lights.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) --The House Appropriations Committee took the advice of President Eisenhower's doctor today and voted more money than the President had requested for heart disease research.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad lost $1,524,196 in January and expects February's results to show "another substantial loss," George Alpert, president, announced yesterday.

PARIS, March 2--Christian Pineau, French Foreign Minister, severely criticized the United States and Britain today for what he called the absence of a common Western policy, notably in the Middle and Far East.

House passage of the $756,000,000 bill to harness, store and use the waters of the Upper Colorado makes it virtually certain that this gigantic power and irrigation project will soon be enacted into law.
BUYING a carpet is a major homefurnishings investment. If a mistake is made, it will be under foot for years.
WASHINGTON, March 2-- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, indicated today that he might like to retire from the Cabinet at the end of the year even if President Eisenhower was re-elected.

Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L.I., and Robert Grant 3d of New York reached the final of the amateur court tennis championship of the United States yesterday. They will meet at 11:30 this morning at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
MOSCOW, March 2--Premier H.C. Hansen of Denmark will refuse to discuss with the Russians the status of United States bases in Greenland during his twelve-day official visit here.
The record-breaking year for travel into New York City reported by the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau is satisfying evidence that it pays to go out looking for business.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 2-- Archbishop Makarios blamed Britain today for the breakdown of negotiations on Cyprus autonomy.
Carmelo Costa, a Brooklyn lightweight, scored a close victory over Baby Vasquez of Mexico City in the main event of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday withheld approval of a match requested for the St. Nicholas Arena for Monday, March 12. Julius Helfand, chairman of the commission, said that he would conduct a hearing on the matter on Monday.

THE New York City Ballet is definitely in fine fettle these nights. Its program at the City Center last night was another manifestation of it, with the Balanchine-Stravinsky-Chagall "Firebird" and the Balanchine-Glinka-Karinska "Pas de Trois" making their season's bows in impeccable form.

North American friends of Peru are becoming more and more disturbed over the way President Odria is handling the aftermath of the suppressed uprising in Iquitos. This is not what was expected of General Odria, and to citizens here, brought up in the traditions of civic rights, including habeas corpus, and of freedom of the press, his actions are disturbing.
One of the busiest ski areas in the United States is right here in the heart of Manhattan. It's the State of Vermont Information Center.
The six-story apartment building accommodating twenty-eight families at 76 Remsen Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Mrs. Fanny Goldstein to Mr. and Mrs. Paul Oste.

One of the largest gatherings of leading clergymen in the history of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will witness the institution of a new rector of Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn Heights.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 2 --Mrs. Gertrude Foster Brown, a leader in women's affairs in New York for half a century, died here yesterday after several months' illness. She was 88 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 2-- The railroads today won permanent freight rate increases of as much as 6 per cent without fear of future refunds. The carriers estimate the increases will give them an additional $400,000,000 a year in revenue.

Since one minute after midnight Wednesday military pilots affiliated with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and civilian pilots operating under the rules of the International Civil Aviation Organization have been using a new phonetic alphabet in international voice communications.

The flying blonde ponytail that is Carol Heiss' trademark gyrated at Iceland yesterday as she repeated the routine that had won the women's world figure-skating championship for the 16-year-old girl from Ozone Park, Queens.

Pontiac has asked to be relieved of its sponsorship, of "Playwrights '56" during the summer months. Produced by Fred Coe, the drama series is televised on alternate Tuesdays from 9:30 to 10:30 P.M.

Governor Harriman accused President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles last night of unwittingly helping the Soviet campaign for world domination.
ROME, March 4--It is not by chance that Pope Pius XII chose a dove of peace for his arms and the words "Peace is the fruit of justice" for his motto.
ALBANY, March 4--Governor Harriman invited Republican legislative leaders today to meet with him again tomorrow to discuss a compromise on income tax reduction.
HELSINKI, Finland, March 4 --The effect of the general strike in this capital city of 400,000 grew worse today as further walkouts threatened.

WASHINGTON, March 4-- Clare Boothe Luce is going back to her post as Ambassador in Rome after all. There was serious talk of keeping her here this time and giving her a job in the White House that would have enabled her to do a lot of campaigning for President Eisenhower.

HONG KONG, March 4--Communist China warned again tonight that it might pull out of the stalemated ambassadorial talks with the United States if these talks were "dragged out" further along present lines.
Thousands of Negroes gathered in city churches yesterday to fight segregation with prayer and contributions.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4-- As Willie Mays goes so go the Giants. Something similar used to be said about Babe Ruth and the Yankees and for many years it was a slogan around the Stadium.

NEW DELHI, India, March 4--Selwyn Lloyd, British Foreign Secretary, said today the large-scale supply of Communist arms to Egypt was "one of the most worrying features" of the situation in the Middle East.

HOLLYWOOD Calif., March 4 --Walter Wanger's second production for R.K.O.-Radio Pictures will be "The Day They Gave Babies Away." The property is the fourth in the "Climax!" television productions to be scheduled for motion picture filming by R.K.O.

The Rev. William Howard Melish announced yesterday that only a court order or the expressed wishes of his congregation would make him relinquish the pulpit of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 4--Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lock Haven, Pa., had the bestof-breed winner in the specialty of the Pekingese Club of America today in Ch. Tulo Yu Chuo of Orchard Hill. The event draw fifty-four dogs to the Roger Smith Hotel.

Approximately $100,000,000 in orders for twenty new vessels have been placed by Stavros S. Niarchos, wealthy Greek shipowner. The project is one of the most ambitious private construction programs ever launched.
HONOLULU, March 4 (UP)-- Henry J. Kaiser's speed boat Hawaii-Kai flipped over today while roaring over Keehi Lagoon at 193 miles per hour and with a world unlimited hydroplane record assured.

WHAT is needed sometimes to give a good dinner a fresh twist is an amusing first course --one that excites the eye, provokes the palate and prompts guests to ask the hostess in admiration and curiosity, "Where did you bet this idea?"

DETROIT, March 4 (UP)-- Jean Beliveau and Dickie Moore blasted two goals each tonight to lead the National Hockey League champion Montreal Canadiens to a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Red Wings before 13,804 fans at Olympia.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4--Long-brewing dissension between motion picture and television unionists approached a first-class jurisdictional dispute today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4--The Yankees are again one big happy family with just one objective in mind--the winning of another American League pennant.
Don Bragg, George Sydnor, Charley Jenkins, Charley Pratt, Arnie Sowell, Ron Delany and others turned in better performances than Wes Santee in the Knights of Columbus track meet last Saturday night.
The Radio Corporation of America's Victor record division will put on what it calls "an advertising blitz" beginning next Sunday to introduce a novel plan for selling phonograph records.
Puerto Rico is developing a stronger lift for its "Operation Bootstrap."
